Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3556279 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Lower bounds on coloring numbers from hardness hypotheses in pcf theory. (English summary)
Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 144 (2016), no. 12, 5371–5383.
03E04 (03C15 03E05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-12-16 Review Published2017-03-21

The paper under review focuses on the interplay between pcf theory and a question about chromatic numbers in graph theory. In order to describe its content, we need to give some preliminaries. Let $G=(V,E)$ be an undirected graph. A coloring $c\:V\rightarrow\theta$ is a proper vertex coloring iff no two adjacent vertices share the same color. The chromatic number $\chi(G)$ is the minimal $\kappa$ such that there exists a proper vertex coloring $c\:V\rightarrow\kappa$. Two variations of the chromatic number are discussed in this paper:
$(\aleph)$
the list-chromatic number (also called the choosability number), denoted by $\chi_\ell(G)$, and
$(\beth)$
the coloring number, denoted by ${\rm Col}(G)$.
The list-chromatic number of $G=(V,E)$ is the minimal $\kappa$ such that for every assignment $\{L(v):v\in V\}$ of lists (sets), each consisting of at most $\kappa$ many colors, one can find a proper vertex coloring $c$ for which $c(v)\in L(v)$ whenever $v\in V$. The coloring number of $G=(V,E)$ is the minimal $\kappa$ so that there exists a well-ordering $<^*$ of $V$ for which $|\{u:\{u,v\}\in E \land u<^* v\}|<\kappa$ for every $v\in V$.
   The basic question in the background of this paper is about the relationship between these concepts. It is easy to verify that $\chi(G)\leq\chi_\ell(G)\leq{\rm Col}(G)$ for any graph $G$. Is it possible to bound ${\rm Col}(G)$ by some function of $\chi_\ell(G)$? A positive answer for finite graphs was given by N. Alon [Random Structures Algorithms 16 (2000), no. 4, 364–368; MR1761581]. Alon asked whether such an upper bound for ${\rm Col}(G)$, in terms of $\chi_\ell(G)$, can be proved for infinite graphs. This question was answered affirmatively by M. Kojman [Israel J. Math. 201 (2014), no. 2, 585–592; MR3265296], who proved that ${\rm Col}(G)\leq \beth_\omega(\chi_\ell(G))$.
   By and large, cardinal arithmetic at infinite cardinals is beyond the provability forces of ZFC. However, Shelah's pcf theory excavated deep principles and statements, many of which hold in ZFC. One of the most important among these is the so-called revised GCH (or RGCH). Roughly, the "easy to manipulate'' size of $\Cal{P}(\kappa)$ is replaced by the stable covering measurements of $[\lambda]^\kappa$. Many instances of these principles hold in ZFC for these pcf analogues of GCH.
   Kojman employed RGCH in order to prove that ${\rm Col}(G)\leq \beth_\omega(\chi_\ell(G))$, thus getting an upper bound in ZFC. A natural question is whether this upper bound can be improved, still in ZFC. Comparing with the upper bound found by Alon in the case of finite graphs, in which ${\rm Col}(G)$ is bounded by a finite number of exponents of $\chi_\ell(G)$, an appealing theorem would be that there is some $n\in\omega$ such that ${\rm Col}(G)\leq \beth_n(\chi_\ell(G))$ for all $G$. Another point of view which has been discussed by Kojman is the role of RGCH within the proof. Can one replace the use of RGCH by similar pcf theorems which yield a better upper bound?
   Shelah shows, in the current paper, that Kojman's bound is optimal from the historical time slice in which we are ensconced. In §1 he proves that the bound of $\beth_\omega(\chi_\ell(G))$ implies the weak RGCH (see Definition 1.1). Thence he proceeds, in §2, to show that improvements upon this bound result in strengthenings of the weak RGCH. Proving these stronger statements in ZFC seems currently quite far. On the other hand, our poor ability to change basic pcf notions by means of forcing points to the fact that any improvement of Kojman's bound will not be easy.
Reviewed by Shimon Garti

    References
  1. Noga Alon, Degrees and choice numbers, Random Structures Algorithms 16 (2000), no. 4, 364–368, DOI 10.1002/1098-2418(200007)16:4$\langle$364::AID-RSA5$\rangle$3.3.CO;2-S. MR1761581 MR1761581
  2. P. Erdős and A. Hajnal, On chromatic number of graphs and set-systems, Acta Math. Acad. Sci. Hungar 17 (1966), 61–99. MR0193025 MR0193025

  13. Saharon Shelah, The generalized continuum hypothesis revisited, Israel J. Math. 116 (2000), 285–321, DOI 10.1007/BF02773223. MR1759410 MR1759410
  14. Shmuel Lifsches and Saharon Shelah, Random graphs in the monadic theory of order, Arch. Math. Logic 38 (1999), no. 4-5, 273–312, DOI 10.1007/s001530050129. Logic Colloquium '95 (Haifa). MR1697962 MR1697962
  15. Saharon Shelah, Was Sierpiński right? IV, J. Symbolic Logic 65 (2000), no. 3, 1031–1054, DOI 10.2307/2586687. MR1791363 MR1791363
  16. Saharon Shelah, Anti-homogeneous partitions of a topological space, Sci. Math. Jpn. 59 (2004), no. 2, 203–255. Special issue on set theory and algebraic model theory. MR2062196 MR2062196
  17. Saharon Shelah, Two cardinals models with gap one revisited, MLQ Math. Log. Q. 51 (2005), no. 5, 437–447, DOI 10.1002/malq.200410036. MR2163755 MR2163755
  18. Saharon Shelah, Pcf and abelian groups, Forum Math. 25 (2013), no. 5, 967–1038, DOI 10.1515/forum-2013-0119. MR3100959 MR3100959
  19. S. Shelah, Forcing axioms for $\lambda$-complete $\mu^+$-c.c., 1036 in Shelah-s list; preprint.

MR3549381 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(1-RTG)
Department of Mathematics, Rutgers University
Piscataway (New Brunswick), New Jersey, 08854
; Steprāns, Juris(3-YORK)
Department of Mathematics, York University
Toronto, Ontario, M3J 1P3, Canada

When automorphisms of $\Cal P(\kappa)/[\kappa]^{<\aleph_0}$ are trivial off a small set. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 235 (2016), no. 2, 167–182.
03E05 (03E20)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-11-29 Review Published2017-03-20

A homomorphism $\Phi\:{\Cal P}(\kappa)/\Cal Fin\longrightarrow {\Cal P}(\kappa)/\Cal Fin$ is $\lambda$-trivial if there is a set $S\in [\kappa]^\lambda$ and a one-to-one function $F\:\kappa\sbs S\longrightarrow \kappa$ such that $F\langle X\rangle\in \Phi([X])$ for every $X\subseteq \kappa\sbs S$. (Here, $F\langle X\rangle$ denotes the image of $X$ under $F$.)
   The article under review proves the following result:
   Theorem 3.1. If $\kappa>2^{\aleph_0}$ and $\kappa$ is less than the first inaccessible cardinal, then every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\kappa)/\Cal Fin$ is $2^{\aleph_0}$-trivial.
   The inductive proof of this theorem uses several lemmas which are interesting on their own.
   Lemma 3.3. If $\kappa^{\aleph_0}=\kappa$ and $\nu\leq 2^\kappa$ then every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\nu)/\Cal Fin$ is $\kappa$-trivial.
   Lemmas 3.4 and 3.5. If $\kappa$ is a singular cardinal and for every $\lambda<\kappa$ every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\lambda)/\Cal Fin$ is $2^{\aleph_0}$-trivial, then every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\kappa)/\Cal Fin$ is $2^{\aleph_0}$-trivial.
   Lemma 3.6. Suppose that
(1)
${\rm cf}(\kappa)=\omega$ and $2^\mu<\kappa$ for each $\mu<\kappa$, and
(2)
if $\mu\leq \kappa$, then every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\mu)/\Cal Fin$ is $2^{\aleph_0}$-trivial.
Then every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\rho)/\Cal Fin$ is $\kappa$-trivial for every cardinal $\rho$ such that $\kappa^+\leq\rho\leq \kappa^{\aleph_0}$.
   The proofs of Lemmas 3.3, 3.5 and 3.6 occupy most of the article and are presented in sections 4, 5 and 6, respectively.
   It should be noted that cardinals not greater than the continuum were dealt with in [P. B. Larson and P. McKenney, Fund. Math. 233 (2016), no. 3, 271–291; MR3480121]. Using a result from that paper, the authors of the current article show the following:
   Corollary 1.2. If MA and OCA both hold and if $\kappa$ is less than the first inaccessible cardinal, then every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\kappa)/\Cal Fin$ is trivial.
   Corollary 1.2 contradicts a claim at the end of [B. Veličković, Topology Appl. 49 (1993), no. 1, 1–13; MR1202874]. In that paper, Veličković proved that PFA implies that for every $\kappa$, every automorphism of ${\Cal P}(\kappa)/\Cal Fin$ is trivial. It remains open whether the conjunction of MA and OCA suffices for this conclusion.
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

    References
  1. B. Balcar and R. Frankiewicz, To distinguish topologically the spaces $m^\ast$. II, Bull. Acad. Polon. Sci. Sér. Sci. Math. Astronom. Phys. 26 (1978), 521–523. MR0511955
  2. D. Chodounský, A. Dow, K. P. Hart and H. de Vries, The Katowice problem and autohomeomorphisms of $\omega_0^\ast$, arXiv:1307.3930 (2013). cf. MR3563083
  3. P. Larson and P. McKenney, Automorphisms of $\Cal{P}(\lambda)/\Cal{I}_k$, Fund. Math. 233 (2016), 271–291. MR3480121
  4. W. Rudin, Homogeneity problems in the theory of Čech compactifications, Duke Math. J. 23 (1956), 409–419. MR0080902
  5. W. Rudin, Note of correction, Duke Math. J. 23 (1956), 633. MR0080903
  6. S. Shelah, Proper Forcing, Lecture Notes in Math. 940, Springer, Berlin, 1982. MR0675955
  7. B. Velickovic, OCA and automorphisms of $\Cal{P}(\omega)$/fin, Topology Appl. 49 (1993), 1–13. MR1202874
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR3523657 Reviewed
Matet, Pierre(F-CAEN-LM)
Laboratoire de Mathématiques Nicolas Oresme (LMNO), Universit'e de Caen Basse Normandie
14032 Caen, France
; Péan, Cédric(F-NEXWAYS)
Nexways
75002 Paris, France
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Cofinality of normal ideals on $[\lambda]^{<\kappa}$ I. (English summary)
Arch. Math. Logic 55 (2016), no. 5-6, 799–834.
03E05 (03E35 03E55)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-10-04 Review Published2017-01-17

The notion of normal ideals has been extensively studied in the literature. The authors further generalize previous works of D. M. Carr, J.-P. Levinski and D. H. Pelletier [Arch. Math. Logic 30 (1990), no. 1, 59–72; MR1074449] on strong normality and of Y. Abe [Arch. Math. Logic 36 (1997), no. 6, 385–397; MR1477763] on $\delta$-normality to a broader notion. An ideal $I$ on $[\lambda]^{<\kappa}$ is called $[\delta]^{<\theta}$-normal (where $\delta \leq \lambda$ is an ordinal and $\theta\leq \kappa$ is a cardinal) if given $B_e\in I$ for $e \in [\delta]^{<\theta}$, we have $$ \{a \in [\lambda]^{<\kappa} \mid \exists e \in [a \cap \delta]^{<|a \cap \theta|}(a \in B_e)\} \in I. $$ A necessary and sufficient condition for the existence of such ideals is given (Proposition 3.19) and the smallest of such ideals, denoted as $\roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda}^{[\delta]^{<\theta}}$, is studied (§4–6).
   The paper also deals with the question of when we can have $\roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda}^{[\delta]^{<\theta}} = \roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda}^{[\delta']^{<\theta'}}\!\!{}| A$ for some $A$, where $\delta \leq \delta'$ and $\theta \leq \theta'$ but $(\delta,\theta)\neq (\delta',\theta')$ (see §7–8). In §9, the authors extend the well-known result of T. K. Menas [Ann. Math. Logic 7 (1974/75), 327–359; MR0357121] and show that for $\kappa \leq \lambda' \leq \lambda$, $\roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda'}^{[\min(\delta,\lambda')]^{<\theta}}$ is a projection of $\roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda}^{[\delta]^{<\theta}}$. The last section of this paper computes the cofinality of $\roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda}^{[\delta]^{<\theta}}$, i.e., the least size of a subcollection $J$ such that every member of $\roman{NS}_{\kappa,\lambda}^{[\delta]^{<\theta}}$ is contained in some member of $J$.
Reviewed by Xianghui Shi

    References
  1. Abe, Y.: A hierarchy of filters smaller than $CF_{\kappa\lambda}$. Arch. Math. Log. 36, 385–397 (1997) MR1477763
  2. Carr, D.M.: The minimal normal filter on $P_\kappa\lambda$. Proc. Am. Math. Soc. 86, 316–320 (1982) MR0667297

  8. Feng, Q.: An ideal characterization of Mahlo cardinals. J. Symb. Log. 54, 467–473 (1989) MR0997880

  11. Kunen, K.: Set Theory, Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, vol. 102. North-Holland, Amsterdam (1980) MR0597342
  12. Landver, A.: Singular Baire Numbers and Related Topics. Ph.D. Thesis, University of Wisconsin, Madison (1990) MR2685174
  13. Matet, P.: Un principe combinatoire en relation avec l'ultranormalité des idéaux. C. R. Acad. Sci. Paris Sér. I 307, 61–62 (1988) MR0954259
  14. Matet, P.: Concerning stationary subsets of $[\lambda]^{<\kappa}$. In: Steprāns J., Watson S. (eds.) Set Theory and Its Applications , Lecture Notes in Mathematics, vol. 1401, pp. 119–127. Springer, Berlin (1989) MR1031769

  17. Matet, P.: Large cardinals and covering numbers. Fundam. Math. 205, 45–75 (2009) MR2534178

  20. Shelah, S.: Cardinal Arithmetic, Oxford LogicGuides, vol. 29. Oxford University Press, Oxford (1994) MR1318912

MR3521114 Reviewed
Cherlin, Gregory(1-RTG)
Department of Mathematics, Rutgers University
Piscataway (New Brunswick), New Jersey, 08854
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Universal graphs with a forbidden subgraph: block path solidity. (English summary)
Combinatorica 36 (2016), no. 3, 249–264.
03C15 (05C60 05C63)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-09-26 Review Published2017-02-03

Let $C$ be a finite graph. We say that a graph $\Gamma $ is $C$-free if $\Gamma$ contains no subgraph isomorphic to $C$. We also say that a countable $C$-free graph $\Gamma$ is weakly universal (strongly universal) if every countable $C$-free graph is isomorphic to a subgraph (induced subgraph) of $\Gamma$. The authors consider the problem of finding conditions we have to put on a finite connected graph $C$ so that a universal $C$-free graph exists.
   The main result of the paper under review states that if $C$ is a finite connected block path, and there is a weakly universal $C$-free graph, then the blocks of $C$ are complete. The main techniques used in the proof were developed by Z. Füredi and P. Komjáth in [J. Graph Theory 25 (1997), no. 1, 53–58; MR1441978] and the authors in [J. Combin. Theory Ser. B 97 (2007), no. 3, 293–333; MR2305886].
Reviewed by Boriša Kuzeljević

    References
  1. G. Cherlin: Two problems on homogeneous structures, revisited, in: Proceedings of the AMS-ASL Special Session on Model Theoretic Methods in Finite Combinatorics, January 5–8, 2009, in Washington, DC.; 319–416 in Contemporary Mathematics, AMS, Providence, RI, 2011. MR3418640
  2. G. Cherlin and S. Shelah: Universal graphs with a forbidden subtree, J. Comb. Theory, Series B 97 (2007), 293–333. MR2305886
  3. G. Cherlin and L. Tallgren: Universal graphs with a forbidden near-path or 2-bouquet, J. Graph Theory 56 (2007), 41–63. MR2342786
  4. M. Džamonja: Club guessing and the universal models. Notre Dame J. Formal Logic 46 (2005), 283–300. MR2160658
  5. Z. Füredi and P. Komjáth: On the existence of countable universal graphs. J. Graph Theory 25 (1997), 53–58. MR1441978
  6. C. Ward Henson: A family of countable homogeneous graphs. Pacific J. Math. 38 (1971), 69–83. MR0304242
  7. P. Komjáth and J. Pach: Universal elements and the complexity of certain classes of infinite graphs. Discrete Math. 95 (1991), 255–270. MR1141942
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

MR3510831 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

No universal group in a cardinal. (English summary)
Forum Math. 28 (2016), no. 3, 573–585.
03C45 (03C50 03C55 03C65 03E04 03E75 20A15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-08-30 Review Published2017-01-13

The paper under review is concerned with the following general problem: given a first-order theory $T$ and an infinite cardinal $\lambda > |T|$, does $T$ have a universal model of cardinality $\lambda$ (i.e., a model of cardinality $\lambda$ in which every other model of cardinality $\lambda$ embeds)? If $2^{<\lambda} = \lambda$, the answer is easily shown to be positive. However, the question "is it consistent that $\lambda < 2^{<\lambda}$ and $T$ does not have a universal model in $\lambda$?'' turns out to be very interesting. Shelah has conjectured that it should be a dividing line: theories where this is inconsistent (at least if, say, $\lambda$ is a "nice'' regular cardinal) should be well behaved and theories where this is consistent should have strong non-structural properties. For example, stable, and even simple theories have quite a nice behavior with respect to universal models [see S. Shelah, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 80 (1996), no. 3, 229–255; MR1402297]. On the other hand, M. Kojman and Shelah [Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 58 (1992), no. 1, 57–72; MR1169786] have shown that linear orders (and more generally any theory with the strict order property) essentially do not have a universal model at regular cardinals where GCH fails (more precise cardinal arithmetic assumptions are provided in the paper). In [S. Shelah, op. cit.], the assumption that the strict order property holds was weakened to the so-called strong order property of order 4 ($\text{SOP}_4$).
   The present paper is concerned with whether the $\text{SOP}_4$ hypothesis can be weakened further, and in particular with the example of the theory of groups: by results of Shelah and A. Usvyatsov [Israel J. Math. 152 (2006), 245–270; MR2214463], this theory is $\text{SOP}_3$ but not $\text{SOP}_4$. The present paper introduces a new sufficient condition, which the author calls the olive property (a relative of the oak property from [M. Džamonja and S. Shelah, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 139 (2006), no. 1-3, 280–302; MR2206258]). The main results are that the theory of groups has the olive property, and that any theory with the olive property is badly behaved with respect to universal models, i.e., essentially it does not have universal models at any regular cardinals where GCH fails. An application to the universality problem for locally finite groups (first studied in [R. P. Grossberg and S. Shelah, Israel J. Math. 44 (1983), no. 4, 289–302; MR0710234]) is also given.
   The proof that the olive property implies non-existence of universal models at certain cardinals follows a general method introduced by Kojman and Shelah, based on club-guessing. The author notes that it is not known whether the negation of the olive property has any interesting consequences. Numerous other open questions are mentioned in the introduction.
Reviewed by Sebastien Vasey

    References
  1. M. Džamonja, Club guessing and the universal models, Notre Dame J. Form. Log. 46 (2005), 283–300. MR2160658
  2. M. Džamonja and S. Shelah, On the existence of universal models, Arch. Math. Logic 43 (2004), 901–936. MR2096141
  3. R. Grossberg and S. Shelah, On universal locally finite groups, Israel J. Math. 44 (1983), 289–302. MR0710234
  4. M. Kojman and S. Shelah, Non-existence of universal orders in many cardinals, J. Symbolic Logic 57 (1992), 875–891. MR1187454
  5. R. C. Lyndon and P. E. Schupp, Combinatorial Group Theory, Ergeb. Math. Grenzgeb. 89, Springer, Berlin, 1977. MR0577064
  6. S. Shelah, Independence results, J. Symbolic Logic 45 (1980), 563–573. MR0583374
  7. S. Shelah, Advances in cardinal arithmetic, in: Finite and Infinite Combinatorics in Sets and Logic (Banff 1991), NATO ASI Ser. C Math. Phys. Sci. 411, Kluwer, Dordrecht (1993), 355–383. MR1261217
  8. S. Shelah, The universality spectrum: Consistency for more classes, in: Combinatorics. Paul Erdős is Eighty (Keszthely 1993), vol. 1, Bolyai Soc. Math. Stud., János Bolyai Mathematical Society, Budapest (1993), 403–420. MR1249724
  9. S. Shelah, Toward classifying unstable theories, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 80 (1996), 229–255. MR1402297
  10. S. Shelah, Applications of PCF theory, J. Symbolic Logic 65 (2000), 1624–1674. MR1812172
  11. S. Shelah, On what I do not understand (and have something to say), model theory, Math. Jpn. 51 (2000), 329–377. MR1747306
  12. S. Shelah, Universal structures, preprint (2004), http://arxiv.org/abs/math/0405159; to appear in Notre Dame J. Form. Log.
  13. S. Shelah, Classification Theory for Abstract Elementary Classes, Stud. Log. (Lond.) 18, College Publications, London, 2009. MR2643267
  14. S. Shelah, Universal models consistently exist: Revisited, in preparation.
  15. S. Shelah, Minimal universality spectrum, in preparation.
  16. S. Shelah and A. Usvyatsov, Banach spaces and groups – Order properties and universal models, Israel J. Math. 152 (2006), 245–270. MR2214463
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR3509814 Reviewed
Machura, Michał(PL-SILS-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, University of Silesia
40-007 Katowice, Poland
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Tsaban, Boaz(IL-BILN)
Department of Mathematics, Bar-Ilan University
Ramat Gan 52900, Israel

The linear refinement number and selection theory. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 234 (2016), no. 1, 15–40.
03E17 (03E75 54C65)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-08-29 Review Published2017-01-05

In what follows, $\omega$ is the set of all natural numbers and $[\omega]^\omega$ denotes the family of all infinite subsets of $\omega$. If $A, B \in [\omega]^{\omega}$, $B \subseteq^* A$ means that $B \sbs A$ is finite. We assume the reader is familiar with the definitions of a number of well-known cardinal invariants of the continuum, such as $\germ{p}, \germ{b}, \germ{d}, \germ{s}$ and ${\rm cov}(\Cal{M})$; information on these cardinals may be found in [A. R. Blass, in Handbook of set theory. Vols. 1, 2, 3, 395–489, Springer, Dordrecht, 2010; MR2768685]. A subfamily $\Cal{F} \subseteq [\omega]^\omega$ is said to be centered if every non-empty, finite subset of $\Cal{F}$ has an infinite intersection, and it is said to be linear if it is linearly ordered by $\subseteq^*$. A family $\Cal{G} \subseteq [\omega]^\omega$ is a refinement of a family $\Cal{F} \subseteq [\omega]^{\omega}$ if for each $A \in \Cal{F}$ there is some $B \in \Cal{G}$ such that $B \subseteq^* A$. The linear refinement number, denoted by $\germ{lr}$, is the minimal cardinality of a centered subfamily of $[\omega]^\omega$ that has no linear refinement. A variation of $\germ{lr}$—namely, the linear excluded middle number $\germ{lx}$, defined in terms of subfamilies of the set $^\omega \omega$ of functions from $\omega$ into $\omega$—is also investigated in the paper (as well as the cardinal invariant $\germ{od}$, introduced in [H. Mildenberger, S. Shelah and B. Tsaban, Topology Appl. 154 (2007), no. 1, 263–276; MR2271787]).
   Given a bijectively enumerated, countably infinite cover $\Cal{U} = \{U_n: n < \omega\}$ of a topological space $X$, we say that $\Cal{U} \in O(X)$ if each $U_n$ is an open set; $\Cal{U} \in \Omega(X)$ if $\Cal{U} \in O(X)$ and each finite subset of $X$ is included in some member of $\Cal{U}$; $\Cal{U} \in \Gamma(X)$ if $\Cal{U} \in O(X)$ and each element of $X$ is included in all but finitely many members of $\Cal{U}$; and $\Cal{U} \in T^*(X)$ if the family $\{\{n: x \in U_n\}: x \in X\}$ is a subfamily of $[\omega]^{\omega}$ which has a linear refinement. We assume the reader is familiar with the definitions of the selection principles $S_1(\Cal{A},\Cal{B})$, $S_{{\rm fin}}(\Cal{A},\Cal{B})$ and $U_{{\rm fin}}(\Cal{A}, \Cal{B})$ (as introduced by M. Scheepers [Topology Appl. 69 (1996), no. 1, 31–62; MR1378387]), where $\Cal{A}$ and $\Cal{B}$ are any of the above-described families of open covers. Given a selection principle $\Cal{P}$, the critical cardinality of $\Cal{P}$, denoted by ${\rm non}(\Cal{P})$, is the minimal cardinality of a topological space $X$ which does not satisfy the selection principle $\Cal{P}$.
   In the paper under review, the authors compare $\germ{lr}$ and $\germ{lx}$ with other classical combinatorial characteristics of the continuum, and they also prove that such cardinal invariants estimate the critical cardinalities of a number of selective properties. Typical results of the paper are as follows:
   (i) It is consistent that $\germ{p} < \germ{lr} < \germ{c}$.
   (ii) $\germ{lr} = \germ{d}$ in all models of set theory where $\germ{c} \leqslant \aleph_2$.
   (iii) The cofinality of $\germ{lr}$ is uncountable.
   (iv) If $\germ{p} < \germ{b}$, then $\germ{lr} \leqslant \germ{b}$.
   (v) $\germ{lr} \leqslant \germ{lx} \leqslant \germ{d}$, and $\germ{b},\germ{s} \leqslant \germ{lx}$.
   (vi) ${\rm non}(S_1(\Gamma,T^*)) = {\rm non}(S_{{\rm fin}}(\Gamma,T^*)) = \germ{lx}$.
   (vii) ${\rm non}(S_1(\Omega,T^*)) = \min\{{\rm cov}(\Cal{M}),\germ{lr}\}$.
   (viii) ${\rm non}(S_1(T^*,\Omega)) = {\rm non}(S_1(T^*,O)) = \germ{od}$.
   (ix) Using the method of forcing, it is shown that neither the equality $\germ{lr} = \germ{d}$ nor the equality $\germ{lx} = \germ{d}$ is a theorem of ZFC.
   The paper finishes with a number of open problems. For instance, is it consistent that $\germ{lr}$ is singular?
Reviewed by Samuel Gomes da Silva

    References
  1. J. Baumgartner and P. Dordal, Adjoining dominating functions, J. Symbolic Logic 50 (1985), 94–101. MR0780528
  2. A. Blass, Combinatorial cardinal characteristics of the continuum, in: Handbook of Set Theory, M. Foreman and A. Kanamori (eds.), Springer, 2010, 395–489. MR2768685
  3. T. Jech, Set Theory, The Third Millennium Edition, Revised and Expanded, Springer, 2003. MR1940513

  5. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Cofinality spectrum theorems in model theory, set theory and general topology, J. Amer. Math. Soc. 29 (2016), 237–297. MR3402699
  6. H. Mildenberger, S. Shelah, and B. Tsaban, The combinatorics of $\tau$-covers, Topology Appl. 154 (2007), 263–276. MR2271787

MR3509813 Reviewed
Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Open and solved problems concerning polarized partition relations. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 234 (2016), no. 1, 1–14.
03E02 (03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-08-29 Review Published2017-02-10

The paper under review deals with the strong polarized partition relation $$ \binom\lambda\kappa\rightarrow \binom\lambda\kappa^{1,1}_2, $$ where $\lambda,\kappa$ are cardinals, and which abbreviates the statement "For every $c\colon \lambda\times{\kappa}\to 2$ there are $A\subseteq{\lambda}$ and $B\subseteq{\kappa}$ such that $|A|=\lambda$, $|B|=\kappa$ and $c\restriction{A\times{B}}$ is constant.''
   The authors list a number of open problems about this partition relation and solve two of these problems by showing that for every limit ordinal $\alpha$ which is not inaccessible there exists a forcing notion $\Bbb{P}$ such that $$ \binom{\aleph_{\alpha+1}}{\aleph_{\alpha}} \rightarrow \binom{\aleph_{\alpha+1}}{\aleph_{\alpha}}^{1,1}_2 $$ holds in ${\bf V}^{\Bbb{P}}$.
   The paper is divided into five sections. The first is an introduction, where some background on the relation $$ \binom{\lambda^{+}}{\lambda}\rightarrow \binom{\lambda^{+}}{\lambda}^{1,1}_2 $$ for a large $\lambda$ is given and the main combinatorial ideas involved in the consistency proof stated above are described. These make use of some assumptions involving pcf theory.
   The second section reviews some previously known results.
   In the third section, many open problems about the partition relation $$ \binom\lambda\omega\rightarrow \binom\lambda\omega^{1,1}_2 $$ are stated. In most of the cases, $\lambda$ is a cardinal invariant of the continuum.
   The fourth section is devoted to stating many open problems about the partition relations $$ \binom{2^{\lambda}}{\lambda}\rightarrow \binom{2^{\lambda}}{\lambda}^{1,1}_2\quad\text{ and }\quad\binom{\lambda^{+}}{\lambda}\rightarrow \binom{\lambda^{+}}{\lambda}^{1,1}_2 $$ when $\lambda$ is a large cardinal or a sufficiently large strong limit singular cardinal, perhaps assuming the existence of large cardinals below $\lambda$.
   In the fifth and final section of the paper, a proof of the polarized partition property $$ \binom\lambda\mu\rightarrow \binom\lambda\mu^{1,1}_2 $$ from several assumptions is presented. As a corollary, the consistency of the polarized partition relations $$ \binom{\mu^{+}}{\mu}\rightarrow \binom{\mu^{+}}{\mu}^{1,1}_2\quad\text{ and }\quad \binom{2^{\mu}}{\mu}\rightarrow \binom{2^{\mu}}{\mu}^{1,1}_2 $$ is established by forcing, assuming that $\mu$ is a supercompact cardinal in the ground model.
Reviewed by Andrés Millán

    References
  1. J. E. Baumgartner and R. Laver, Iterated perfect-set forcing, Ann. Math. Logic 17 (1979), 271–288. MR0556894
  2. A. Blass, Combinatorial cardinal charactersitics of the continuum, in: M. Foreman and A. Kanamori (eds.), Handbook of Set Theory, Springer, Dordrecht, 2010, Vol. 1, 395–489. MR2768685
  3. A. Blass and S. Shelah, There may be simple $P_{\aleph_1}$ and $P_{\aleph_2}$ points and the Rudin–Keisler ordering may be downward directed, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 33 (1987), 213–243. MR0879489
  4. A. Blass and S. Shelah, Ultrafilters with small generating sets, Israel J. Math. 65 (1989), 259–271. MR1005010

MR3509699 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Cohen, Moran(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Stable theories and representation over sets. (English summary)
MLQ Math. Log. Q. 62 (2016), no. 3, 140–154.
03C45
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-09-10 Review Published2017-01-17

In this paper the authors consider the notion of representability of one class of structures in another. Specifically, given two classes of structures $\Cal{I}$ and $\Cal{J}$, we say that $\Cal{I}$ is represented in $\Cal{J}$ if for any $I \in \Cal{I}$ there is $J \in \Cal{J}$ and a function $f\: |I| \to |J|$ so that two tuples from $I$ of the same length $\overline{a}$ and $\overline{b}$ have the same type in $I$ if and only if $f(\overline{a})$ and $f(\overline{b})$ have the same quantifier free type in $J$. Thus in some sense structures in $\Cal{I}$ are "represented'' in structures from $\Cal{J}$.
   The main results in this paper deal with the classes of models of stable and $\omega$-stable theories. To this end let ${\rm Ex}^0_{\mu, \kappa}$ for cardinals $\mu$ and $\kappa$ be the class of structures in a vocabulary consisting of $\mu$ unary predicate symbols and $\kappa$ unary function symbols. Let ${\rm Ex}^{0,{\rm lf}}_{\mu, \kappa}$ be those structures $I$ in ${\rm Ex}^0_{\mu, \kappa}$ so that for any element $a \in |I|$ the closure of $a$ under all function symbols is finite ("lf'' stands for "locally finite''). Given these definitions, two of the authors' results are:
   Theorem 1. Let $T$ be a complete first-order theory.
(1)
$T$ is stable if and only if ${\rm EC}(T)$ (the class of all models of $T$) is representable in ${\rm Ex}^0_{0, |T|}$.
(2)
$T$ is $\omega$-stable if and only if ${\rm EC}(T)$ is representable in ${\rm Ex}^{0,{\rm lf}}_{\aleph_0,2}$.

   The authors provide many more variants of the above results, all reinforcing the idea that stable or $\omega$-stable theories may be represented in reasonably uncomplicated classes of structures.
Reviewed by Alfred Dolich

    References
  1. T. Jech, Set theory (Academic Press, New York, 1978). MR0506523
  2. I. Kaplan and S. Shelah, Dependent examples, Examples in dependent theories, J. Symb. Log. 49, 585–619 (2014). MR3224981
  3. S. Shelah, Universal classes, in: Classification theory. Proceedings of the U.S.-Israel Binational Workshop on Model Theory in Mathematical Logic held in Chicago, Illinois, December 15–19, 1985. Edited by J. T. Baldwin. Lecture Notes in Mathematics Vol. 1292 (Springer-Verlag, 1987), pp. 264–418. MR1033033
  4. S. Shelah, Classification theory and the number of nonisomorphic models, Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics Vol. 92 (North-Holland, 1990). MR1083551
  5. S. Shelah, Introduction to: classification theory for abstract elementary class, preprint, 2009 (arXiv: math.LO/0903.3428). cf. MR2643267
  6. S. Shelah, Strongly dependent theories, Isr. J. Math. 204, 1–83 (2014). MR3273451
  7. S. Shelah, Superstable theories and representation, preprint, 2014 (arXiv:math.LO/1412.0421).
  8. S. Shelah, On spectrum of $\kappa$-resplendent models, preprint, 2015 (available on the author's website as Sh:363).
  9. S. Shelah, General non-structure theory, preprint, 2016 (arXiv: math.LO/1011.3576).
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3453586 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

$\rm ZF+DC+AX_4$. (English summary)
Arch. Math. Logic 55 (2016), no. 1-2, 239–294.
03E04 (03E25 03E75 20K20 20K30)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-04-21 Review Published2016-05-26

${\rm AX}_4$ is the axiom: For every ordinal $\lambda$ the set $\lambda^\omega$ can be well ordered. DC is the axiom of dependent choices.
   The thesis of this paper is that the addition of ${\rm AX}_4+{\rm DC}$ to the standard system ${\rm ZF}$ results in a reasonable set theory. Although much weaker than the theory resulting from adopting the full axiom of choice, it is still possible to do much of combinatorial set theory in this restricted setting. As the author states, "${\rm ZF}+{\rm DC}+{\rm Ax}_4$ is a reasonable set theory, for which much of combinatorial set theory can be generalized, but many times in a challenging way and even discover new phenomena.'' For example, existence results are strengthened by the necessity of producing nicely definable sets.
   A version of the PCF Theorem is obtained for sequences of the form $(\delta_s\:s\in Y)$ with ${\rm cf}(\delta_s)$ large enough compared to $Y$. Even though in this setting $\lambda^\kappa$ may not be well orderable, relevant covering numbers exist, e.g., ${\rm cov}(\lambda,\theta_3(\kappa),\kappa,\sigma)$. Using this, it is shown that many successors of singular cardinals are regular. In particular, if $\mu$ is singular, and for every $\alpha<\mu$, $\alpha^\omega<\mu$, then $\mu^+$ is a regular cardinal. The author gives some diagonalization arguments constructing Abelian groups, which might be thought to require the full axiom of choice. This is done using the combinatorial properties called Black Boxes.
Reviewed by Arnold W. Miller

    References
  1. Eklof, P.C., Mekler, A.: Almost Free Modules: Set Theoretic Methods, North–Holland Mathematical Library, vol. 65, Revised edn. North–Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam (2002) MR1914985

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 1

MR3451934 Reviewed
Malliaris, M.(1-CHI)
Department of Mathematics, University of Chicago
Chicago, Illinois, 60637
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Existence of optimal ultrafilters and the fundamental complexity of simple theories. (English summary)
Adv. Math. 290 (2016), 614–681.
03C45 (03C20 03E05 03G05 06E10)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-04-20 Review Published2016-08-24

The paper under review is part of the authors' broad interdisciplinary program inspired by the study of Keisler's order. The program involves model theory (e.g., classifying theories) and set theory (e.g., constructing ultrafilters), and has found surprising and unexpected applications in topology and in the theory of cardinal invariants of the continuum, providing a proof that $\germ p = \germ t$, solving an important longstanding problem. See the authors' [J. Amer. Math. Soc. 29 (2016), no. 1, 237–297; MR3402699], and see [M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 110 (2013), no. 33, 13300–13305; MR3105597] for a detailed introduction to the program.
   Keisler's (pre-)order $\trianglelefteq$ from [H. J. Keisler, J. Symbolic Logic 32 (1967), 23–46; MR0218224] compares the complexity of first-order theories by measuring how hard it is to have saturated regular ultrapowers of models of the theory (a regular ultrapower is an ultrapower by a regular ultrafilter). Specifically, given two countable complete first-order theories $T_1$ and $T_2$, define $T_1\trianglelefteq T_2$ precisely when for every infinite cardinal $\lambda$ and regular ultrafilter $\Cal{D}$ on $\lambda$, if $M_1\models T_1$, $M_2\models T_2$, and $M_2^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated, then also $M_1^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated.
   Before the recent advances, little was known about Keisler's order, apart from that it has both a maximal and a minimal equivalence class, the latter class being one of the two classes which divide stable theories. In spite of the deep mysteries that were surrounding the order at the time (and many mysteries remain!), the authors mention in their abstract a key result of Shelah from [Classification theory and the number of nonisomorphic models, Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, 92, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1978; MR0513226], characterizing stable theories in terms of saturation of ultrapowers. They add that "[a] contribution of the ultrapower characterization [of stable theories] was that it involved sorting out the global theory, and introducing nonforking, seminal for the development of stability theory''. The delicate issues arising from Keisler's order were well expressed in [M. Malliaris, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 157 (2009), no. 2-3, 220–224; MR2499710]: "The Keisler order exposes certain basic, though often surprising, tensions between finite combinatorial problems posed by fragments of a theory in each index model and infinitary combinatorial problems posed by the aggregate in the ultrapower.''
   The paper under review presents an ultrapower characterization of simple theories, under the set-theoretic assumption of the existence of a supercompact cardinal $\sigma$. Simple theories, a generalization of stable theories, have been shown over the years to be more and more tractable, and the paper under review is a further step in this direction.
   A parameter-free instance of one of the main results is that if $\sigma$ is a supercompact cardinal, then there exists a regular ultrafilter $\Cal D$ on $\sigma^+$ such that, for every model $M$ in a countable signature, the ultrapower $M^{ \sigma ^+}/ \Cal D$ is $\sigma ^{++} $-saturated if and only if $Th(M)$ is simple. A notable consequence, in a formulation the authors credit to the referee, is the following: Assume that there exists a supercompact cardinal. If $T$, $T'$ are countable theories, $T$ is simple, and $T'$ is less than or equal to $T$ in Keisler's order, then $T'$ is simple.
   However, an important ingredient in the paper is given by some parametrized notions and results depending on suitable 4-tuples $( \lambda , \mu , \theta , \sigma )$ of infinite cardinals, where "suitable'' means that the 4-tuple satisfies some natural cardinal inequalities (it should be pointed out that some notions and statements could be naturally stated as depending on an additional parameter; see p. 656). The authors then go on by defining the notion of a $( \lambda , \mu , \theta , \sigma )$-explicitly simple theory and prove, among other things, that a complete theory is simple if and only if it is $( \lambda , \mu , \theta , \sigma )$-explicitly simple, for some suitable 4-tuple. This is interesting, since the "explicit-simplicity spectrum'' might vary from theory to theory; thus it gives the possibility of establishing new dividing lines between simple unstable theories. The authors announce some results in this direction, in particular that Keisler's order has infinitely many classes, contrary to some previous conjectures.
   On the parallel set-theoretic side, the notion of a $( \lambda , \mu , \theta , \sigma )$-optimized ultrafilter is introduced, and it is shown that ultrapowers of models of $( \lambda , \mu , \theta , \sigma )$-explicitly simple theories by such an ultrafilter on $\lambda$ are $\lambda^+$-saturated. The construction of an optimized ultrafilter proceeds in two steps, first constructing an "optimal'' ultrafilter over an appropriate Boolean algebra $\germ B$, using a supercompact cardinal, and then extending an "excellent'' filter on a set $I$ through a Boolean homomorphism $j \colon \Cal P(I) \to \germ B$. The construction is versatile, since each step controls particular aspects of the resulting optimized ultrafilter. This procedure gives a way of constructing regular ultrafilters starting from highly irregular ones, the $\sigma$-complete ultrafilters provided by the supercompactness of $\sigma$.
   The paper contains many more results and ideas which cannot be summarized here for lack of space. A large part of the material is technical, but the reader is assisted by a good deal of clear and elucidating comments and remarks disseminated through the text. The paper also contains various non-technical and introductory sections. Among them, the first subsection on backgrounds contains a concise but effective history of ultrafilters; it is valuable to anyone, possibly outside the field, who is looking for a quick guide to model-theoretic applications of ultrafilters. A special subsection dedicated to set theorists explains what they should and should not read in case they are unwilling to embark on the model-theoretic tour. The reasons for the use of a supercompact cardinal are discussed in Subsection 2.2.
   This paper is a must-read for every model-theorist interested in unstable theories, as well as for every mathematician interested in applications of ultrafilters.
Reviewed by Paolo Lipparini

    References

MR3427592 Reviewed
Farah, Ilijas(3-YORK-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, York University
Toronto, Ontario, M3J 1P3, Canada
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University

Rigidity of continuous quotients. (English summary)
J. Inst. Math. Jussieu 15 (2016), no. 1, 1–28.
03C65 (03E35 03E50 03E57 46L05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-03-14 Review Published2016-11-17

The authors give an independence result about the existence of non-trivial autohomeomorphisms of the remainder of the interval $[0,1)$ with respect to its Stone-Čech compactification (denoted by $[0,1)^*$). Recall that a continuous map $F\:X^*\to Y^*$ is said to be trivial if there are a compact set $K\subseteq X$ and a continuous map $f \: X\sbs K\to Y$ such that $F=\beta f| X^*$, where $\beta f\: \beta X\to\beta Y$ is the (unique) continuous extension of $f$.
   They find that assuming the continuum hypothesis (CH), $[0,1)^*$ does have $2^{\aleph_1}$ non-trivial autohomeomorphisms; this is obtained as a consequence of the fact that, under CH, $C([0,1)^*)$ is countably saturated. In turn, this is a consequence of a general result, obtained using techniques of model theory of metric structures, on the saturation properties of reduced products. On the contrary, assuming the Proper Forcing Axiom (PFA), every autohomeomorphism of $[0,1)^*$ is trivial.
   The paper is interesting and goes in the same direction as previous papers from the authors, applying forcing constructions to open questions about operator algebras and analysis.
Reviewed by Camilo Enrique Argoty

MR3418888 Reviewed
Bagaria, Joan(E-ICREA)
Institució Catalana de Recerca i Estudis Avancats (ICREA)
08010 Barcelona, Spain
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

On partial orderings having precalibre-$\aleph_1$ and fragments of Martin's axiom. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 232 (2016), no. 2, 181–197.
03E40 (03E35 03E50 03E57)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2016-02-02 Review Published2016-04-26

L. A. Harrington and S. Shelah [Notre Dame J. Formal Logic 26 (1985), no. 2, 178–188; MR0783595] showed that if $\aleph_1^{L[x]}=\aleph_1$ for a real number $x$, then Martin's axiom MA implies that there exists a $\Delta^1_3(x)$ set of reals that does not have the Baire property. In [J. Bagaria, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 69 (1994), no. 1, 1–25; MR1301604] it was shown that if ${\rm MA}(\sigma\text{-centered})$ holds, every Aronszajn tree is special, and $\aleph_1^{L[x]}=\aleph_1$ for a real number $x$, then there exists a $\Delta^1_3(x)$ set of reals that does not have the Baire property. Therefore it was natural to ask how weak is ${\rm MA}(\sigma\text{-centered}){}+{}$"every Aronszajn tree is special'' as compared to full MA and, in particular, if it implies ${\rm MA}(\sigma\text{-linked})$. The answer to this question is negative by a result of D. Chodounský and J. Zapletal [Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 166 (2015), no. 11, 1123–1149; MR3385104].
   In the paper under review the authors give another and stronger negative answer. They introduce classes $\roman{Pr}_k$ of ccc forcing notions for $k\ge2$, and show that, for each $k$, ${\rm Pr}_k$ contains all forcing notions with the $k$-Knaster property (that is, all those posets with the property that any uncountable set contains an uncountable subset such that any $k$ of its elements have a common extension), and thus contains all forcing notions that are $\sigma$-$k$-linked or have precaliber $\aleph_1$ (recall that $\Bbb P$ has precaliber $\aleph_1$ if every uncountable subset of $\Bbb P$ has an uncountable subset such that any finite set of its elements has a common lower bound, and that $\Bbb P$ is $\sigma$-$k$-linked if we can write $\Bbb P$ as a countable union of sets, each of which consists of pairwise compatible elements).
   The standard forcing notions that specialize Aronszajn trees are in Pr$_k$ and the property of being in ${\rm Pr}_k$ is preserved by finite-support iterations. The authors prove that ${\rm MA}(\roman{Pr}_{k+1})$ plus "every Aronszajn tree is special'' does not imply ${\rm MA}(\sigma\text{-$k$-linked})$. They also prove that it is consistent relative to ZFC that CH holds and there exists a forcing notion $T$ of cardinality $\aleph_1$ that preserves cardinals and two partial orderings $\Bbb{P}_0$ and $\Bbb{P}_1$ having precaliber $\aleph_1$ such that $\Vdash_T$ "$\Bbb{P}_0$, $\Bbb{P}_1$ are ccc but $\Bbb{P}_0\times\Bbb{P}_1$ is not ccc''. Hence $\Vdash_T$ "$\Bbb{P}_0$ and $\Bbb{P}_1$ do not have precaliber $\aleph_1$''. This answers a question of J. Steprāns and W. S. Watson [Fund. Math. 129 (1988), no. 3, 223–229; MR0962545].
Reviewed by Miroslav Repický

    References

Citations

From References: 13

From Reviews: 2

MR3402699 Reviewed
Malliaris, M.(1-CHI)
Department of Mathematics, University of Chicago
Chicago, Illinois, 60637
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-E)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics and Computer Science, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Cofinality spectrum theorems in model theory, set theory, and general topology.
J. Amer. Math. Soc. 29 (2016), no. 1, 237–297.
03C20 (03C45 03E05 03E17)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2016 Indexed 2015-12-07 Review Published2016-07-11

This paper addresses two problems: one from model theory, concerning Keisler's order of theories [H. J. Keisler, J. Symbolic Logic 32 (1967), 23–46; MR0218224], and the other from set-theoretic topology.
   The first problem describes a class of theories that are maximal in Keisler's order; paraphrasing slightly, if there is a formula that has a set of instances (in suitable models) indexed by the binary tree such that branches are consistent but antichains are inconsistent then the theory is maximal in Keisler's order.
   Regarding the second problem, the authors show that ${\frak{p}=\frak{t}}$ [see E. K. van Douwen, in Handbook of set-theoretic topology, 111–167, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1984; MR0776622].
   The common framework is that of theories, and models thereof, that have enough expressibility to allow the development of rudimentary set theory for trees and linear orders. Under certain assumptions one can prove the non-existence of unfilled gaps of small character; this leads both to the maximality result and the equality $\frak{p}=\frak{t}$. For those interested in the latter result it may be most convenient to start with Definition 14.3 and simply use all of set theory as the underlying theory in the rest of the section. Likewise specialise the main non-existence result, Theorem 8.1, to that case. The final contradiction, from the assumption $\frak{p}<\frak{t}$, is reached via the second author's special cut in $\omega^\omega$ from [Canad. Math. Bull. 52 (2009), no. 2, 303–314; MR2518968].
Reviewed by Klaas Pieter Hart

    References

  13. F. Hausdorff, Summen von $\aleph_1$ Mengen, Fund. Math. 26 (1936), 241–255.
  14. H. Jerome Keisler, Good ideals in fields of sets, Ann. of Math. (2) 79 (1964), 338–359. MR 0166105 (29 #3383) MR0166105
  15. H. Jerome Keisler, Ultraproducts and saturated models, Nederl. Akad. Wetensch. Proc. Ser. A 67 = Indag. Math. 26 (1964), 178–186. MR 0168483 (29 #5745) MR0168483

  17. Simon Kochen, Ultraproducts in the theory of models, Ann. of Math. (2) 74 (1961), 221–261. MR 0138548 (25 #1992) MR0138548
  18. Sabine Koppelberg, Cardinalities of ultraproducts of finite sets, J. Symbolic Logic 45 (1980), no. 3, 574–584, DOI 10.2307/2273424. MR 583375 (81i:04006) MR0583375
  19. Linus Kramer, Saharon Shelah, Katrin Tent, and Simon Thomas, Asymptotic cones of finitely presented groups, Adv. Math. 193 (2005), no. 1, 142–173, DOI 10.1016/j.aim.2004.04.012. MR 2132762 (2006d:20075) MR2132762
  20. Kenneth Kunen, Ultrafilters and independent sets, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 172 (1972), 299–306. MR 0314619 (47 #3170) MR0314619
  21. Jerzy Łoś, Quelques remarques, théorèmes et problèmes sur les classes définissables d'algèbres (French), Mathematical interpretation of formal systems, North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1955, pp. 98–113. MR 0075156 (17, 700d) MR0075156
  22. M. Malliaris, Persistence and regularity in unstable model theory, Ph. D. thesis, University of California, Berkeley, 2009. MR2713926
  23. M. E. Malliaris, Realization of $\phi$ -types and Keisler's order, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 157 (2009), no. 2-3, 220–224, DOI 10.1016/j.apal.2008.09.008. MR 2499710 (2010b:03044) MR2499710
  24. M. E. Malliaris, Hypergraph sequences as a tool for saturation of ultrapowers, J. Symbolic Logic 77 (2012), no. 1, 195–223, DOI 10.2178/jsl/1327068699. MR2951637 MR2951637
  25. M. E. Malliaris, Independence, order, and the interaction of ultrafilters and theories, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 163 (2012), no. 11, 1580–1595, DOI 10.1016/j.apal.2011.12.010. MR2959661 MR2959661
  26. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Constructing regular ultrafilters from a model-theoretic point of view, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. (2015). MR3391912
  27. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Model-theoretic properties of ultrafilters built by independent families of functions, J. Symbolic Logic 79 (2014), no. 1, 103–134, DOI 10.1017/jsl.2013.28. MR3226014 MR3226014
  28. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, A dividing line within simple unstable theories, Adv. Math. 249 (2013), 250–288, DOI 10.1016/j.aim.2013.08.027. MR3116572 MR3116572
  29. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Saturating the random graph with an independent family of small range, Logic Without Borders (A. Hirvonen, J. Kontinen, R. Kossak, and A. Villaveces, eds.), DeGruyter, 2015, pp. 422.
  30. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, An axiomatic approach to cofinality spectrum problems. Manuscript F1245.
  31. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Existence of optimal ultrafilters and the fundamental complexity of simple theories. arXiv:1404.2919. cf. MR3451934
  32. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Keisler's order has infinitely many classes. arXiv:1503.08341.
  33. M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Model-theoretic applications of cofinality spectrum problems. Manuscript 1051, arXiv:math.LO/1503.08338. cf. MR3563070
  34. Zbigniew Piotrowski and Andrzej Szymański, Some remarks on category in topological spaces, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 101 (1987), no. 1, 156–160, DOI 10.2307/2046568. MR 897088 (88g:54007) MR0897088
  35. A. J. Wilkie and J. B. Paris, On the scheme of induction for bounded arithmetic formulas, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 35 (1987), no. 3, 261–302, DOI 10.1016/0168-0072 (87) 90066-2. MR 904326 (89g:03087) MR0904326
  36. F. Rothberger and J. B. Paris, Une remarque concerenant l'hypothèse du continu, Fund. Math. 31 (1939), no. 3, 224–226.
  37. Fritz Rothberger, On some problems of Hausdorff and of Sierpiński, Fund. Math. 35 (1948), 29–46. MR 0029958 (10, 689a) MR0029958

  42. Saharon Shelah, Toward classifying unstable theories, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 80 (1996), no. 3, 229–255, DOI 10.1016/0168-0072 (95) 00066-6. MR 1402297 (97e:03052) MR1402297
  43. Saharon Shelah, Two cardinal invariants of the continuum $(\frak{d} < \frak{a})$ and FS linearly ordered iterated forcing, Acta Math. 192 (2004), no. 2, 187–223, DOI 10.1007/BF02392740. MR 2096454 (2005f:03074) MR2096454
  44. Saharon Shelah, A comment on "$\frak{p} < \frak{t}$", Canad. Math. Bull. 52 (2009), no. 2, 303–314, DOI 10.4153/CMB-2009-033-4. MR 2518968 (2010h:03078) MR2518968

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3485653 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

On failure of 0-1 laws. (English summary) Fields of logic and computation. II, 293–296,
Lecture Notes in Comput. Sci., 9300, Springer, Cham, 2015.
03C13 (03C75 05C80)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2016-06-02 Review Published2017-01-12

The subject matter of the paper under review stems from the logical foundations of random graph theory. The inspiration for building and developing random graph theory was the needs of mathematical research in very large networks such as power grids or social networks (collaboration networks such as the Erdős number graph are examples here). Now random graph theory can be used to analyse some aspects of large networks such as those associated with various areas of information technology, for example the World Wide Web. Random graphs allow people to build mathematical models of portions of networks that are too large to be precisely studied as a whole.
   The prehistory of the area of random graphs can be traced to Problem 38, due to S. M. Ulam, in the famous Scottish book, see in particular the comments on that problem by R. L. Graham and D. S. Jungreis in [The Scottish Book, Birkhäuser/Springer, Cham, 2015; MR3242261]. It is generally accepted that the following papers founded random graph theory: [E. N. Gilbert, Ann. Math. Statist. 30 (1959), 1141–1144; MR0108839; P. Erdős and A. Rényi, Publ. Math. Debrecen 6 (1959), 290–297; MR0120167; Magyar Tud. Akad. Mat. Kutató Int. Közl. 5 (1960), 17–61; MR0125031]. The following are several examples of the numerous papers and books devoted to random graphs from a network-theoretic point of view: [E. N. Gilbert, J. Soc. Indust. Appl. Math. 9 (1961), 533–543; MR0132566; M. E. J. Newman, in Handbook of graphs and networks, 35–68, Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2003; MR2016118; Handbook of large-scale random networks, Bolyai Soc. Math. Stud., 18, Springer, Berlin, 2009; MR2582385; R. van der Hofstad, Random graphs and complex networks, Camb. Ser. Stat. Probab. Math., 43, Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, to appear]. One can also observe that random graph theory has connections with aspects of percolation theory [R. van der Hofstad, in New perspectives in stochastic geometry, 173–247, Oxford Univ. Press, Oxford, 2010; MR2654679].
   For each positive integer $n$ let $V_n$ be an $n$-element set and let $\Cal{G}_{(n,{p_n})} = (K_n,p_n)$ be a pair such that
1.
$K_n$ is the set of all simple (unordered) graphs $\germ{G} = (V_n; R^{\germ{G}})$ with set of vertices $V_n$.
2.
$p_n\:K_n\to[0,1]$ is a probability distribution, $\sum \{p_n(\germ{G}) \mid \germ{G} \in G_n\} = 1$.
The elements of $K_n$ are called random graphs or, more precisely, $(n,{p_n})$-random graphs.
   Consider such a sequence $(\Cal{G}_{(n,p_n)})_{n\in\Bbb N}$. Let $\psi$ be a sentence over a logic $\Bbb{L}$. We say that for every random enough $G_n$ we have $G_n\models \psi$ (i.e., the random graph $G_n\in \Cal{G}_{(n,p_n)}$ is a model of $\psi$) if and only if $$ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty}\roman{Pr}(G_n \models \psi) = 1, $$ where $$ \roman{Pr}(G_n\models \psi) = \sum \{p_n(\germ{G}) \mid \germ{G} \in K_n \land \germ{G} \models \psi \}. $$
   A random graph ($(n,{p_n})$-random graph) or more precisely $(\Cal{G}_{(n,{p_n})})_{n \in \Bbb{N}}$ satisfies the 0-1 law for the logic $\Bbb{L}$ if and only if for every statement $\psi$ in the language of graphs expressible in $\Bbb{L}$, $$ \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty}\text{Pr}(G_n \models \psi) \in \{0,1\}. $$ It is known that for first-order logic the 0-1 law is satisfied when each edge in the random graph is selected with constant probability $p\in[0,1]$ and different edges are drawn independently. The 0-1 law still holds under more general assumptions, as has been proved in numerous papers, some of them cited in the paper under review. For an introduction, see for example [J. H. Spencer, The strange logic of random graphs, Algorithms Combin., 22, Springer, Berlin, 2001; MR1847951; H.-D. Ebbinghaus and J. Flum, Finite model theory, second revised and enlarged edition, Springer Monogr. Math., Springer, Berlin, 2006; MR2177676].
   As the author recalls, the proof of the constant case [Y. V. Glebski\u{ı} et al., Kibernetika (Kiev) 1969, no. 2, 17–27; MR0300882; R. Fagin, J. Symbolic Logic 41 (1976), no. 1, 50–58; MR0476480] adapts to show the 0-1 law is satisfied (again, in the constant case) in inductive logic and in the infinitary logic $L_{\infty,\omega}^\omega$. The 0-1 law is also satisfied in first-order logic when the probability of each edge in the random graph $G_n$ is not constant but is given instead by $1/n^\alpha$ for $\alpha$ irrational (for proofs of these statements, see the books cited in the previous paragraph). In contrast to the constant case, the main part of this short paper is devoted to slightly informal considerations on the 0-1 law not holding true under this distribution for these two stronger logics. The argument, as suggested in the paper, proceeds "by proving that for some so called scheme $\bar\varphi$ of interpretation, for any random enough $G_n$, $\bar\varphi$ interpret an initial segment of number theory, say up to $m(G_n)$ where $m(G_n)$ is not too small; e.g. at least $\log_2(\log_2(n))$''.

{For the collection containing this paper see MR3485656.} Reviewed by Jan Gałuszka

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3485648 Reviewed
Haber, Simi(IL-BILN-NDM)
Bar-Ilan University
Ramat Gan 52900, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-NDM)
Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

An extension of the Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game for first order logics augmented with Lindström quantifiers. (English summary) Fields of logic and computation. II, 226–236,
Lecture Notes in Comput. Sci., 9300, Springer, Cham, 2015.
03C85 (03C55)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2016-06-02 Review Published2016-08-18

The Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé game in first-order logic is a two-player game designed to capture the first-order elementary equivalence of two models: two models are elementarily equivalent in first-order logic if and only if the first player has a winning strategy in all Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé games of finite length. The game can be generalized to various extensions of first-order logic. In particular, the authors generalize it to the extension of first-order logic resulting from adding Lindström quantifiers of any type. The three games designed by the authors are, as claimed in the paper, more general and easier to use than previously designed games.

{For the collection containing this paper see MR3485656.} Reviewed by Renling Jin

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3433640 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Models of ${\rm PA}$: when two elements are necessarily order automorphic. (English summary)
MLQ Math. Log. Q. 61 (2015), no. 6, 399–417.
03C62 (03C64 03E65 03H15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2016-03-14 Review Published2016-06-06

To what extent is an uncountable model of arithmetic determined by its order-type? This is an old question for which we still do not have a satisfactory answer. The paper under review is one of the few contributions making progress on this question.
   Let $a,b$ be nonstandard elements in a model $M$ of $\roman{PA}$. It is a straightforward exercise to show that if the difference between $a$ and $b$ is finite, then there is an order-automorphism of $M$ mapping $a$ to $b$. With more effort, one can relax `finite' in the hypothesis while still guaranteeing the conclusion. In the paper, the author determines precisely how far this can go in general, under the set-theoretic assumption of $\diamondsuit_{\aleph_1}$.
   Following the notation in this paper, write $a\mathrel{E^3_M}b$ to mean there is $c\in M$ such that $c^n$ is below both $a$ and $b$ for all $n\in\Bbb{N}$, but $a<bc$ and $b<ac$. The author shows that if $a\mathrel{E^3_M}b$, then there is an order-automorphism of $M$ mapping $a$ to $b$. Moreover, using $\diamondsuit_{\aleph_1}$, he constructs models $M$ of $\roman{PA}$ in which the converse is true for all $a,b\in M$, thus establishing the optimality of $E^3_M$.
   Models witnessing the optimality of $E^3_M$ are called 3-order rigid in the paper. As proved by the author, the order-type of a model of this kind has some control over its additive structure: if $M$ is 3-order rigid and $N$ is another model of $\roman{PA}$ order-isomorphic to $M$, then $M$ and $N$ are almost $\{+,<\}$-isomorphic, in the sense that there is an order-isomorphism $f\colon M\to N$ such that the difference between $f(x)+f(y)$ and $f(x+y)$ is always finite.
   The paper ends with a discussion on the validity of its arguments when $\roman{PA}$ is replaced by various induction-free fragments.
Reviewed by Tin Lok Wong

    References
  1. R. Kossak and J. Schmerl, The structure of models of Peano arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides Vol. 50 (Oxford University Press, 2006). MR2250469
  2. R. Göbel and J. Trlifaj, Approximations and endomorphism algebras of modules, de Gruyter Expositions in Mathematics Vol. 41 (Walter de Gruyter, 2006). MR2251271
  3. S. Shelah, Compact logics in ZFC : Complete embeddings of atomless Boolean rings, preprint (to appear as Chapter X of the forthcoming book Nonstructure Theory).
  4. S. Shelah, Quite Complete Real Closed Fields, Isr. J. Math. 142, 261–272 (2004). MR2085719
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR3416920 Reviewed
Kuhlmann, Katarzyna(3-SK-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Saskatchewan
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, S7N 0W0, Canada
; Kuhlmann, Franz-Viktor(PL-SILS-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, University of Silesia
40-007 Katowice, Poland
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Symmetrically complete ordered sets abelian groups and fields. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 208 (2015), no. 1, 261–290.
06F20 (03E04 06A05 12J10 12J15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2016-01-25 Review Published2016-08-30

The object of this paper is to characterize those linearly ordered sets, linearly ordered abelian groups, and linearly ordered fields that are symmetrically complete (see (2)–(8) below). The authors show as well that such ordered abelian groups are divisible Hahn products and that such ordered fields are real closed power series fields (see (9) and (10) below) and as a consequence provide a way of constructing symmetrically complete abelian groups and fields.
   NB: In what follows, "ordered'' is shorthand for "linearly ordered''.
   A Dedekind cut $C=(C^-,C^+)$ in an ordered set $I$ is a pair of nonempty subsets $C^-$ and $C^+$ of $I$ such that $C^-\cup C^+=I$ and $d<e$ for all $d\in C^-$ and $e\in C^+$; $C$ is principal if either $C^-$ has a maximal element or $C^+$ has a minimal element; $(C^-,C^+)$ is symmetric if the cofinality, $\kappa\varphi(C^-)$, of $C^-$ and the coinitiality, $\kappa\iota(C^+)$, of $C^+$ are the same; $I$ is symmetrically complete if every symmetric cut is principal. The authors show that
(1)
$I$ is symmetrically complete if and only if every nonempty chain of nonempty, closed, bounded intervals in $I$ has a nonempty intersection.

   A Dedekind cut $C$ in $I$ is strongly asymmetric if $\kappa\varphi(C^-)\ne\kappa\iota(C^+)$ and at least one of $\kappa\varphi(C^-)$ and $\kappa\iota(C^+)$ is uncountable. The ordered set $I$ is strongly symmetrically complete if, for every cut $C$, either $C$ is strongly asymmetric or $\kappa\varphi(C^-)=1=\kappa\iota(C^+)$; $I$ is extremely symmetrically complete if it is strongly symmetrically complete and both the coinitiality and the cofinality of $I$ are uncountable.
   Two elements $a,b$ in an ordered abelian group $G$ are archimedean equivalent if ${n|a|\ge|b|}$ and $n|b|\ge|a|$ for some positive integer $n$; $va$ denotes the archimedean equivalence class of $a$; $G$ is archimedean if all nonzero elements are archimedean equivalent. Let $vG=\{vg\ |\ 0\ne g\in G\}$, and define a linear order on $vG$ by letting $va>vb$ if $|a|<|b|$ and $a$ and $b$ are not archimedean equivalent; an archimedean component of $G$ is then one of the archimedean ordered abelian groups $\Cal{C}_\gamma=\Cal{O}_\gamma/\Cal{M}_\gamma$, where $\gamma\in vG$, $\Cal{O}_\gamma={\{g\in G\ |\ vg\ge\gamma\}}$ and $\Cal{M}_\gamma=\{g\in G\ |\ vg>g\}$. The function $u(a,b)=v(a-b)$ is an ultrametric on $G$; the ultrametric ball determined by $a$ and $b$ is then the set $B_u(a,b)={\{g\ |\ v(a-g)\ge v(a-b)\}}$; $G$ is spherically complete if every nonempty chain of ultrametric balls has nonempty intersection.
   Let $G$ be a nontrivial densely ordered abelian group. The authors prove that
(2)
$G$ is symmetrically complete if and only if $G$ is spherically complete, $vG$ is dense and strongly symmetrically complete, and all the archimedean components of $G$ are isomorphic to $\Bbb R$,
(3)
$G$ is strongly symmetrically complete if and only if $G$ is symmetrically complete and $vG$ has uncountable cofinality, and
(4)
$G$ is extremely symmetrically complete if and only if $G$ is strongly symmetrically complete and $vG$ is extremely symmetrically complete.

   A $\Bbb Z$-group is an ordered abelian group $G$ that contains a convex subgroup $Z$ such that $Z$ is isomorphic to $\Bbb Z$ and $G/Z$ is divisible.
   Let $G$ be a nontrivial discretely ordered abelian group. The authors prove that
   (5) the following are equivalent:
(5.1)
$G$ is symmetrically complete,
(5.2)
$G$ is strongly symmetrically complete, and
(5.3)
$G$ is a $\Bbb Z$-group such that $G/Z$ is strongly symmetrically complete.
They also prove that
(6)
$G$ is extremely symmetrically complete if and only if $G$ is a $\Bbb Z$-group and $G/Z$ is extremely symmetrically complete.

   For an ordered field $K$, defining $va+vb=v(ab)$ makes $v$ a valuation into the ordered abelian group $vK$; the resulting residue field, $Kv$, is ordered and archimedean, and hence can be considered as a subfield of $\Bbb R$.
   Let $K$ be an ordered field. The authors prove that
(7)
$K$ is symmetrically complete if and only if $K$ is spherically complete, $Kv$ is all of $\Bbb R$, and $vK$ is dense and strongly symmetrically complete.
They also prove that
   (8) the following are equivalent:
(8.1)
$K$ is strongly symmetrically complete,
(8.2)
$K$ is extremely symmetrically complete, and
(8.3)
$K$ is spherically complete, $Kv$ is all of $\Bbb R$, and $vK$ is dense and extremely symmetrically complete.

   Let $T$ be an ordered set, and for each $\tau\in T$, let $C_\tau$ be an ordered group. The Hahn product of the $C_\tau$ is the subset, ${\bf H}_{\tau\in T}C_\tau$, of the product $\prod_{\tau\in T}C_\tau$ consisting of all $f$ whose support, $\{\tau\in T\ |\ f_\tau\ne0\}$, is well ordered. Addition is performed coordinatewise; the order is lexicographic: $f>0$ if and only if $f_\mu>0$, where $\mu$ is the minimal element of the support of $f$. If $T$ is an ordered abelian group and $K$ is an ordered field, then ${\bf H}_{\tau\in T}K$ is an ordered field with respect to the multiplication that treats the elements as polynomials: $(fg)_\tau=\sum_{\alpha+\beta=\tau}f_\alpha g_\beta$; ${\bf H}_{\tau\in T}K$ is called the power series field of $K$ over $T$.
   The authors use the preceding results to prove that
(9)
every dense, symmetrically complete, ordered abelian group is both divisible and isomorphic to a Hahn product, and
(10)
every symmetrically complete ordered field is real closed and isomorphic to a power series field that has residue field $\Bbb R$ and divisible value group.
They also prove that
(11)
every ordered set can be extended to an extremely symmetrically complete ordered set,
(12)
every ordered abelian group can be extended to an extremely symmetrically complete ordered abelian group, and
(13)
every ordered field can be extended to an extremely symmetrically complete ordered field.
Reviewed by R. H. Redfield

    References
  1. F. Hausdorff, Grundzüge einer Theorie der geordneten Mengen, Mathematische Annalen 65 (1908), 435–505. MR1511478
  2. I. Kaplansky, Maximal fields with valuations. I, Duke Mathematical Journal 9 (1942), 303–321. MR0006161
  3. F.-V. Kuhlmann, Maps on ultrametric spaces, Hensel's Lemma, and differential equations over valued fields, Communications in Algebra 39 (2011), 1730–1776. MR2821504
  4. F.-V. Kuhlmann, Valuation Theory, book in preparation, preliminary versions of several chapters available at http://math.usask.ca/~fvk/Fvkbook.htm.
  5. F.-V. Kuhlmann and K. Kuhlmann, A common generalization of metric, ultrametric and topological fixed point theorems, Forum Mathematicum, to appear. cf. MR3334063
  6. F.-V. Kuhlmann and K. Kuhlmann, A basic framework for fixed point theorems: ball spaces and spherical completeness, in preparation.
  7. F.-V. Kuhlmann, S. Kuhlmann and S. Shelah, Functorial equations for lexicographic products, Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society 131 (2003), 2969–2976. MR1993201
  8. S. Kuhlmann, On the structure of nonarchimedean exponential fields. I, Archive for Mathematical Logic 34 (1995), 145–182. MR1337111
  9. R. Levy, P. Loustaunau and J. Shapiro, The prime spectrum of an infinite product of copies of $\Bbb{Z}$, Fundamenta Mathematica 138 (1991), 155–164. MR1121602
  10. A. Prestel, Lectures on Formally Real Fields, Lecture Notes in Mathematics, Vol. 1093, Springer, Berlin–Heidelberg–New York–Tokyo, 1984. MR0769847
  11. S. Shelah, Vive la différence. II. The Ax–Kochen isomorphism theorem, Israel Journal of Mathematics 85 (1994), 351–390. MR1264351
  12. S. Shelah, Quite complete real closed fields, Israel Journal of Mathematics 142 (2004), 261–272. MR2085719
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3401904 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Steprāns, Juris(3-YORK)
Department of Mathematics, York University
Toronto, Ontario, M3J 1P3, Canada

Non-trivial automorphisms of $\scr{P}(\Bbb{N})/[\Bbb{N}]^{<\aleph_0}$ from variants of small dominating number. (English summary)
Eur. J. Math. 1 (2015), no. 3, 534–544.
03E35 (03E05 03E17 03E50 06E05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-12-04 Review Published2015-12-28

The problem whether, or rather when, the automorphisms of $\Cal{P}(\Bbb{N})/[\Bbb{N}]^{<\aleph_0}$ are trivial (induced by a map between cofinite subsets of $\Bbb{N}$) has received much attention. W. Rudin [Duke Math. J. 23 (1956), 633; MR0080903] showed that there may be many non-trivial automorphisms, and S. Shelah [Proper forcing, Lecture Notes in Mathematics, 940, Springer, Berlin, 1982; MR0675955] established the consistency of "all automorphisms are trivial''. The present paper offers a sufficient condition for the existence of non-trivial automorphisms of $\Cal{P}(\kappa)/[\kappa]^{<\kappa}$ for general $\kappa$. This condition is shown to be applicable to inaccessible $\kappa$.
   In the case of $\kappa=\aleph_0$ the condition can be distilled down to a cardinal equality: $\frak{d}_{f,g}=\aleph_1$ for certain functions from $\Bbb{N}$ to $\Bbb{N}$, where $\frak{d}_{f,g}$ is the minimum cardinality of a set, $\Cal{F}$, of functions $F\:\omega\to[\omega]^{<\aleph_0}$ that satisfy $F(n)\in[f(n)]^{g(n)}$ for all $n$, and is such that for every $x\in\prod_n f(n)$ there is $F\in\Cal{F}$ such that $x(n)\in F(n)$ for all $n$. By contrast the equality $\frak{d}=\aleph_1$ is consistent with all automorphisms of $\Cal{P}(\Bbb{N})/[\Bbb{N}]^{<\aleph_0}$ being trivial [I. Farah and S. Shelah, Israel J. Math. 201 (2014), no. 2, 701–728; MR3265300].
Reviewed by Klaas Pieter Hart

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3395354 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Spinas, Otmar(D-KIEL-MS)
Mathematisches Seminar, Christian-Albrechts Universität Kiel
D-24118 Kiel, Germany

Mad spectra. (English summary)
J. Symb. Log. 80 (2015), no. 3, 901–916.
03E35 (03E17)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-11-23 Review Published2016-02-18

Two infinite subsets $A$ and $B$ of $\omega$ are almost disjoint provided $A\cap{B}$ is finite. A family $\Cal{A}$ of pairwise almost disjoint subsets of $\omega$ is an almost disjoint family. If, in addition, $\Cal{A}$ is maximal with respect to inclusion then $\Cal{A}$ is called a maximal almost disjoint, or a mad, family. The minimum size of a mad family is a cardinal invariant denoted by $\germ{a}$. It is easy to see that $\omega_1\leq{\germ{a}}\leq 2^{\omega}$. Two major results about this cardinal invariant are provided by the consistency (with respect to ${\ssf{ZFC}}$) of the inequality $\germ{d}<\germ{a}$ [see S. Shelah, Acta Math. 192 (2004), no. 2, 187–223; MR2096454] and the consistency of $\germ{a}=\aleph_{\omega}$ [see J. Brendle, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 355 (2003), no. 7, 2633–2649; MR1975392]. One natural problem is to determine whether a given set of uncountable cardinals can be realized as the set of sizes (or spectrum) of mad families on $\omega$. Since there are always mad families of size $2^{\omega}$, such a set must contain $2^{\omega}$ as its maximum. Also, it is not difficult to see that the mad spectrum must be closed under taking singular limits. As early as 1972, S. H. Hechler [General Topology and Appl. 2 (1972), 139–149; MR0307913] obtained a characterization of those sets $\Bbb{C}\subseteq{{\bf Card}}$ that occur as the mad spectrum of some forcing extension of a ground model ${\bf V}$. More specifically, he proved that if ${\bf V}\models$"${\ssf{ZFC+GCH}}$'', then there exists a c.c.c. forcing notion $\Bbb P\in{\bf V}$ such that $\Vdash_{\Bbb{P}}$"$\Bbb{C}$ is the mad spectrum'', provided the following conditions are satisfied:
(a)
$\Bbb{C}$ is a set of uncountable cardinals;
(b)
$\Bbb{C}$ is closed under singular limits;
(c)
if $\mu\in{\Bbb{C}}$ and ${\rm cof}(\mu)=\omega$, then $\mu=\sup(\Bbb{C}\cap{\mu})$;
(d)
$\max(\Bbb{C})$ exists and $\max(\Bbb{C})^{\omega}=\max(\Bbb{C})$;
(e)
$\omega_1\in \Bbb{C}$;
(f)
if $\mu\in{{\bf Card}}$ and $\omega_1<\mu\leq{|\Bbb{C}|}$ then $\mu\in{\Bbb{C}}$;
(g)
if $\mu\in{\Bbb{C}}$ and ${\rm cof}(\mu)=\omega$ then $\mu^{+}\in{\Bbb{C}}$.
The question whether conditions (c), (e), (f) and (g) are necessary remained open. In particular, D. Raghavan asked whether one can obtain a model where the mad spectrum contains $\aleph_{\omega}$ but it does not contain $\aleph_{\omega+1}$. In the paper under review the authors prove that for every $\Bbb{C}\subseteq{{\bf Card}}$ with properties (a), (b) and (d) there is a c.c.c. forcing notion $\Bbb{P}_{\Bbb{C}}$ such that $\Vdash_{\Bbb{P}_{\Bbb{C}}}$"$\Bbb{C}$ is the mad spectrum'', provided $\min(\Bbb{C})$ satisfies
(i)
$\min(\Bbb{C})=\min(\Bbb{C})^{<\min(\Bbb{C})}$ (hence $\min(\Bbb{C})$ is regular), and
(ii)
$\max(\Bbb{C})^{<\min(\Bbb{C})}=\max(\Bbb{C})$.
In particular, this answers affirmatively the question of Raghavan.
Reviewed by Andrés Millán

    References
  1. Jörg Brendle, The almost-disjointness number may have countable cofinality. Transactions of the American Mathematical Society 355, vol. no. 7 (2003), pp. 2633–2649. MR1975392
  2. Stephen S. Hechler, Short complete nested sequences in $\beta n \backslash n$ and small maximal almost-disjoint families. General Topology and its Applications, vol. 2 (1972), pp. 139–149. MR0307913
  3. Saharon Shelah, Special subsets of $^{cf(\mu)}\mu$, boolean algebras and maharam measure algebras. Topology and its Application, vol. 99 (1999), pp. 135–235. MR1728851
  4. Saharon Shelah, Two cardinal invariants of the continuum $(\frak{d} < \frak{a})$ and fs linearly ordered iterated forcing. Acta Mathematica, vol. 192 (2004), pp. 187–233. MR2096454
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 0

MR3395349 Reviewed
Baldwin, John T.(1-ILCC-MS)
Department of Mathematics, Statistics and Computer Science, University of Illinois
Chicago, Illinois, 60680
; Larson, Paul B.(1-MMOH-DM)
Department of Mathematics, Miami University
Oxford, Ohio, 45056
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Almost Galois $\omega$-stable classes. (English summary)
J. Symb. Log. 80 (2015), no. 3, 763–784.
03C48 (03C45 03C75)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-11-23 Review Published2016-07-12

This paper examines pseudoelementary classes in $L_{\omega_1,\omega}$ to gain insight into characteristics of counterexamples to Vaught's conjecture and to establish an absoluteness theorem for $\aleph_1$-categoricity in pseudoelementary classes which also happen to be abstract elementary classes (AECs). This work, which combines syntactic ideas from infinitary logic with semantic AECs, helps to connect model theorists and set theorists interested in non-elementary classes. The reader will benefit from prior familiarity with the literature on AECs. However, although it is referenced, background on Shelah's good $\lambda$-frames is not required. For those interested in AECs, Theorem 3.18 provides sufficient conditions to conclude $\omega$-Galois stability. Furthermore, in the proof of Theorem 3.18, the authors—in a rare but welcome manner—take care to provide details of a construction of an increasing chain of elementary submodels of $H(\theta)$. In the existing literature on AECs, this kind of argument is generally not well explained.
Reviewed by Monica M. VanDieren
