Citations

From References: 7

From Reviews: 1

MR3391912 Reviewed
Malliaris, M.(1-CHI)
Department of Mathematics, University of Chicago
Chicago, Illinois, 60637
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Constructing regular ultrafilters from a model-theoretic point of view. (English summary)
Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 367 (2015), no. 11, 8139–8173.
03C20 (03C45 03E05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-11-10 Review Published2016-09-30

A regular ultrafilter can be used to construct an elementary extension of a model by taking an ultrapower of the model modulo the ultrafilter, resulting in a structure with some saturation properties. Good ultrafilters are particularly useful in this regard, in the sense that saturation properties of the resulting ultrapowers are stronger than what can be ensured with ordinary regular ultrafilters. The authors analyze the effects of some properties of ultrafilters between regularity and goodness on the amount of saturation which ultrapowers of models of some unstable theories can have. The analysis enables the authors to identify some useful properties strictly between regularity and goodness. The paper continues the program of the authors of analyzing Keisler's order of theories [see, for instance, M. Malliaris and S. Shelah, Adv. Math. 290 (2016), 614–681; MR3451934]. Some results are expressed in terms of possible cuts in linear orders. The paper includes applications in the presence of large cardinals.
   Summary: "This paper contributes to the set-theoretic side of understanding Keisler's order. We consider properties of ultrafilters which affect saturation of unstable theories: the lower cofinality $\operatorname{lcf}(\aleph_0,\Cal{D})$ of $\aleph_0$ modulo $\Cal{D}$, saturation of the minimum unstable theory (the random graph), flexibility, goodness, goodness for equality, and realization of symmetric cuts. We work in ZFC except when noted, as several constructions appeal to complete ultrafilters and thus assume a measurable cardinal. The main results are as follows. First, we investigate the strength of flexibility, known to be detected by non-low theories. Assuming $\kappa>\aleph_0$ is measurable, we construct a regular ultrafilter on $\lambda\ge2^\kappa$ which is flexible but not good, and which moreover has large $\operatorname{lcf}(\aleph_0)$ but does not even saturate models of the random graph. This implies (a) that flexibility alone cannot characterize saturation of any theory, however (b) by separating flexibility from goodness, we remove a main obstacle to proving non-low does not imply maximal. Since flexible is precisely OK, this also shows that (c) from a set-theoretic point of view, consistently, OK need not imply good, addressing a problem from Dow (1985). Second, under no additional assumptions, we prove that there is a loss of saturation in regular ultrapowers of unstable theories, and also give a new proof that there is a loss of saturation in ultrapowers of non-simple theories. More precisely, for $\Cal{D}$ regular on $\kappa$ and $M$ a model of an unstable theory, $M^\kappa/\Cal{D}$ is not $(2^\kappa)^+$-saturated; and for $M$ a model of a non-simple theory and $\lambda=\lambda^{<\lambda}$, $M^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ is not $\lambda^{++}$-saturated. In the third part of the paper, we investigate realization and omission of symmetric cuts, significant both because of the maximality of the strict order property in Keisler's order, and by recent work of the authors on $SOP_2$. We prove that if $\Cal{D}$ is a $\kappa$-complete ultrafilter on $\kappa$, any ultrapower of a sufficiently saturated model of linear order will have no $(\kappa,\kappa)$-cuts, and that if $\Cal{D}$ is also normal, it will have a $(\kappa^+,\kappa^+)$-cut. We apply this to prove that for any $n<\omega$, assuming the existence of $n$ measurable cardinals below $\lambda$, there is a regular ultrafilter $\Cal{D}$ on $\lambda$ such that any $\Cal{D}$-ultrapower of a model of linear order will have $n$ alternations of cuts, as defined below. Moreover, $\Cal{D}$ will $\lambda^+$-saturate all stable theories but will not $(2^\kappa)^+$-saturate any unstable theory, where $\kappa$ is the smallest measurable cardinal used in the construction.''
Reviewed by Renling Jin

    References

MR3373611 Reviewed
Kennedy, Juliette(FIN-HELS-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Helsinki
00170 Helsinki, Finland
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Väänänen, Jouko(FIN-HELS-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Helsinki
00170 Helsinki, Finland

Regular ultrapowers at regular cardinals. (English summary)
Notre Dame J. Form. Log. 56 (2015), no. 3, 417–428.
03C20 (03E05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-09-28 Review Published2016-01-04

The paper under review represents a significant advancement towards a complete solution of some classical problems in model theory. Conjectures 18 and 19 in [C. C. Chang and H. J. Keisler, Model theory, third edition, Stud. Logic Found. Math., 73, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1990; MR1059055] ask, respectively, whether ultrapowers of elementarily equivalent models are isomorphic and whether ultrapowers are $\lambda^{++}$-universal, where the ultrapowers are taken modulo some regular ultrafilter $D$ on $\lambda$ and the models and the language are required to satisfy some appropriate cardinality conditions.
   In the case when $\lambda$ is a singular strong limit cardinal, the same authors have consistently answered the problems in the negative, relative to the consistency of a strongly compact cardinal [see J. Symbolic Logic 73 (2008), no. 3, 817–823; MR2444269]. The proofs rely heavily on a formerly introduced finite square-like principle $\square ^{\rm fin} _{ \lambda, D} $ depending on a filter $D$ on $\lambda$. See [J. C. Kennedy and S. Shelah, J. Symbolic Logic 67 (2002), no. 3, 1169–1177; MR1926605; J. Symbolic Logic 69 (2004), no. 4, 1261–1266; MR2135667].
   In order to deal with the case when $\lambda$ is regular the authors introduce some new notions of independent interest. First, some weaker versions of $\square ^{\rm fin} _{ \lambda, D} $ are considered and, remarkably, they are shown to be provable in ZFC, under the assumption that the filter $D$ extends the closed unbounded filter. Furthermore, new classes of ultrafilters are introduced. A filter $D$ on a regular cardinal $\lambda$ is called doubly$^{+}$ regular if it extends the "sum'' of a family of $\lambda$-many $\lambda$-regular filters, where the sum is taken modulo the closed unbounded filter on $\lambda$. Double regularity is defined in a similar way, with the sum taken modulo the filter dual to the ideal of bounded sets.
   The authors prove that if $D$ is a doubly$^{+}$ regular filter on a regular uncountable cardinal $\lambda$, then $\square ^{\rm fin} _{ \lambda, D} $ holds. This implies that Conjecture 19 has a positive answer when specialized to double$^{+}$ regular ultrafilters on uncountable regular cardinals. Concerning Conjecture 18, the results give Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé infinitary equivalence up to length $\lambda^+$, in place of isomorphism. These are only partial solutions of the conjectures, since it is proved that, under some cardinality assumptions on $\lambda$, double$^{+}$ regularity is a notion strictly stronger than regularity. Double regularity is incomparable, in general, with being good. The same applies to double$^{+}$ regularity, as follows from a variant of the proof.
Reviewed by Paolo Lipparini

    References

This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR3320594 Reviewed
Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Väänänen, J.(FIN-HELS-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Helsinki
00170 Helsinki, Finland
; Veličković, B.(F-PARIS7-IMJ)
Institut de Mathématiques de Jussieu (IMJ-PRG), Université de Paris VII (Denis Diderot)
Paris, France

Positional strategies in long Ehrenfeucht-Fraïssé games. (English summary)
J. Symb. Log. 80 (2015), no. 1, 285–300.
03E35 (03C55 03E10)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-05-06 Review Published2016-02-02

Given the relational structures ${\cal A}=(A;\dots)$ and ${\cal B}=(B;\dots)$ of size $\aleph_2$, one can consider the following weakenings of being isomorphic:
($*$)
Player II has a winning strategy in the game of length $\omega_1$, where in round $\alpha$ the first player, I, chooses the countable subsets $A_\alpha\subseteq A$ and $B_\alpha \subseteq B$. Then player II extends the formerly obtained partial isomorphism to include $A_\alpha$ and $B_\alpha$ in the domain and range, respectively, and II wins if she can continue forever.
($**$)
There is a set ${\cal F}$ of partial isomorphisms between countable subsets of $A$ and $B$ such that ${\cal F}$ is closed under taking increasing unions of countable length and for each $f\in{\cal F}$, countable sets $A_0\subseteq A$ and $B_0\subseteq B$, $f$ extends to some $f'\in{\cal F}$ whose domain and range contain $A_0$ and $B_0$, respectively.
A model of ZFC+CH is given with two structures for which ($*$) holds but ($**$) fails. The model is obtained by an $\omega_1$-closed, $\aleph_2$-c.c. forcing over a model with a generically added simplified morass.
Reviewed by Péter Komjáth

    References
  1. M. A. Dickmann, Large infinitary languages, Model theory, Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, vol. 83, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1975. MR0539973
  2. M. A. Dickmann, Deux applications de la méthode de va-et-vient. Publ. Dép. Math. (Lyon), vol. 14 (1977), no. 2, pp. 63–92. MR0540001
  3. P. Erdös, L. Gillman, and M. Henriksen, An isomorphism theorem for real-closed fields. Annals of Mathematics (2), vol. 61 (1955), pp. 542–554. MR0069161
  4. Tapani Hyttinen, Games and infinitary languages. Ann. Acad. Sci. Fenn. Ser. A I Math. Dissertationes, vol. 64 (1987), p. 32. MR0881268
  5. Maaret Karttunen, Infinitary languages ${N_{\infty \lambda }}$ and generalized partial isomorphisms. Essays on mathematical and philosophical logic (Proc. Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3314130 Reviewed
Juhász, István(H-AOS)
Alfréd Rényi Institute of Mathematics, Hungarian Academy of Sciences (MTA)
1364 Budapest, Hungary
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Strong colorings yield $\kappa$-bounded spaces with discretely untouchable points. (English summary)
Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 143 (2015), no. 5, 2241–2247.
54A25 (03E05 54D30)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-04-15 Review Published2015-08-14

In a compact Hausdorff space, every non-isolated point is the accumulation point of a discrete subset. Answering an open problem, the authors in this article show that this is not the case for countably compact regular spaces or even $\omega$-bounded regular spaces. Explicitly, the authors show that when $\lambda>\kappa^+$ is a regular cardinal such that ${\rm Col}(\lambda, \kappa)$ holds, there is a dense $\kappa$-unbounded subspace of the Cantor cube $2^\lambda$ that has a discretely untouchable non-isolated point.
   The condition ${\rm Col}(\lambda, \kappa)$ is the strong coloring property invented by the second author, which holds true when $\lambda=(2^\kappa)^{++}+\omega_4$. It states the existence of a coloring $c\: [\lambda]^2\rightarrow 2$ such that, given any ordinal $\xi<\kappa^+$ and a map $h\: \xi\times \xi\rightarrow 2$, for every family $\{A_\alpha = \{a_{\alpha, i}: i<\xi\}: \alpha<\lambda\}$ of $\lambda$ many pairwise disjoint subsets of $\lambda$ of order type $\xi$, there are $\alpha<\beta<\lambda$ such that $c(a_{\alpha, i}, a_{\beta, j})=h(i,j)$ holds for all $(i, j)\in \xi\times\xi$.
Reviewed by Wanjun Hu

    References
  1. Eric K. van Douwen, Applications of maximal topologies, Topology Appl. 51 (1993), no. 2, 125–139, DOI 10.1016/0166–8641(93)90145–4. MR1229708 (94h:54012) MR1229708
  2. Edwin Hewitt, A problem of set-theoretic topology, Duke Math. J. 10 (1943), 309–333. MR0008692 (5,46e) MR0008692
  3. István Juhász, Lajos Soukup, and Zoltán Szentmiklóssy, $\scr{D}$-forced spaces: a new approach to resolvability, Topology Appl. 153 (2006), no. 11, 1800–1824, DOI 10.1016/j.topol.2005.06.007. MR2227028 (2007m:54005) MR2227028
  4. István Juhász, Lajos Soukup, and Zoltán Szentmiklóssy, Resolvability and monotone normality, Israel J. Math. 166 (2008), 1–16, DOI 10.1007/s11856–008-1017-y. MR2430422 (2009d:54007) MR2430422
  5. P. L. Sharma and Saroj Sharma, Resolution property in generalized $k$-spaces, Topology Appl. 29 (1988), no. 1, 61–66, DOI 10.1016/0166–8641(88)90057–0. MR944069 (89e:54048) MR0944069
  6. Saharon Shelah, Cardinal arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides, vol. 29, The Clarendon Press Oxford University Press, New York, 1994. Oxford Science Publications. MR1318912 (96e:03001) MR1318912
  7. S. Shelah, The coloring theorems revisited, [Sh:1027] in preparation.
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 1

MR3312115 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Laskowski, Michael C.(1-MD)
Department of Mathematics, University of Maryland
College Park, Maryland, 20742

$\bold P$-NDOP and $\bold P$-decompositions of $\aleph_\epsilon$-saturated models of superstable theories. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 229 (2015), no. 1, 47–81.
03C45 (03C50)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-04-10 Review Published2015-06-10

The authors study tree decompositions of sufficiently saturated models with respect to a class $P$ of regular types, in the context of superstable theories satisfying a suitable form of the condition known as NDOP. Generally speaking, the class of regular types considered is taken to be closed under non-orthogonality, isomorphism, and a notion of support reflecting the construction of tree decompositions. The first five sections give a thorough development of this theory, with the fifth section introducing an associated family of types over the model, namely the set of types in $P$ over the model which are orthogonal to the base but not to all nodes of the tree. This set is shown to be independent of the specific decomposition (Theorem 5.12) and to have its own intrinsic tree structure (Theorem 5.16).
   In the sixth and final section these results are transferred to some extent to arbitrary models $M$. Extending $M$ to a sufficiently saturated model, one looks for a tree decomposition of the extension compatible with $M$ in an appropriate sense (§6.1). Then in §6.2 the context is specialized to totally transcendental theories and a technical result is proved (Theorem 6.19) which plays an essential role in [M. C. Laskowski and S. Shelah, Fund. Math. 229 (2015), no. 1, 1–46; MR3312114]. The authors have some harsh words for this result ("inelegant at best,'' "extreme case'') but the reader (or in any case, the reader of [op. cit.]) will no doubt be happy to have it.
Reviewed by G. Cherlin

    References
  1. M. C. Laskowski and S. Shelah, Decompositions of saturated models of stable theories, Fund. Math. 191 (2006), 95–124. MR2231058
  2. M. C. Laskowski and S. Shelah, Borel completeness of some $\aleph _0$-stable theories, Fund. Math. 229 (2015), 1–46. MR3312114
  3. M. Makkai, A survey of basic stability theory, with particular emphasis on orthogonality and regular types, Israel J. Math. 49 (1984), 181–238. MR0788268
  4. S. Shelah, Classification Theory, rev. ed., North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1990.
  5. S. Shelah, Characterizing an $\aleph _\epsilon$-saturated model of superstable NDOP theories by its ${\Bbb{L}_{\infty ,{\aleph _\epsilon}}}$-theory, Israel J. Math. 140 (2004), 61–111. MR2054839
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 1

MR3312114 Reviewed
Laskowski, Michael C.(1-MD)
Department of Mathematics, University of Maryland
College Park, Maryland, 20742
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Borel completeness of some $\aleph_0$-stable theories. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 229 (2015), no. 1, 1–46.
03C45 (03E15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-04-10 Review Published2016-07-28

Suppose that $T$ is a countable, complete, $\aleph_0$-stable theory. When is the isomorphism relation on the class of countable models of $T$ Borel complete? When is it the case that for every infinite cardinal $\lambda$, $T$ has the maximum possible number $2^\lambda$ of pairwise $L_{\infty,\aleph_0}$-inequivalent models of size $\lambda$? These two questions are closely related, and the paper under review gives a complete answer to the second question and a partial answer to the first. Namely, within the class of $\aleph_0$-stable theories $T$, the following is established:
   Theorem 1. If $T$ has eni-DOP, or if $T$ has eni-NDOP and is eni-deep, then its class of countable models is Borel complete.
   Theorem 2. The following are equivalent: (a) for all infinite cardinals $\lambda$, $T$ has $2^\lambda$ pairwise $L_{\infty, \aleph_0}$-inequivalent models of size $\lambda$; (b) $T$ either has eni-DOP or is eni-deep.
   Recall that DOP is the dimensional order property. The key new notion is that of an eni type. A stationary regular type $p$ is eventually nonisolated (eni) if there is a finite set $A$ on which $p$ is based and stationary, while $p|A$ is non-isolated. The theory of eni types and related notions (such as a theory $T$ having eni-DOP, which means that some eni type $p$ has a DOP witness) are introduced and developed in Sections 1 and 2.
   As is usual in Shelahian classification theory, the overarching strategy is to search for general wild/tame dichotomies for a theory $T$, and for $T$ which are sufficiently "tame'', one develops a scheme for classifying all of its models using trees of invariants. In this case, the idea will be that wild enough $\aleph_0$-stable theories (those which have eni-DOP or are eni-deep) can encode complicated families of bipartite graphs or trees in their models, which will imply Borel completeness, as well as the more general property of $\lambda$-Borel completeness for the class of models of size $\lambda$. In case $T$ is tame—in the context of this paper, this means that $T$ both has eni-NDOP and is eni-shallow—then it turns out that all models are prime over "nice'' well-founded trees of small submodels, which is used to show that $T$ has fewer than the maximal number of $L_{\infty, \aleph_0}$-inequivalent models.
   The two main dichotomies defined in this paper are eni-DOP/eni-NDOP and eni-deep/eni-shallow. These are like the usual DOP/NDOP and deep/shallow dichotomies but applied to models that are prime over realizations of regular eni types. It is shown that for $\aleph_0$-stable theories, eni-DOP is equivalent to OTOP. The authors also introduce a new dichotomy for regular types, eni-active/dull, where "dull types'' form a class closed under automorphisms and nonorthogonality of types which, in a sense, have nothing to do with any eni-types.
   On the structure side, some interesting new results are obtained on prime regular, eni, and eni-active decompositions of models of $\aleph_0$-stable, eni-NDOP theories. Essentially, any model of such a theory is prime over a tree of elementary submodels whose "root'' is prime over $\emptyset$ and whose "branching'' is given by independent families of submodels which are prime over realizations of types of the corresponding flavor (regular, eni, or eni-active). Eni-active tree decompositions determine models of $\aleph_0$-stable, eni-NDOP theories up to $L_{\infty, \aleph_0}$-equivalence.
   The problem of characterizing which $\aleph_0$-stable, eni-NDOP, and eni-shallow theories have Borel complete classes of countable models is apparently still open.
Reviewed by John Goodrick

    References
  1. E. Bouscaren and D. Lascar, Countable models of nonmultidimensional $\aleph _0$-stable theories, J. Symbolic Logic 48 (1983), 197–205. MR0693263
  2. H. Friedman and L. Stanley, A Borel reducibility theory for classes of countable structures, J. Symbolic Logic 54 (1989), 894–914. MR1011177
  3. M. Koerwien, Comparing Borel reducibility and depth of an $\omega $-stable theory, Notre Dame J. Formal Logic 50 (2009), 365–380. MR2598869
  4. M. C. Laskowski, An old friend revisited: Countable models of $\omega $-stable theories, Notre Dame J. Formal Logic 48 (2007), 133–141. MR2289902
  5. M. Makkai, A survey of basic stability theory, with particular emphasis on orthogonality and regular types, Israel J. Math. 49 (1984), 181–238. MR0788268
  6. S. Shelah, Classification Theory, rev. ed., North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1990.
  7. S. Shelah, On the number of non-almost isomorphic models of $T$ in a power, Pacific J. Math. 36 (1971), 811–818. MR0285375
  8. S. Shelah, Existence of many $L_{\infty ,\lambda }$-equivalent, nonisomorphic models of $T$ of power $\lambda$, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 34 (1987), 291–310. MR0899084
  9. S. Shelah, Characterizing an $\aleph _\epsilon$-saturated model of superstable NDOP theories by its ${\Bbb{L}_{\infty ,{\aleph _\epsilon}}}$-theory, Israel J. Math. 140 (2004), 61–111. MR2054839
  10. S. Shelah and M. C. Laskowski, $\bold P$-NDOP and $\bold P$-decompositions of $\aleph _\epsilon$-saturated models of superstable theories, Fund. Math. 229 (2015), 47–81. MR3312115
  11. S. Shelah, L. A. Harrington, and M. Makkai, A proof of Vaught's conjecture for $\omega$-stable theories, Israel J. Math. 49 (1984), 259–280. MR0788270
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 10

From Reviews: 0

MR3291978 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Dependent theories and the generic pair conjecture. (English summary)
Commun. Contemp. Math. 17 (2015), no. 1, 1550004, 64 pp.
03C45 (03C55)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2015 Indexed 2015-02-24 Review Published2015-11-18

This article aims to provide a new characterization of which first-order theories are dependent (also known as NIP) via the author's own Generic Pair Conjecture, which roughly speaking gives a kind of bound on the types of elementary extensions $M_\alpha \prec M_\beta$ which can occur in a continuous chain $\{M_\alpha: \alpha < \lambda^+\}$ of models of size $\lambda$ whose union is $\lambda^+$-saturated. The author notes parallels between this characterization and well-known structural equivalents of the stable/unstable divide: stability, like dependence, is defined by combinatorial properties of definable sets but, surprisingly, it turns out to be equivalent to the saturation of certain elementary chains of models.
   Fix some complete first-order theory $T$ and a sufficiently large cardinal $\lambda = \lambda^{<\lambda} > |T|$. Also suppose that we are given a continuous, increasing elementary chain $\{M_\alpha: \alpha < \lambda^+\}$ of models of $T$, each of size $\lambda$, such that its union is a saturated model of size $\lambda^+$. Then the Generic Pair Conjecture states that $T$ is dependent if and only if there is some closed, unbounded $E \subseteq \lambda^+$ such that all pairs $(M_\alpha, M_\beta)$ such that $\alpha, \beta \in E_\lambda$ have the same isomorphism type, where $E_\lambda$ denotes the elements of $E$ with cofinality $\lambda$. The main theorem of the article under review establishes the "only if'' direction of the Generic Pair Conjecture in the case when $\lambda$ is a measurable cardinal.
   In Section $1$, the Density of Reduced Pairs Theorem for dependent $T$ is established: If $\kappa$ is a regular cardinal greater than $|T|$ and $M \prec N$ is a pair of $\kappa$-saturated models, then there is another pair $M_1 \prec N_1$ of models such that $M \prec M_1$, $N \prec N_1$, $M_1$ is constructible over $M$ by successively realizing types non-splitting over bases of size $< \kappa$ (i.e. it is "$\bold{F}^{nsp}_\kappa$-constructible over $M$''), and $(N_1 / M_1)$ is weakly orthogonal to any type realized in an $\bold{F}^{nsp}_\kappa$-constructible extension over $M_1$.
   The principal result of Section 2 is the Type Decomposition Theorem: if $M$ is a $\kappa$-saturated model of $T$ (which is dependent) and $\text{cf}(\kappa) > \theta \geq |T|$, then for any type $\text{tp}(\overline{d} / M)$ of some $\theta$-tuple $\overline{d}$, there is another $\theta$-tuple $\overline{c}$ such that:
(1)
$\text{tp}(\overline{c} / M)$ does not split over some set of size $\kappa$; and
(2)
the partial ordering on $\{ \text{tp}(\overline{d} / A \cup \overline{c} ) : A \subseteq M, |A| \leq \theta \}$ given by $\vdash$ is $\kappa$-co-directed.

   The idea is that $\text{tp}(\overline{c} / M)$ corresponds to a "stable-like'' part of $\text{tp}(\overline{d} / M)$ (indeed if $T$ is stable one can take $\overline{c} = \overline{d}$) while $\text{tp}(\overline{d} / M \overline{c})$ is "purely tree-like''.
   Section 3 is devoted to proving a stronger version of this (Strict Decomposition), which in Section 4 is used to prove the "structure'' half of the Generic Pair Conjecture stated above for measurable cardinals.
Reviewed by John Goodrick

    References
  1. C. C. Chang and H. Jerome Keisler, Model Theory, Studies in Logic and the Foundation of Mathematics, Vol. 73 (North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1973). MR0409165
  2. A. Ehrenfeucht, On theories categorical in power, Fund. Math. 44 (1957) 241–248. MR0096606

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3468189 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Reflecting on logical dreams. Interpreting Gödel, 242–255, Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, 2014.
03E35 (03-02 03A05 03B60 03C45 03E25)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2016-08-09 Review Published2017-01-05

The distinguished author gives a progress report on his various projects, called "dreams'' in his 2003 paper "Logical dreams'' [Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.) 40 (2003), no. 2, 203–228; MR1962296]. The projects from the 2003 paper that are discussed in this report are:
(1)
Find a general method of proving independence results from the Peano axioms, similar to forcing for ZFC.
(2)
Search for additional axioms for ZFC. What makes such an axiom good? (In particular, identify interesting theories for the projective sets that are incompatible with determinacy, and find interesting systems where the classical cardinal characteristics from the Cichoń diagram are all distinct.)
(3)
Elaborate a method of forcing iteration making the continuum $\frak c$ at least $\aleph_3$. The current general methods can only produce models where $\frak{c}\le\aleph_2$.
(4)
Study the world without the Axiom of Choice; e.g., understand how model theory or pcf theory is affected if we only allow a weak form of AC.
(5)
Prove a form of the main gap for several general classes.
(6)
Search for a new logic with good model theory and strong expressive power.
(7)
Develop the theory of abstract elementary classes.

   Beyond representing the corresponding results (for instance, there is significant progress regarding (3), and the two volumes [S. Shelah, Classification theory for elementary abstract classes, Stud. Log. (Lond.), 18, Coll. Publ., London, 2009; MR2643267; Classification theory for abstract elementary classes. Vol. 2, Stud. Log. (Lond.), 20, Coll. Publ., London, 2009; MR2649290] can be seen as progress toward (5) and (7)), the author describes his views on the "right'' directions, and gives rich details of his philosophy. Nevertheless, "ideology and/or good taste should not stop you from proving a good theorem'' (p. 247).

{For the collection containing this paper see MR3381588.} Reviewed by Péter Komjáth

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3365394 Reviewed
Filipczak, Tomasz(PL-PLDZ-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Technical University of Łódź
90-924 Łódź, Poland
; Rosłanowski, Andrzej(1-NEO)
Department of Mathematics, University of Nebraska
Omaha, Nebraska, 68182
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

On Borel hull operations. (English summary)
Real Anal. Exchange 40 (2014/15), no. 1, 129–140.
54H05 (03E15 03E17 28A05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2015-08-28 Review Published2015-11-05

In the paper under review, the authors study the existence of a monotone or translation-invariant Borel hull operation for the $ \sigma $-ideals of meager sets and of Lebesgue null sets.
   Let $ \Cal{M} $ denote the $ \sigma $-ideal of meager sets in a Polish space $ \bold{X} $ and let $ \Cal{S}_{\Cal{M}} $ be the $ \sigma $-algebra of all subsets of $ \bold{X} $ with the Baire property. Let $ \Cal{N} $ denote the $ \sigma $-ideal of all Lebesgue null sets in $ \Bbb{R}^{n} $ and let $ \Cal{S}_{\Cal{N}} $ be the $ \sigma $-algebra of all Lebesgue measurable subsets of $ \Bbb{R}^{n} $.
   Let $ \Cal{I} = \Cal{M} $ or $ \Cal{I} = \Cal{N} $ and let $ \Cal{F} \subseteq \Cal{S}_{\Cal{I}} $. A Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{F} $ with respect to $ \Cal{I} $ is a mapping $ \psi \: \Cal{F} \to \roman{Borel} $ such that $ A \subseteq \psi(A) $ and $ \psi(A) \sbs A \in \Cal{I} $ for all $ A \in \Cal{F} $. A Borel hull operation $ \psi $ on $ \Cal{F} $ is called monotone if $ \psi(A_{1}) \subseteq \psi(A_{2}) $ whenever $ A_{1} \subseteq A_{2} $ are from $ \Cal{F} $. In the case that $ \bold{X} = \Bbb{R}^{n} $ and $ \Cal{F} $ is translation invariant, $ \psi $ is called translation invariant if $ \psi(A + x) = \psi(A) + x $ for all $ A \in \Cal{F} $ and $ x \in \Bbb{R}^{n} $.
   The following cardinal coefficients of $ \Cal{I} $ are considered: $$ \roman{non}(\Cal{I}) = \min \{ |A| : A \subseteq \bold{X}, A \notin \Cal{I} \}, $$ $$ \roman{cof}(\Cal{I}) = \min \{ |\Cal{F}| : \Cal{F} \subseteq \Cal{I}, (\forall A \in \Cal{I})(\exists B \in \Cal{F})(A \subseteq B) \}, $$ and, in the case $ \bold{X} = \Bbb{R}^{n} $, $$ \roman{cov}^{*}(\Cal{I}) = \min \{ |A| : A \subseteq \Bbb{R}^{n}, (\exists B \in \Cal{I})(A + B = \Bbb{R}^{n}) \}. $$
   It was shown in [M. Elekes and A. Máthé, Fund. Math. 205 (2009), no. 2, 105–115; MR2545447] and [M. Balcerzak and T. Filipczak, MLQ Math. Log. Q. 57 (2011), no. 2, 186–193; MR2816096] that the existence of a monotone Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{S}_{\Cal{I}} $ with respect to $ \Cal{I} $ (where $ \Cal{I} = \Cal{M} $ or $ \Cal{I} = \Cal{N} $) is independent of ZFC.
   The authors show that, if there exists a monotone Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{M} $, then there exists a monotone Borel hull operation even on $ \Cal{S}_\Cal{M} $. It is not known if the same holds for $ \Cal{N} $ and $ \Cal{S}_\Cal{N} $.
   The authors prove further that if $ \Bbb{R}^{n} $ has a subgroup $ G \in \Cal{N} \sbs \Cal{M} $, then there is no translation invariant Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{N} $. Similarly, if $ \Bbb{R}^{n} $ has a subgroup $ H \in \Cal{M} \sbs \Cal{N} $, then there is no translation invariant Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{M} $. They also prove the existence of such subgroups (in fact, $ \Bbb{Q} $-linear subspaces) under some set-theoretic assumptions.
   So, there is no translation invariant Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{N} $ if $$ \roman{non}(\Cal{N}) > \roman{non}(\Cal{M}) \quad \text{or} \quad \roman{cov}^{*}(\Cal{M}) \geq \roman{cof}(\Cal{M}) \quad \text{or} \quad \roman{MA} $$ (where MA stands for Martin's axiom) and, similarly, there is no translation invariant Borel hull operation on $ \Cal{M} $ if $$ \roman{non}(\Cal{M}) > \roman{non}(\Cal{N}) \quad \text{or} \quad \roman{cov}^{*}(\Cal{N}) \geq \roman{cof}(\Cal{N}) \quad \text{or} \quad \roman{MA}. $$ It is not known whether a subgroup of $ \Bbb{R}^{n} $ belonging to $ \Cal{N} \sbs \Cal{M} $ or $ \Cal{M} \sbs \Cal{N} $ can be found in ZFC.
Reviewed by Ondřej Kurka

Citations

From References: 6

From Reviews: 0

MR3313049 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Dependent $T$ and existence of limit models. (English summary)
Tbilisi Math. J. 7 (2014), no. 1, 99–128.
03C45 (03C50 03C55 06A05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2015-04-13 Review Published2015-07-06

A universal model $M$ of a complete first-order theory $T$ is called a superlimit model if the union of any continuous elementary chain of length $\delta$ of isomorphic copies of $M$ is isomorphic to $M$, for any ordinal $\delta < \lambda^+$, where $\lambda= |M|$. If this holds for any $\delta<\lambda^+$ with ${\rm cf}(\delta)=\kappa$ then $M$ is called a $(\lambda,\kappa)$-superlimit model. An unstable theory $T$ has no superlimit models of uncountable cardinalities $\ge |T|$ [S. Shelah, Colloq. Math. 126 (2012), no. 2, 187–204; MR2924249].
   In the paper under review the author proves that the theory $T_{\rm ord}$ of dense linear orderings without endpoints (which is an unstable theory without the independence property) not only has no uncountable superlimit models but also has no $(\lambda,\kappa)$-superlimit model if ${\rm cf}(\kappa)=\kappa<\lambda=\lambda^{<\lambda}$; however, for any such $\lambda$ and $\kappa$ the theory $T_{\rm ord}$ has a so-called invariant medium $(\lambda,\kappa)$-limit model. (This notion is one of the versions of the concept of $(\lambda,\kappa)$-limit model considered in the paper.) The author conjectures that this is true not only for $T_{\rm ord}$ but for any $T$ without the independence property. He asks whether this is false for any $T$ with the independence property, and proves for such theories $T$ a weaker version of that: if $\lambda=2^\nu\ge |T|$ and ${\rm cf}(\kappa)=\kappa<\lambda=\lambda^\kappa$ then $T$ has no medium $(\lambda,\kappa)$-limit model (which is one more version of the concept of $(\lambda,\kappa)$-limit model).
Reviewed by O. V. Belegradek

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3274973 Reviewed
Baldwin, John T.(1-ILCC-MS)
Department of Mathematics, Statistics and Computer Science, University of Illinois
Chicago, Illinois, 60680
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

A Hanf number for saturation and omission: the superstable case. (English summary)
MLQ Math. Log. Q. 60 (2014), no. 6, 437–443.
03C45 (03C75 03C85)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2015-01-09 Review Published2015-09-29

Consider two theories, $T \subseteq T_1$, and a type $p$ over the empty set consistent with $T_1$. The goal of this paper is to compute the least cardinal $\mu$ such that if such a triple $(T, T_1, p)$ has a model of cardinality $\mu$, then it has arbitrarily large models.
   This problem bears on the larger program of the two authors (and others) of describing classification theory in the context of abstract elementary classes.
   The paper under review gives bounds on this cardinal $\mu$ in the case that $T$ is superstable, relating it to the Hanf numbers of infinitary logics.
Reviewed by Wesley Calvert

    References
  1. J. T. Baldwin, Categoricity, University Lecture Notes Vol. 51 (American Mathematical Society, 2009). MR2532039
  2. J. T. Baldwin and S. Shelah, A Hanf number for saturation and omission, Fund. Math. 213, 255–270 (2011). MR2822421
  3. C. C. Chang, Some Remarks on the Model Theory of Infinitary Languages, in: The Syntax and Semantics of Infinitary Languages, edited by J. Barwise, Lecture Notes in Mathematics Vol. 72 (Springer-Verlag, 1968), pp. 36–64. MR0234827
  4. W. Hanf, Models of Languages with Infinitely Long Expressions, in: International Congress of Logic, Methodology and Philosophy of Science, Abstracts of Contributed Papers, Stanford University, Stanford, Calif., August 24 to September 2, 1960 (Stanford University, 1960), p. 24.
  5. E. Hrushovski and S. Shelah, Stability and omitting types, Isr. J. Math. 74, 289–321 (1991). MR1135241
  6. L. Newełski, Bounded orbits and measures on a group, Isr. J. Math. 187, 209–229 (2012). MR2891705
  7. S. Shelah, Classification Theory and the Number of Nonisomorphic Models, Studies of Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics Vol. 92, second edition (Elsevier, 1991). MR1083551
  8. S. Shelah, P. Väisänen, and J. Väänänen, On ordinals accessible by infinitary languages, Fundam. Math. 186, 193–214 (2005). MR2191236

MR3273451 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-E)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics and Computer Science, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Strongly dependent theories. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 204 (2014), no. 1, 1–83.
03C45
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-12-16 Review Published2015-07-13

In this paper, S. Shelah defines several variants on the notion of strongly dependent theories—he attempts to solve the equation $$ \roman{superstable} : \roman{stable} :: x :\roman{dependent}. $$ (Here dependent is another designation for a theory without the independent property.) The most quotable result is: If $|A| + |T|\leq \mu$ and $I$ is an arbitrary subset of the monster with $|I| > \beth_{|T|^+} + \mu$ then some subset $J$ of $I$ is an indiscernible sequence over $A$. I. Kaplan and Shelah [J. Symb. Log. 79 (2014), no. 2, 585–619; MR3224981] showed that there is no such bound for a general dependent theory. In the paper under review, Shelah also shows that the theory of $p$-adics is strongly dependent. The publication date of this influential paper is misleading; the article first appeared on arxiv.org in 2005.
Reviewed by John T. Baldwin

    References
  1. J. T. Baldwin and J. Saxl, Logical stability in group theory, Journal of the Australian Mathematical Society, Ser. A 21 (1976), 267–276. MR0407151
  2. G. Cherlin, Superstable division rings, in Logic Colloquium '77 (Proc. Conf., Wrocław, 1977), Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, Vol. 96, North-Holland, Amsterdam—Newyork, 1978, pp. 99–111. MR0519805

MR3273308 Reviewed
Göbel, Rüdiger; Herden, Daniel(1-WACO)
Department of Mathematics, Baylor University
Waco, Texas, 76798
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Prescribing endomorphism algebras of $\aleph_n$-free modules. (English summary)
J. Eur. Math. Soc. (JEMS) 16 (2014), no. 9, 1775–1816.
13C10 (03C55 03E75 16S50)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-12-15 Review Published2016-02-08

Summary: "It is a well-known fact that modules over a commutative ring in general cannot be classified, and it is also well-known that we have to impose severe restrictions on either the ring or on the class of modules to solve this problem. One of the restrictions on the modules comes from freeness assumptions which have been intensively studied in recent decades. Two interesting, distinct but typical examples are the papers by Blass [1] [MR2513227] and Eklof [8] [MR1914985], both jointly with Shelah. In the first case the authors consider almost-free abelian groups and assume the existence of large canonical, free subgroups. Nevertheless, there exist $\aleph_1$-separable torsion-free groups $G$ of size $\aleph_1$ with a basic subgroup $B$ of rank $\aleph_1$ such that all subgroups of $G$ disjoint from $B$ are also free, but the groups $G$ are still not free. What else can we say about $G$? The other paper deals with Kaplansky's test problems (which are excellent indicators that the objects defy classification). The authors are able to construct very free abelian groups and verify the test problems for them by a careful choice of particular elements of their endomorphism rings.
   "Accordingly, we want to investigate and construct $\aleph_n$-free $R$-modules $M$ (with $n$ an arbitrary, but fixed natural number) over a domain $R$ with ${\rm End}_RM=R$ for the first time more systematically and uniformly. Recall that $M$ is $\aleph_n$-free if every subset of size $<\aleph_n$ is contained in a pure, free submodule of $M$. The requirement ${\rm End}_RM=R$ implies that $M$ is indecomposable, hence complicated. (We will also allow that ${\rm End}_RM$ is a prescribed $R$-algebra, as in the title of this paper.)
   "By now it is folklore to construct such modules $M$ using additional set-theoretic axioms, most notably Jensen's $\diamondsuit$-principle. In this case the freeness condition can even be strengthened (see [6] [MR0670040] and many examples in [9] [MR1485469]). However, if we insist on proving this result in ordinary ZFC, then the known arguments fail: The classical constructions from the fundamental paper by Corner [2] [MR0153743] do not apply because they are based on pure submodules of $p$-adic completions of free $A$-modules, which are never even $\aleph_1$-free. If we use Shelah's Black Box instead of Jensen's $\diamondsuit$-principle, then the constructed modules $M$ are still $\aleph_1$-free, but always fail to be even $\aleph_2$-free (see [4] [MR0779399]). Thus we must develop new methods, which are presented for the first time in Sections 2 to 6, to achieve the desired result (Main Theorem 7.6). With these methods we provide a useful tool for a wide range of problems concerning $\aleph_n$-free structures which can then be attacked.''
Reviewed by Serap Şahinkaya

    References
  1. Blass, A., Shelah, S.: Basic subgroups and freeness, a counterexample. In: Models, Modules and Abelian Groups (in memory of A. L. S. Corner), R. Göbel and B. Goldsmith (eds.), de Gruyter, Berlin, 63–73 (2008) Zbl 1192.20039 MR 2513227 MR2513227
  2. Corner, A. L. S.: Every countable reduced torsion-free ring is an endomorphism ring. Proc. London Math. Soc. (3) 13, 687–710 (1963) Zbl 0116.02403 MR 0153743 MR0153743

  4. Corner, A. L. S., Göbel, R.: Prescribing endomorphism algebras—A unified treatment. Proc. London Math. Soc. (3) 50, 447–479 (1985) Zbl 0562.20030 MR 0779399 MR0779399
  5. Corner, A. L. S., Göbel, R.: Small almost free modules with prescribed topological endomorphism rings. Rend. Sem. Mat. Univ. Padova 109, 217–234 (2003) Zbl 1148.20308 MR 1997988 MR1997988

  8. Eklof, P., Mekler, A.: Almost Free Modules, Set-Theoretic Methods. North-Holland (2002) Zbl 1054.20037 MR 1914985 MR1914985

  13. Göbel, R., Shelah, S.: Almost free indecomposable modules—the local case. Canad. J. Math. 50, 719–738 (1998) Zbl 0959.20049 MR 1638607 MR1638607

  16. Göbel, R., Trlifaj, J.: Approximations and Endomorphism Algebras of Modules. Expositions Math. 41, Vols. 1, 2, de Gruyter, Berlin (2012) Zbl 05948863 MR 2985654 MR2251271

  25. Shelah, S.: PCF and abelian groups. Forum Math. 25, 967–1038 (2013) Zbl 06220099 MR 3100959 MR3100959
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 0

MR3269711 Reviewed
Rosłanowski, Andrzej(1-NEO)
Department of Mathematics, University of Nebraska
Omaha, Nebraska, 68182
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Monotone hulls for $\scr{N}\cap\scr{M}$. (English summary)
Period. Math. Hungar. 69 (2014), no. 1, 79–95.
03E17 (03E15 03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-12-03 Review Published2015-05-15

J. Brendle and S. Fuchino [Fund. Math. 196 (2007), no. 2, 151–195; MR2342625] defined the cardinal invariant $$ \multline \germ{d}_{\germ{o}}=\sup\{\roman{cf}(\roman{o.t.}(\langle X,R \upharpoonright X\rangle)) |\, X\subseteq2^\omega, R\subseteq 2^\omega\times2^\omega\ \text{is projective and}\\ \langle X,R \upharpoonright X\rangle\ \text{is a well order}\} \endmultline $$ and proved that $\min\{\roman{cov}(\scr{I}),\roman{non}(\scr{I})\}\leq\germ{d}_{\germ{o}}$ for every ideal $\scr{I}$ on $2^\omega$ with a Borel basis. In particular, this holds for the $\sigma$-ideal of meager sets $\scr{M}$ and the $\sigma$-ideal of Lebesgue measure zero sets $\scr{N}$.
   One of the main results of the authors is the consistency with ZFC of $\germ{d}_{\germ{o}}=\aleph_1<\roman{non}(\scr{N}\cap \scr{M})=\germ{c}$ (so $\roman{cov}(\scr{M})=\roman{cov}(\scr{N})=\aleph_1$ and $\roman{non}(\scr{M})=\roman{non}(\scr{N})=\germ{c}$) with $\germ{c}$ regular. For this, they prove that any forcing notion constructed with the method of decisive creatures of J. Kellner and S. Shelah [J. Symbolic Logic 74 (2009), no. 1, 73–104; MR2499421], along with a few requirements, forces $\germ{d}_{\germ{o}}=\aleph_1$ and, later, they construct a particular forcing notion with this method that forces $\aleph_1<\roman{non}(\scr{N}\cap \scr{M})=\germ{c}$.
   This consistency result is related with the non-existence of monotone Borel hull operations. If $\scr{I}$ is an ideal on $2^\omega$ with a Borel basis, recall that a monotone Borel hull operation on $\scr{I}$ is a function $\psi\:\scr{I}\to\scr{B}\cap\scr{I}$ ($\scr{B}$ denotes the class of Borel subsets of $2^\omega$) such that, for any $A,A'\in\scr{I}$, if $A\subseteq A'$ then $A\subseteq\psi(A)\subseteq\psi(A')$. M. Elekes and A. Máthé [Fund. Math. 205 (2009), no. 2, 105–115; MR2545447] showed that there is no monotone Borel hull operation on a Borel ideal $\scr{I}$ when $\germ{d}_{\scr{B}}<\roman{cf}(\roman{non}(\scr{I}))$, where $$ \germ{d}_{\scr{B}}=\sup\{\roman{cf}(\gamma)\mid \text{there is a $\subsetneq$-increasing sequence in $\scr{B}$ of length $\gamma$}\}. $$ As $\germ{d}_{\scr{B}}\leq\germ{d}_{\germ{o}}$, there are no monotone Borel hull operations on $\scr{N}$, $\scr{M}$ and $\scr{N}\cap\scr{M}$ in the model discussed above, which answers a question of M. Balcerzak and T. Filipczak [MLQ Math. Log. Q. 57 (2011), no. 2, 186–193; MR2816096].
   On the other hand, Balcerzak and Filipczak noticed that, if $\scr{I}$ is an ideal on $2^\omega$ with Borel basis and $\roman{add}(\scr{I})=\roman{cof}(\scr{I})$, then there exists a monotone Borel hull operation on $\scr{I}$. Nevertheless, it seems that this is the only situation where such an operation can be constructed. In contrast to this, the authors show, by a finite support iteration of (nice) suborders of amoeba forcing for category and amoeba forcing for measure, the consistency of the existence of monotone Borel hull operations on all $\scr{N}$, $\scr{M}$ and $\scr{N}\cap\scr{M}$ with $\roman{add}(\scr{N})=\roman{add}(\scr{M})<\roman{cof}(\scr{M})=\roman{cof}(\scr{N})$, the latter implying that neither $\scr{N}$ nor $\scr{M}$ is generated by a tower. This is done by forcing bases of type $\kappa\times\lambda$ (where $\kappa$ is the value intended for the additivities while $\lambda$ is intended for the cofinalities) for both ideals $\scr{N}$ and $\scr{M}$. A $\kappa\times\lambda$-base for an ideal $\scr{I}$ on $2^\omega$ is a Borel basis which is $\subseteq$-isomorphic to $\kappa\times\lambda$ ordered by $(\alpha_0,\beta_0)\leq(\alpha_1,\beta_1)$ iff $\alpha_0\leq\alpha_1$ and $\beta_0\leq\beta_1$. The authors prove that the existence of such a base implies $\roman{add}(\scr{I})=\min\{\roman{cf}(\kappa),\roman{cf}(\lambda)\}$, $\roman{cof}(\scr{I})=\max\{\roman{cf}(\kappa),\roman{cf}(\lambda)\}$ and the existence of a monotone Borel hull operation on $\scr{I}$.
Reviewed by Diego Alejandro Mejía

    References
  1. M. Balcerzak, T. Filipczak, On monotone hull operations. Math. Log. Q. 57, 186–193 (2011) MR2816096
  2. T. Bartoszyński, H. Judah, Set Theory: On the Structure of the Real Line (A K Peters, Wellesley, 1995) MR1350295
  3. T. Bartoszyński, M. Kada, Hechler's theorem for the meager ideal. Topol. Appl. 146(147), 429–435 (2005) MR2107162
  4. J. Brendle, S. Fuchino, Coloring ordinals by reals. Fundam. Math. 196, 151–195 (2007) MR2342625
  5. M.R. Burke, M. Kada, Hechler's theorem for the null ideal. Arch. Math. Log. 43, 703–722 (2004) MR2076412
  6. M. Elekes, K. Kunen, Transfinite sequences of continuous and Baire class 1 functions. Proc. Am. Math. Soc. 131, 2453–2457 (2003) MR1974643
  7. M. Elekes, A. Máthé, Can we assign the Borel hulls in a monotone way? Fundam. Math. 205, 105–115 (2009) MR2545447
  8. J. Kellner, S. Shelah, Decisive creatures and large continuum. J. Symb. Log. 74, 73–104 (2009). arXiv:math.LO/0601083 cf. MR2499421
  9. K. Kunen. Inaccessibility properties of cardinals. PhD thesis, Stanford University (1968). MR2617841
  10. H. Mildenberger, S. Shelah, Changing cardinal characteristics without changing $\omega$-sequences or cofinalities. Ann. Pure Appl. Log. 106, 207–261 (2000). arXiv:math.LO/9901096 cf. MR1785760
  11. A. Roslanowski, S. Shelah, Norms on possibilities I: forcing with trees and creatures. Mem. Am. Math. Soc. 141(671):xii + 167 (1999). arXiv:math.LO/9807172 cf. MR1613600
  12. A. Roslanowski, S. Shelah, Around cofin. Colloq. Math. 134, 211–225 (2014). arXiv:1304.5683. cf. MR3194406
  13. S. Shelah, Covering of the null ideal may have countable cofinality. Fundam. Math. 166, 109–136 (2000). arXiv:math.LO/9810181 cf. MR1804707
  14. S. Shelah, Was Sierpiński right? IV. J. Symb. Log. 65, 1031–1054 (2000). arXiv:math.LO/9712282 cf. MR1791363
  15. S. Shelah, The null ideal restricted to some non-null set may be $\germ{N}_{1}$-saturated. Fundam. Math. 179, 97–129 (2003). arXiv:math.LO/9705213 cf. MR2029228
  16. S. Shelah, S. Thomas. The cofinality spectrum of the infinite symmetric group. J. Symb. Log. 62, 902–916 (1997). arXiv:math.LO/9412230 cf. MR1472129
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 3

From Reviews: 1

MR3265314 Reviewed
Kaplan, Itay(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

A dependent theory with few indiscernibles. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 202 (2014), no. 1, 59–103.
03C45 (03C55 03E02)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-11-19 Review Published2015-12-07

Ramsey theory is closely connected to indiscernibles in model theory and the main theorem of this paper actually establishes the equivalence of a partition statement and a statement about indiscernibles in models. The partition statement is $\kappa\to(\delta)_\theta^{<\omega}$, which says that given $f\:[\kappa]^{<\omega}\to\theta$ there is a subset $A$ of $\kappa$ of order type $\delta$ such that $f$ is constant on $[A]^n$ for each $n$ (most likely with value depending on $n$). The statement on indiscernibles is written $\kappa\to(\delta)_{T,1}$ and it concerns a complete first-order theory $T$ with a given large saturated model $\frak{C}$ and states that whenever $A\subseteq\frak{C}$ has cardinality $\kappa$ there is a non-constant sequence $x$ of length $\delta$ in $A$ that is indiscernible: if $F$ and $G$ are finite subsets of $\delta$ of the same size then $\langle x_i:i\in F\rangle$ and $\langle x_i:i\in G\rangle$ realize the same types.
   Recall that a theory $T$ is dependent, or NIP, if it does not have the independence property. The main theorem now states that, given $\theta$, there is a dependent theory $T$ of cardinality $\theta$ such that for all $\kappa$ and all limit ordinals $\delta$, the statement $\kappa\to(\delta)_\theta^{<\omega}$ is equivalent to $\kappa\to(\delta)_{T,1}$.
Reviewed by Klaas Pieter Hart

    References
  1. M. Cohen and S. Shelah, Stable theories and representation over sets, 2009; arXiv:0906.3050. cf. MR3509699
  2. W. Hodges, Model Theory, Encyclopedia of Mathematics and its Applications, Vol. 42, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1993. MR1221741
  3. A. Kanamori, The Higher Infinite, second edition, Springer Monographs in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 2009. Large cardinals in set theory from their beginnings, Paperback reprint of the 2003 edition. MR2731169

  5. I. Kaplan and S. Shelah, Chain conditions in dependent groups, Annals of Pure and Applied Logic 164 (2013), 1322–1337. MR3093393
  6. K. Zh. Kudaĭbergenov, Independence property of first-order theories and indiscernible sequences, Matematicheskie Trudy 14 (2011), no. 1, 126–140. MR2858660
  7. S. Shelah, Around Classification Theory of Models, Lecture Notes in Mathematics, Vol. 1182, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 1986. MR0850051

Citations

From References: 3

From Reviews: 2

MR3265300 Reviewed
Farah, Ilijas(3-YORK-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, York University
Toronto, Ontario, M3J 1P3, Canada
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Trivial automorphisms. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 201 (2014), no. 2, 701–728.
03E35 (03E17 03E40 03E57 03G05 06E99)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-11-19 Review Published2015-05-20

Assume $\scr I,\scr J$ are ideals on $\omega$ and $\Phi\:\scr P(\omega)/\scr I\longrightarrow\scr P(\omega)/\scr J$ is a homomorphism of Boolean algebras. A function $F\:{\scr P}(\omega)\longrightarrow {\scr P}(\omega)$ is a representation of $\Phi$ if $[F(c)]_{\scr J}=\Phi([c]_{\scr I})$ for all $c\subseteq \omega$. The main result of the paper is the following theorem.
   Assume there exists a measurable cardinal. Then there is a forcing extension in which every isomorphism between quotient Boolean algebras ${\scr P}(\omega)/{\scr I}$ and ${\scr P}(\omega)/{\scr J}$ over Borel ideals has a continuous representation.
   The proof uses a countable support iteration of length $\aleph_2$. The iterands are either the random real forcing or forcings with norms, bigness and halving of the type ${\Bbb Q}^*_f(K,\Sigma)$ discussed in section 2.2 of [A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 141 (1999), no. 671, xii+167 pp.; MR1613600]. The arguments require careful analysis of continuous reading of names in iterations of this sort. The large cardinal assumption is used to ensure that some $\Pi^1_2$ sets in the extension have Baire-measurable uniformizations.
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3265284 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Pseudo PCF. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 201 (2014), no. 1, 185–231.
03E04 (03E25)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-12-11 Review Published2015-05-21

The author continues his investigation of pcf theory in the absence of the axiom of choice, and under the assumption of limited choice principles.
   The main aim is to analyze "pseudo true cofinality'' of $\prod_{t\in Y}\alpha_t,$ under the assumption of $AC_{P(Y)},$ where $\alpha_t$'s are regular cardinals, and for a quasi order $P$, the pseudo true cofinality of $P$ is defined to be a regular cardinal $\lambda$, such that there exists a sequence $(\scr{F}_\alpha: \alpha<\lambda)$ of subsets of $P$ such that:
(a)
$\alpha< \beta \rightarrow \scr{F}_\alpha \leq_P \scr{F}_\beta$ (i.e., $\forall p\in \scr{F}_\alpha$, $\forall q\in \scr{F}_\beta$, $p\leq_P q$),
(b)
$\bigcup_{\alpha<\lambda} \scr{F}_\alpha$ is cofinal in $P$,
(c)
$\lambda=\sup\{\alpha<\lambda: \scr{F}_\alpha \neq \emptyset\}.$

   In section 1, the canonical filter theorem is proved (under $AC_{P(Y)}$), which implies, under some mild conditions on $\lambda$, $\alpha_t$'s, $t\in Y$, the existence of a minimal $\aleph_1$-complete filter $D$ on $Y$ with $\lambda=\text{ps-tcf}\,(\prod_{t\in Y} \alpha_t, <_D).$ Then the existence of a generator $X \subseteq Y$ is proved such that $J_{\leq \lambda}^{\aleph_1\text{-comp}}=J_{< \lambda}^{\aleph_1\text{-comp}}+X.$ Also the no-hole theorem is proved under $DC+AC_Y.$
   In section 2 a composition theorem is proved which states under what conditions the equality $$ \text{ps-tcf}\Bigl(\prod_i\text{ps-tcf}\Bigl(\prod_j \lambda_{i,j}, <_{D_i}\Bigr), <_E\Bigr)=\text{ps-tcf}\Bigl(\prod_{i, j} \lambda_{i,j}, <_D\Bigr) $$ holds.
   In section 3, the author defines some ways for measuring the size of $\prod_{t\in Y}\alpha_t /D,$ where $\alpha_t$'s are non-zero ordinals, and shows that all of these ways are almost equal. The (pseudo ordinal) depth of a quasi order is defined and some results about the depth of $\prod_{t\in Y}\alpha_t /D$ are proved. Some of these results give more information about pcf theory even in $ZFC$. As a corollary of the results let us mention the following:
(1)
If $pp(\aleph_\omega)> \aleph_{\omega_1}$ and $\aleph_\omega$ divides $\delta$, where $cf(\delta)<\aleph_\omega$, $\delta<\aleph_\delta$, then $pp(\aleph_\delta)< \aleph_{|\delta|^+}$ (the same result holds if we replace $\aleph_\omega$ by any singular $\mu< \aleph_\mu$).
(2)
If $\delta_n < \lambda_n=\aleph_{\delta_n}$, $\delta_n < \delta_{n+1}$, and for all $n<\omega$, $cf(\delta_n)< \lambda_0$, then except at most one $n$, $pp(\aleph_{\lambda_n}) \geq \aleph_{\lambda_n^+}.$

   The author also gives some bounds on the depth of $\prod_{t\in Y}\alpha_t /D$, and hence on singulars of uncountable cofinality.
Reviewed by Mohammad Golshani

    References
  1. T. Jech, M. Magidor, W. Mitchell and K. Prikry, On precipitous ideals, Journal of Symbolic Logic 45 (1980), 1–8. MR0560220
  2. S. Shelah, Proper forcing, Lecture Notes in Mathematics, Vol. 940, Springer-Verlag, Berlin–New York, 1982. MR0675955
  3. S. Shelah, Cardinal Arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides, Vol. 29, Oxford University Press, 1994. MR1318912
  4. S. Shelah, The generalized continuum hypothesis revisited, Israel Journal of Mathematics 116 (2000), 285–321. MR1759410
  5. S. Shelah, Set theory without choice: not everything on cofinality is possible, Archive for Mathematical Logic 36 (1997), 81–125, A special volume dedicated to Prof. Azriel Levy. MR1462202
  6. S. Shelah, PCF and infinite free subsets in an algebra, Archive for Mathematical Logic 41 (2002), 321–359. MR1906504

  8. S. Shelah, PCF without choice, Archive for Mathematical Logic submitted, math.LO/0510229. cf. MR1462202
  9. S. Shelah, PCF arithmetic without and with choice, Israel Journal of Mathematics 191 (2012), 1–40. MR2970861
  10. S. Shelah, PCF with narrow choice or $ZF + DC + A{X_4}$, preprint.
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 0

MR3264251 Reviewed
Lücke, Philipp(D-BONN)
Mathematisches Institut, Rheinische Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität Bonn
D-53115 Bonn, Germany
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Free groups and automorphism groups of infinite structures. (English summary)
Forum Math. Sigma 2 (2014), e8, 18 pp.
03E75 (03E35 20E05 20F29)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-11-19 Review Published2015-08-14

The paper under review presents some new results on the following general question: Given an abstract group $G$ and an infinite cardinal $\lambda$, is $G$ the automorphism group of a $\lambda$-structure? (Here, a structure means an $\Cal{L}$-structure, where $\Cal{L}$ is a first-order language, and the prefix "$\lambda$-'' imposes some cardinality restrictions on it).
   After reviewing some known results, the paper focusses on the following particular case: Given an infinite cardinal $\lambda$, is there a $\lambda$-structure whose automorphism group is free of rank greater than $\lambda$? This question was first asked by D. Evans in the countable case, and was already answered in the negative by S. Shelah in this special case. In the paper under review, the authors extend this negative answer to singular strong limit cardinals of countable cofinality. However, they also provide another result in the opposite direction: For every cardinal $\lambda$ such that $\lambda =\lambda^{\aleph_0}$, there does exist a $\lambda$-structure whose automorphism group is free of rank $2^{\lambda}$. In particular, the free group of rank $2^{2^{\aleph_0}}$ is always the automorphism group of a certain $2^{\aleph_0}$-structure. Some other corollaries are also obtained.
Reviewed by Enric Ventura Capell

    References
  1. J. E. Baumgartner, "Applications of the proper forcing axiom', in Handbook of set-theoretic topology (North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1984), 913–959. MR0776640

  8. T. Jech, Set Theory, Springer Monographs in Mathematics (Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 2003), The third millennium edition, revised and expanded. MR1940513

  10. W. Just, S. Shelah and S. Thomas, `The automorphism tower problem revisited', Adv. Math. 148 (2) (1999), 243–265. MR1736959
  11. I. Kaplan and S. Shelah, `Automorphism towers and automorphism groups of fields without choice', in Groups and Model Theory, Contemp. Math, 576 (Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 2012), 187–203. MR2962885
  12. S. Mac Lane, Categories for the Working Mathematician, 2nd edn, Graduate Texts in Mathematics, 5 (Springer-Verlag, New York, 1998). MR1712872

  17. S. Shelah, `A countable structure does not have a free uncountable automorphism group', Bull. London Math. Soc. 35 (1) (2003), 1–7. MR1934424
  18. S. Shelah, Cardinal arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides, 29 (Oxford University Press, New York, 1994), Oxford Science Publications. MR1318912
  19. S. Solecki, `Polish group topologies', in Sets and Proofs Leeds, 1997, London Math. Soc. Lecture Note Ser., 258 (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1999), 339–364. MR1720580

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3226055 Reviewed
Greenberg, Noam(NZ-VCTR)
Department of Mathematics, Victoria University of Wellington
Wellington, New Zealand
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Models of Cohen measurability. (English summary)
Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 165 (2014), no. 10, 1557–1576.
03E35 (03E40 03E55)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-08-15 Review Published2015-05-18

A cardinal $\kappa$ is Cohen measurable if there is a $\kappa$-complete ideal $I$ on $\kappa$ such that $\scr P(\kappa) / I$ is isomorphic to a Cohen algebra. A Cohen algebra is the completion of a notion of forcing adding a certain amount of Cohen reals. The main theorem of the paper is that in a forcing extension of a model in which $\kappa$ is measurable and $2^\kappa = \kappa^+$, we have that $2^\omega = \kappa$ is Cohen measurable, and every function $f \: 2^\omega \to 2^\omega$ is continuous on a non-meagre set.
Reviewed by John Krueger

    References
  1. Sakae Fuchino, Noam Greenberg, Saharon Shelah, Models of real-valued measurability, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 142 (1–3) (2006) 380–397. MR2250550
  2. D.H. Fremlin, Real-valued-measurable cardinals, in: Set Theory of the Reals, Ramat Gan, 1991, in: Israel Math. Conf. Proc., vol. 6, Bar-Ilan Univ., Ramat Gan, 1993, pp. 151–304. MR1234282
  3. Moti Gitik, Saharon Shelah, More on real-valued measurable cardinals and forcing with ideals, Israel J. Math. 124 (2001) 221–242. MR1856516
  4. Saharon Shelah, Possibly every real function is continuous on a non-meagre set, Publ. Inst. Math. (Beograd) (N.S.) 57 (71) (1995) 47–60, Duro Kurepa memorial volume. MR1387353
  5. Robert M. Solovay, Real-valued measurable cardinals, in: Axiomatic Set Theory, Part I, Univ. California, Los Angeles, Calif., 1967, in: Proc. Sympos. Pure Math., vol. XIII, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, R.I., 1971, pp. 397–428. MR0290961
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 5

From Reviews: 0

MR3226014 Reviewed
Malliaris, M.(1-CHI)
Department of Mathematics, University of Chicago
Chicago, Illinois, 60637
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Model-theoretic properties of ultrafilters built by independent families of functions. (English summary)
J. Symb. Log. 79 (2014), no. 1, 103–134.
03C20 (03C45 03E05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-08-11 Review Published2016-04-28

This paper concerns the following question, stemming from Keisler's order on theories: given a structure $M$ and cardinal $\lambda$, which ultrafilters $\Cal{D}$ on $\lambda$ have the property that the ultraproduct $M^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated? By a result of Keisler (assuming for simplicity the language is countable, an assumption of the current paper), if $\Cal{D}$ is a regular ultrafilter then this property is preserved by elementary equivalence, and we say $\Cal{D}$ saturates ${\rm Th}(M)$.
   The paper builds on earlier work of the first author [J. Symbolic Logic 77 (2012), no. 1, 195–223; MR2951637], where the notion of flexible $\lambda$-filter was introduced. It also extends work of the authors, for example [Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 367 (2015), no. 11, 8139–8173; MR3391912]. In the latter paper, a dictionary was given translating properties of filters into model-theoretic properties of formulas, such that $\Cal{D}$ fails to have the ultrafilter property if and only if $M^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ omits every $\phi$-type where $\phi$ has the corresponding model-theoretic property. Along these lines, Malliaris showed in the former paper that if $T$ is nonlow (so in particular unstable) and $\Cal{D}$ is a $\lambda$-regular ultrafilter on $\lambda$ which is not $\lambda$-flexible, then $M^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ is not $\lambda^+$-saturated.
   Whereas the above paper of Malliaris and Shelah used constructions of ultrafilters via products of regular and complete ultrafilters, the present paper uses the method of independent families of functions, first introduced by Keisler in 1972. The main results are as follows.
   (a) Any ultrafilter $\Cal{D}$ on $\lambda$ which is $\lambda$-flexible must have $\mu(\Cal{D})=2^\lambda$, where $\mu(\Cal{D})$ is the minimum size, modulo $\Cal{D}$, of a product of an unbounded sequence of natural numbers. In particular, any $\lambda$-flexible ultrafilter saturates any stable theory.
   (b) If at some point in a construction by independent functions, the cardinality of the range of the remaining independent family is strictly smaller than the index set, then (essentially) no subsequent ultrafilter can be flexible.
   (c) A construction is given of a filter such that no subsequent ultrafilter can saturate the random graph, so, by the minimality of the theory of the random graph among unstable theories in Keisler's order, no subsequent ultrafilter can saturate any unstable theory.
   (d) Assuming the existence of a measurable cardinal $\kappa$, it is shown that for any $\lambda\geq \kappa^+$ there is a regular ultrafilter on $\lambda$ which is flexible but not good (a notion of Keisler from 1964). This improves a result in the above-mentioned paper of the authors, which answered a question from [A. S. Dow, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 290 (1985), no. 1, 145–160; MR0787959].
   (e) It is shown, assuming the existence of a weakly compact cardinal $\kappa$, that if $\aleph_0<\theta={\rm cf}(\theta)<\kappa\leq \lambda$, then there is a regular ultrafilter $\Cal{D}$ on $\lambda$ such that ${\rm lcf}(\aleph_0,\Cal{D})=\theta$ and $({\Bbb N},<)^\lambda/\Cal{D}$ has no $(\kappa,\kappa)$-cuts. (Here, ${\rm lcf}(\aleph_0,\Cal{D})$ is the coinitiality of $\omega$ in $(\omega,<)^\lambda/\Cal{D}$.) In particular, $\Cal{D}$ will not saturate any unstable theory. The curious aspect here, given that theories with the strict order property are maximal in Keisler's order, is that some families of cuts can be realised without saturating any unstable theory.
Reviewed by H. Dugald Macpherson

    References
  1. C. C. Chang and H. J. Keisler, \bf Model theory, North-Holland, New York, 1973. MR0409165
  2. A. Dow, Good and OK ultrafilters. Transactions of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 290 (1985), no. 1, pp. 145–160. MR0787959

Citations

From References: 7

From Reviews: 1

MR3224981 Reviewed
Kaplan, Itay(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Examples in dependent theories. (English summary)
J. Symb. Log. 79 (2014), no. 2, 585–619.
03C45 (03C64 03C95)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-08-15 Review Published2015-10-28

This paper in model theory gives examples of various phenomena in dependent (NIP) theories.
   Section 2 addresses an infinitary Ramsey-type statement. Namely, given a first-order theory $T$, cardinals $\kappa$ and $\lambda$ and an ordinal $\delta$, let $\kappa\to(\delta)_{T,\lambda}$ mean the following: for every set $A$ of $\lambda$-tuples in a model of $T$, if the size of $A$ is at least $\kappa$, then it contains a non-constant indiscernible sequence of length $\delta$ (recall that a sequence is called indiscernible if the type of any finite subsequence only depends on the ordering). It follows from classical results in infinitary combinatorics that for a general $T$, there are models of ZFC in which $\kappa\to(\omega)_{T,n}$ fails for all $\kappa$. On the other hand, from the early work of Morley and Shelah it is known that if $T$ is stable then $\lambda^{+}\to(\lambda^{+})_{T,n}$ for any $\lambda=\lambda^{|T|}$. In the intermediate case of a dependent $T$, it was conjectured in [S. Shelah, Around classification theory of models, Lecture Notes in Math., 1182, Springer, Berlin, 1986; MR0850051] that for every cardinal $\mu$ there is some $\lambda$ such that $\lambda\to(\mu)_{T,1}$. This conjecture was confirmed by Shelah in the special case of a strongly dependent theory [Israel J. Math. 204 (2014), no. 1, 1–83; MR3273451]; however, the paper at hand gives a negative solution in the general case. Specifically, it is demonstrated (Theorem 2.4) that there is a countable dependent theory $T$ such that if $\kappa$ is smaller than the first inaccessible cardinal, then for all $n\in\omega$, $\kappa\not\to(\omega)_{T,n}$. A subsequent paper by the same authors [Israel J. Math. 202 (2014), no. 1, 59–103; MR3265314] gives a stronger version of this theorem. In addition, Theorem 2.7 shows that even in the strongly dependent case, in fact already in RCF, the conjecture holds only for sequences of finite tuples.
   Section 3 gives an example of an elementary pair of dependent theories with a certain "genericity'' property which is not itself dependent (a similar result is implicit in [B. Poizat, J. Symbolic Logic 48 (1983), no. 2, 239–249; MR0704080]).
   Section 4 introduces the notion of directionality of a dependent theory. By Poizat's theorem, a theory $T$ is dependent if and only if the number of global coheirs of an arbitrary type $p\in S_{x}(M)$ is bounded by $2^{|M|+|x|}$, for all $M\models T$. Now $T$ has small directionality if the bound is actually $2^{|T|+|x|}$ (in particular does not depend on $M$), and $T$ has medium directionality if the bound is given by $|M|^{|T|+|x|}$ (Theorem 4.21). Some basic properties of this new notion are established, and it is demonstrated that RCF and many natural-valued fields, including ACVF and $p$-adics, have large directionality.
   Section 5 considers a new notion for special extensions of types called splintering, a variation of splitting. It is observed that splintering coincides with splitting in stable theories, that they can be different in a dependent theory of small directionality, and that they are always different in a theory of medium or large directionality. Section 6 (Appendix) gives bounds on the number of some special types in RCF that are needed for the directionality computation.
Reviewed by Artem Chernikov

    References

  2. James E. Baumgartner, Almost-disjoint sets, the dense set problem and the partition calculus. Annals of Mathematics, 9 (1976), no. 4, pp. 401–439. MR0401472

MR3219548 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Strüngmann, Lutz(D-DUES2M)
Universität Duisburg-Essen
D-45117 Essen, Germany

On the $p$-rank of ${\rm Ext}(A,B)$ for countable abelian groups $A$ and $B$. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 199 (2014), no. 2, 567–572.
20K35 (20K20)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-09-08 Review Published2014-12-05

Let $A$ and $B$ be abelian groups. The structure of the group of extensions ${\rm Ext}(A,B)$ has received much attention in the literature. If $A$ is torsion-free, then ${\rm Ext}(A,B)$ is divisible and hence determined up to isomorphism by its torsion-free rank and its $p$-rank for each prime $p$. In particular, complete characterisations are known in the case that $A$ is torsion-free and $B=\Bbb Z$.
   A well-known conjecture is that if $A$ is torsion-free and countable and $B$ is countable, then for every prime $p$, the $p$-rank of ${\rm Ext}(A,B)$ is either $\leq\aleph_0$ or $2^{\aleph_0}$. In this paper, the authors prove this conjecture. It is notable that the proof uses descriptive set theory in an essential way.
Reviewed by Phillip Schultz

    References
  1. P. C. Eklof and A. Mekler, Almost Free Modules, Set-Theoretic Methods (revised edition), North-Holland Mathematical Library, Vol. 65, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 2002. MR1914985
  2. S. Friedenberg, Extensions of Abelian Groups, Südwestdeutscher Verlag für Hochschulschrift, 2010.
  3. S. Friedenberg and L. Strüngmann, The structure of $\operatorname {Ext}(A,B)$ for countable abelian groups $A$ and $B$, Archiv der mathematik, 2013, to appear.
  4. L. Fuchs, Infinite Abelian Groups, Vols. I and II, Academic Press, New York, 1970 and 1973. MR0349869
  5. L. Harrington and S. Shelah, Counting equivalence classes for co-$\kappa $-Souslin relation, in Logic Colloquium '80 (Prague 1980), Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, Vol. 108, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1982, pp. 147–152. MR0673790
  6. S. Shelah, Can the fundamental (homotopy) group of a space be the rationals?, Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society 103 (1988), 627–632. MR0943095
  7. S. Shelah and L. Strüngmann, A characterization of $\operatorname{Ext} (G,\Bbb{Z})$ assuming $(V = L)$, Fundamenta Mathematicae 193 (2007), 141–151. MR2282712
  8. S. Shelah and L. Strüngmann, On the $p$-rank of $\operatorname{Ext} (G,\Bbb{Z})$ in certain models of ZFC, Algebra and Logic 46 (2007), 200–215.
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR3201820 Reviewed
Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Partition calculus and cardinal invariants. (English summary)
J. Math. Soc. Japan 66 (2014), no. 2, 425–434.
03E02 (03E04 03E05 03E17 03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-07-07 Review Published2015-05-04

The strong polarized relation ${\lambda\choose \kappa}\rightarrow {\lambda\choose \kappa}^{1,1}_2$ means that for every function $c\:\lambda\times\kappa\rightarrow 2$ there are $A\subseteq\lambda$ and $B\subseteq\kappa$ such that $|A|=\lambda$, $|B|=\kappa$, and $c\upharpoonright (A\times B)$ is constant. (See [A. Hajnal and J. A. Larson, in Handbook of set theory. Vol. 1, 129–213, Springer, Dordrecht, 2010; MR2768681] for more details.)
   Let $inv$ be a cardinal invariant of the continuum [see A. R. Blass, in Handbook of set theory. Vol. 1, 395–489, Springer, Dordrecht, 2010; MR2768685]. Since it was proved in [P. Erdős and R. Rado, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. 62 (1956), 427–489; MR0081864] that the continuum hypothesis implies ${\aleph_1\choose \omega}\nrightarrow {\aleph_1\choose \omega}^{1,1}_2$ and $inv=\aleph_1$ for every cardinal invariant under the continuum hypothesis, it is known that the negative relation ${inv\choose \omega}\nrightarrow {inv\choose \omega}^{1,1}_2$ is always consistent with ZFC. In the paper under review the authors search for positive results, trying to answer the question whether the relation ${inv\choose \omega}\to {inv\choose \omega}^{1,1}_2$ is consistent with ZFC.
   As a matter of fact, that is the case. Using the splitting and reaping numbers the authors obtain a model in which the relation ${\theta\choose \omega}\to {\theta\choose \omega}^{1,1}_2$ holds for every $\theta\in\left[\aleph_1,2^{\omega}\right]$. Later on, some generalizations of this result for uncountable cardinals are presented.
Reviewed by Jan Kraszewski

    References
