From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3194406 Reviewed
Rosłanowski, Andrzej(1-NEO)
Department of Mathematics, University of Nebraska
Omaha, Nebraska, 68182
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Around cofin. (English summary)
Colloq. Math. 134 (2014), no. 2, 211–225.
03E17 (03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-06-17 Review Published2014-08-14

Let $\scr{I}$ be a $\sigma$-ideal on a Polish space. The cardinal coefficient $\ssf{cofin}$ is defined as the minimal limit ordinal of a strictly increasing sequence of sub-$\sigma$-ideals of $\scr{I}$ whose union is $\scr{I}$. If $\scr{I}$ is non-principal, then this coefficient is well-defined and lies somewhere between the additivity of $\scr{I}$ and the cofinality of $\scr{I}$.
   The main theorem of the article answers the questions posed in [P. Borodulin-Nadzieja and S. Głąb, MLQ Math. Log. Q. 57 (2011), no. 6, 582–590; MR2853723]: Is $\ssf{cofin}(\scr{I}) = \ssf{add}(\scr{I})$ for every (nice) $\sigma$-ideal on a Polish space? It turns out that this is not the case. The authors define a $\sigma$-ideal $\scr{I}_f$ with a $G_\delta$ base (using the notion of null slaloms) and show that consistently the above coefficients differ in this case. (More precisely, $\ssf{add}(\scr{I}_f)=\omega_1$ and $\ssf{cofin}(\scr{I}_f)=\omega_2 = \germ{c}$). The model is produced by a finite-support iteration of ccc posets, which itself is forced too.
   The authors ask if there is a model in which $\ssf{add}(\scr{I})<\ssf{cofin}(\scr{I})$, where $\scr{I}\in \{\scr{N},\scr{M}\}$; $\scr{N}$ ($\scr{M}$) is the ideal of null (meager) subsets of the real line. They show that in the model obtained by adding $\kappa$ many Cohen reals $\ssf{add}(\scr{M}) = \ssf{cofin}(\scr{M})=\omega_1<\ssf{cof}(\scr{M})=\kappa=\germ{c}$ and in the model obtained by adding $\kappa$ many Random reals $\ssf{add}(\scr{N}) = \ssf{cofin}(\scr{N})=\omega_1<\ssf{cof}(\scr{N})=\kappa=\germ{c}$ (here, $\kappa$ is an uncountable regular cardinal).
Reviewed by Piotr Borodulin-Nadzieja

    References
  1. T. Bartoszyński and H. Judah, Set Theory. On the Structure of the Real Line, A K Peters, Wellesley, MA, 1995. MR1350295
  2. T. Bartoszyński and M. Kada, Hechler's theorem for the meager ideal, Topology Appl. 146/147 (2005), 429–435. MR2107162
  3. P. Borodulin-Nadzieja and S. Głąb, Ideals with bases of unbounded Borel complexity, Math. Logic Quart. 57 (2011), 582–590. MR2853723
  4. M. R. Burke and M. Kada, Hechler's theorem for the null ideal, Arch. Math. Logic 43 (2004), 703–722. MR2076412
  5. J. Cichoń and J. Pawlikowski, On ideals of subsets of the plane and on Cohen reals, J. Symbolic Logic 51 (1986), 560–569. MR0853839
  6. A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, Monotone hulls for $\scr{N} \cap \scr{M}$, Period. Math. Hungar., to appear; arXiv:1007.5368. cf. MR3269711
  7. S. Shelah, Whitehead groups may not be free, even assuming CH. II, Israel J. Math. 35 (1980), 257–285. MR0594332
  8. S. Shelah, Proper and Improper Forcing, Perspectives in Math. Logic, Springer, 1998. MR1623206
  9. E. K. van Douwen, J. D. Monk, and M. Rubin, Some questions about Boolean algebras, Algebra Universalis 11 (1980), 220–243. MR0588216
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 4

From Reviews: 1

MR3145742 Reviewed
Malliaris, M.(1-CHI)
Department of Mathematics, University of Chicago
Chicago, Illinois, 60637
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Regularity lemmas for stable graphs. (English summary)
Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 366 (2014), no. 3, 1551–1585.
05C75 (03C45 03C98)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-03-14 Review Published2016-10-21

In this paper, graphs are considered model-theoretically, that is, as structures $ G $ in a language with equality and a binary relation $ R $, whose domain consists of a set of vertices, and where the interpretation $ R_{G} $ is symmetric and irreflexive, and consists of all pairs of vertices $ ( a, b ) $ connected by an edge.
   Let $ A, B $ be disjoint subsets of a graph $ G $. Then $ d(A,B) = \frac{|R_{G} \cap (A \times B)|}{|A||B|} $ is the density of $ (A,B) $. Next, $ ( A, B ) $ is $ \epsilon $-regular (where $ \epsilon \in ( 0, 1 ) $) if $ |d(A,B) - d(A',B')| < \epsilon $ for all $ A' \subseteq A $, $ B' \subseteq B $ with $ |A'| \geq \epsilon|A| $, $ |B'| \geq \epsilon|B| $. Recall that by Szemerédi's Regularity Lemma we have that for a given $ \epsilon $, each sufficiently large graph $ G $ admits a partition $ G = X_{1} \cup \cdots \cup X_{l} $ such that $ ||X_{i}|-|X_{j}|| \leq 1 $ and almost all pairs $ ( X_{i}, X_{j} ) $ are $ \epsilon $-regular. It is known that the half-graph (i.e., the bipartite graph with vertex set $ \{ a_{i} : i < k \} \cup \{ b_{i} : i < k \} $ such that $ a_{i}\mathbin{R_{G}}b_{j} $ iff $ i < j $) shows that indeed not all pairs are $ \epsilon $-regular.
   A first-order theory $ T $ is stable iff no formula has the order property relative to $ T $, where a formula $ \varphi(x,y) $ has the order property relative to $ T $ if there exist a model $ M $ of $ T $ and sequences $ a_{0}, a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots $ and $ b_{0}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots $ from $ M $ such that $ M \models \varphi(a_{i},b_{j}) $ iff $ i < j $. Models for a stable theory of graphs have the non-$k$-order property for some natural $ k $, where a graph $ G $ has the non-$k$-order property if there is no $ a_{i}, b_{i} \in G $ for $ i < k $ such that $ a_{i} \mathbin{R_{G}} b_{j} $ and $ \neg a_{j} \mathbin{R_{G}} b_{i} $ for $ i< j < k $.
   Using a model-theoretic approach to graphs, the authors prove a much stronger version of the Regularity Lemma for models of stable theories of graphs (i.e., for graphs with the non-$k$-order property). As a consequence, they obtain that in the Regularity Lemma all pairs are $ \epsilon $-regular for graphs with the non-$k$-order property. Applying model theory to stable theories of graphs, the authors also prove three new Szemerédi-type partition theorems for graphs with the non-$k$-order property.
Reviewed by Konrad P. Pióro

    References

MR3129729 Reviewed
Mildenberger, Heike(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University

; Shelah, Saharon(D-FRBG-ML)
Abteilung für Mathematische Logik, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg

Many countable support iterations of proper forcings preserve Souslin trees. (English summary)
Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 165 (2014), no. 2, 573–608.
03E05 (03E17 03E35 03E40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-02-17 Review Published2014-08-29

The article is motivated by an old question of Juhász asking whether the club principle $\clubsuit$ implies the existence of a Suslin tree. There are results in the literature showing that $\clubsuit$ with some additional assumptions implies the existence of a Suslin tree, and one may be interested in the consistency of "$\clubsuit\,+$ there exists a Suslin tree'' with the negation of those extra assumptions.
   The authors present a method of building models of "${\rm ZFC}+ \,\clubsuit\, + $ there exists a Suslin tree'' by means of countable support iterations of forcing notions of the types described in [A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 141 (1999), no. 671, xii+167 pp.; MR1613600]. Since getting the principle $\clubsuit$ in such models was discussed in [H. Mildenberger, J. Symbolic Logic 76 (2011), no. 1, 34–46; MR2791336], the authors concentrate on preserving Suslin trees. They formulate several conditions on a forcing notion ${\Bbb P}$ implying that if $T$ is a Suslin tree, then $\Vdash_{\Bbb P}$ "$T$ is a Suslin tree'', and then they show that many forcing notions preserve Suslin trees. In the final section of the paper a detailed and self-contained proof of the preservation of a Suslin tree at limit stages of CS iterations is given (thus re-proving 3.9 Application in Chapter 18 of [S. Shelah, Proper and improper forcing, second edition, Perspect. Math. Logic, Springer, Berlin, 1998; MR1623206]).
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

    References

MR3118397 Reviewed
Goldstern, Martin(A-TUWN-DMG)

; Kellner, Jakob(A-WIEN-IL)
Kurt Gödel Research Center for Mathematical Logic (formerly Institut für Formalen Logik), Universität Wien

; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)

; Wohofsky, Wolfgang(A-TUWN-DMG)

1040 Vienna, Austria

Borel conjecture and dual Borel conjecture. (English summary)
Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 366 (2014), no. 1, 245–307.
03E35 (03E17 28E15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2014 Indexed 2014-02-17 Review Published2015-10-30

Let $\Cal{M}$ denote the $\sigma$-ideal of meager subsets of $2^\omega$, and $\Cal{N}$ denote the $\sigma$-ideal of null subsets of $2^\omega$, i.e. $\Cal{N}=\{A\subseteq 2^\omega: \lambda(A)=0\}$ where $\lambda$ is Lebesgue measure. A set $X\subseteq 2^\omega$ is called strongly null if for every sequence $(\varepsilon_n)_{n\in\omega}$ of positive reals, there is a sequence $(I_n)_{n\in\omega}$ of basic clopen sets such that $\lambda(I_n)<\varepsilon_n$ and $X\subseteq \bigcup_{n\in\omega} I_n$. The collection of all strongly null sets is denoted by $\Cal{SN}$.
   The Galvin-Mycielski-Solovay theorem gives us that $$ X\in\Cal{SN}\iff (\forall M\in\Cal{M})(\exists t\in 2^\omega)((t+X)\cap M=\emptyset). $$ By analogy, Prikry defined the collection of strongly meager sets $\Cal{SM}$: $$ X\in\Cal{SM}\iff (\forall N\in\Cal{N})(\exists t\in 2^\omega)((t+X)\cap N=\emptyset). $$
   Let us recall that the Borel Conjecture $BC$ is the statement $ \Cal{SN}=ctbl $, that a set is strongly null if and only if it is countable. The dual Borel Conjecture $dBC$ is the "dual'' statement that $ \Cal{SM}=ctbl$.
   It is known (Sierpiński, Laver) that $BC$ is independent from $ZFC$. Also (Prikry, Carlson) $dBC$ is independent from $ZFC$.
   The main result of the paper is the following statement:
   If $ZFC$ is consistent, then $ZFC+BC+dBC$ is consistent.
   The authors comment on methods given by Laver and Carlson to obtain a model of $BC$ ($dBC$ respectively). They introduce the family of ultra-Laver forcings and Janus forcing, and use almost finite support and almost countable support iterations. They also work with the more general class of ord-transitive models rather than transitive models as usual. (A model $M$ of a large enough fragment of set theory is called ord-transitive if it is "transitive outside the ordinals'', that is, if $x\in M\sbs \ssf{ORD}$, then $x\subset M$.)
Reviewed by Szymon Żeberski

    References
  1. Tomek Bartoszyński and Haim Judah. Set theory. A K Peters Ltd., Wellesley, MA, 1995. On the structure of the real line. MR1350295
  2. Andreas Blass. Selective ultrafilters and homogeneity. Ann. Pure Appl. Logic, 38(3):215– 255, 1988. MR0942525

MR3469119 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Dependent classes E72. (English summary) European Congress of Mathematics, 137–157, Eur. Math. Soc., Zürich, 2013.
03C45 (03-02)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2016-06-21 Review Published2016-10-14

The first "dividing line'' in classification theory separates "tractable'' (stable) from "intractable'' (unstable) theories. Afterwards, this line was pushed forward into the realm of unstable theories, separating "tame'' from "wild'' theories.
   This is the main idea behind the paper under review. It is directed to nonspecialists and points out some features of model theory which may be useful in other areas.
   The author describes informally the notion of dependent classes, which are classes of structures with tame behavior, in contrast with "chaotic'' classes (an example of the latter is the class of random graphs, that is, graphs such that for any disjoint pair of finite sets $A$ and $B$, there is a node $x$ connected to every member of $A$, but not connected to any member of $B$). The notion is made precise in Definition 2.1, stating that a class $\Cal{K}$ of models is independent (or not dependent) if and only if for some formula $\varphi(\bar x,\bar y)$ and some $M\in\Cal{K}$, considering the set $\varphi[M]$ of tuples satisfying $\varphi$ in $M$ as a bipartite graph, it has an induced random subgraph.
   For more details, the recent book by Pierre Simon [A guide to NIP theories, Lect. Notes Log., 44, Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, 2015] introduces the subject of dependent theories, also called NIP (since no formula has the independence property).

{For the collection containing this paper see MR3410185.} Reviewed by Ricardo Bianconi

Citations

From References: 3

From Reviews: 0

MR3164725 Reviewed
Dow, Alan(1-NC3-NDM)
University of North Carolina
Charlotte, North Carolina, 28213
; Shelah, Saharon(1-RTG)
Department of Mathematics, Rutgers University
Piscataway (New Brunswick), New Jersey, 08854

An Efimov space from Martin's axiom. (English summary)
Houston J. Math. 39 (2013), no. 4, 1423–1435.
54A20 (03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2014-04-11 Review Published2014-11-04

An Efimov space is an infinite compact space which contains no infinite convergent sequences and no homeomorphic copy of the Stone-Čech compactification of the integers. V. V. Fedorchuk constructed an Efimov space assuming the Continuum Hypothesis [Mat. Sb. (N.S.) 96(138) (1975), 41–62, 167; MR0362259], but it is not known if an Efimov space exists in ZFC. K. P. Hart asked [in Open problems in topology. II, 171–177, Elsevier B. V., Amsterdam, 2007; see MR2367385] if the existence of Efimov spaces is consistent with Martin's Axiom and the failure of the Continuum Hypothesis. The authors of the paper under review give a positive answer to this question by showing that the hypothesis $\germ{b}=\germ{c}$, which is a consequence of Martin's Axiom, implies the existence of Efimov spaces. The authors introduce a game in which if Player I has a winning strategy then there exists an Efimov space. They build a winning strategy for Player I assuming the hypothesis $\germ{b}=\germ{c}$.
Reviewed by Akira Iwasa

    References
  1. A. Dow, Efimov spaces and the splitting number. Spring Topology and Dynamical Systems Conference. Topology Proc. 29 (2005), no. 1, 105–113. MR2182920
  2. A. Dow, D.H. Fremlin, Compact sets without converging sequences in the random real model, Acta Math. Univ. Comenian. (N.S.) 76 (2007), no. 2, 161–171. 54A25 MR2385028
  3. V. V. Fedorčuk, A bicompactum whose infinite closed subsets are all $n$-dimensional, Mat. Sb. (N.S.) 96(138) (1975), 41–62, 167. MR 0362259 (50 #14701) MR0362259
  4. K.P. Hart, Efimov's problem, Open Problems in Topology II, (E. Pearl, ed.), Elsevier Science, 2007, pp. 171–177. MR2367385
  5. S. Koppelberg, Minimally generated Boolean algebras, Order 5 (1989), no. 4, 393–406. MR 90g:06022 MR1010388
  6. Sabine Koppelberg, Handbook of Boolean algebras. Vol. 1. North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1989. Edited by J. Donald Monk and Robert Bonnet. MR0991565
  7. Piotr Koszmider, Forcing minimal extensions of Boolean algebras. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 351(8):3073–3117, 1999. MR1467471
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 6

MR3116572 Reviewed
Malliaris, M.(1-CHI)
Department of Mathematics, University of Chicago
Chicago, Illinois, 60637
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

A dividing line within simple unstable theories. (English summary)
Adv. Math. 249 (2013), 250–288.
03C50 (03C20 03C45 03E05 05Cxx)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2014-01-21 Review Published2014-11-11

Summary: "We give the first (ZFC) dividing line in Keisler's order among the unstable theories, specifically among the simple unstable theories. That is, for any infinite cardinal $\lambda$ for which there is $\mu<\lambda\leq 2^\mu$, we construct a regular ultrafilter $\scr D$ on $\lambda$ so that (i) for any model $M$ of a stable theory or of the random graph, $M^\lambda/\scr D$ is $\lambda^+$-saturated but (ii) if $Th(N)$ is not simple or not low then $N^\lambda/\scr D$ is not $\lambda ^+$-saturated. The non-saturation result relies on the notion of flexible ultrafilters. To prove the saturation result we develop a property of a class of simple theories, called ${\rm Qr}_1$, generalizing the fact that whenever $B$ is a set of parameters in some sufficiently saturated model of the random graph, $|B|=\lambda$ and $\mu<\lambda\leq 2^\mu$, then there is a set $A$ with $|A|=\mu$ so that any nonalgebraic $p\in S(B)$ is finitely realized in $A$. In addition to giving information about simple unstable theories, our proof reframes the problem of saturation of ultrapowers in several key ways. We give a new characterization of good filters in terms of `excellence', a measure of the accuracy of the quotient Boolean algebra. We introduce and develop the notion of moral ultrafilters on Boolean algebras. We prove a so-called `separation of variables' result which shows how the problem of constructing ultrafilters to have a precise degree of saturation may be profitably separated into a more set-theoretic stage, building an excellent filter, followed by a more model-theoretic stage: building so-called moral ultrafilter on the quotient Boolean algebra, a process which highlights the complexity of certain patterns, arising from first-order formulas, in certain Boolean algebras.''

    References

Malliaris, Maryanthe(1-CHI)

General topology meets model theory, on $\germ p$ and $\germ t$. (English summary)
Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 110 (2013), no. 33, 13300–13305.
03C45 (03C20 03E17)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2014-01-16 Review Published2014-12-03

Summary: "G. Cantor proved in 1874 [J. Reine Angew. Math. 77 (1873), 258–263; JFM 06.0057.01] that the continuum is uncountable, and Hilbert's first problem asks whether it is the smallest uncountable cardinal. A program arose to study cardinal invariants of the continuum, which measure the size of the continuum in various ways. By K. Gödel [Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. U.S.A 25 (1939), 220–224; JFM 65.0185.02] and P. J. Cohen [Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 50 (1963), 1143–1148; MR0157890], Hilbert's first problem is independent of ZFC (Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the axiom of choice). Much work both before and since has been done on inequalities between these cardinal invariants, but some basic questions have remained open despite Cohen's introduction of forcing. The oldest and perhaps most famous of these is whether `${\germ p}=\germ t$,' which was proved in a special case by F. Rothberger [Fund. Math. 35 (1948), 29–46; MR0029958], building on F. Hausdorff [Fund. Math. 26 (1936), 241–255; JFM 62.0228.03]. In this paper we explain how our work on the structure of Keisler's order, a large-scale classification problem in model theory, led to the solution of this problem in ZFC as well as of an a priori unrelated open question in model theory.''

    References
  1. Morley M (1965) Categoricity in power. Trans Am Math Soc 114:514–538. MR0175782

MR3102967 Reviewed
Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Non-reflection of the bad set for $\check{I}_{\theta}[\lambda]$ and pcf. (English summary)
Acta Math. Hungar. 141 (2013), no. 1-2, 11–35.
03E04 (03E05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-12-17 Review Published2014-09-26

Suppose that $\theta<\lambda$ are regular cardinals. Let $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ be the restriction of the approachability ideal $I[\lambda]$ to the stationary set $S^{\lambda}_{\theta}=\{\delta<\lambda:\rm{cf}(\delta)=\theta\}$. The author [in Finite and infinite combinatorics in sets and logic (Banff, AB, 1991), 355–383, NATO Adv. Sci. Inst. Ser. C Math. Phys. Sci., 411, Kluwer Acad. Publ., Dordrecht, 1993; MR1261217] established that if $\theta^{+}<\lambda$, then $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ contains a stationary subset of $S^{\lambda}_{\theta}$. It is natural to ask how large stationary sets in $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ can be. For example, in [Arch. Math. Logic 31 (1991), no. 1, 25–53; MR1126352] the author showed that if $\lambda$ is the successor of a regular cardinal $\mu>\theta$, then $S^{\lambda}_{\theta}\in I_{\theta}[\lambda]$, i.e. $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ is an improper ideal.
   The first main result of the paper under review is that if $\theta<\theta^{+}<\kappa<\sigma<\lambda$ are all regular and uncountable, then $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ contains a stationary set $S\subset S^{\lambda}_{\theta}$ such that $\{\xi\in S^{\delta}_{\kappa}:S\cap\xi\ \text{is stationary in}\ \xi\}$ is stationary in $\delta$ for every $\delta\in S^{\lambda}_{\sigma}$.
   The second main result of this paper is concerned with the complements of the stationary sets in $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$. It is known to be consistent (relative to supercompactness) that GCH holds, in which case $I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ contains the largest set modulo the club filter, and the bad set, i.e. the complement of the largest set is stationary with $\theta=\omega_{1}$ and $\lambda=\omega_{\omega+1}$. However, the corresponding claim for $\theta=\omega_{n}$ $(n\ge2)$ and $\lambda=\omega_{\omega+1}$ is not known to be consistent.
   The following result of the author shows that even if the bad set (exists and) is stationary, it should not be so large: Suppose that $\theta<\lambda$ are regular and uncountable. If $2^{\theta^{+n}}<\lambda$ for every $n<\omega$, then there is a set $S\in I_{\theta}[\lambda]$ such that for every $n\ge2$ either $S_{n}=\{\delta\in S^{\lambda}_{\theta^{+n}}: (S^{\lambda}_{\theta}\sbs S)\cap\delta\ \text{is stationary in}\ \delta\}$ is non-stationary, or $S_{n}$ can be decomposed into $T_{\xi}$ $(\xi<2^{\theta^{+n}})$ so that $T_{\xi}\cap\delta$ is non-stationary in $\delta$ whenever $\xi<2^{\theta^{+n}}$ and $\theta^{+n+2}\le\rm{cf}(\delta)<\theta^{+\omega}$.
Reviewed by Masahiro Shioya

    References
  1. U. Abraham and M. Magidor, Cardinal arithmetic, in: M. Foreman and A. Kanamori (Eds.) Handbook of Set Theory, Vols. 1, 2, 3, Springer (Dordrecht, 2010), pp. 1149–1227. MR2768693

  14. S. Shelah, Vive la différence III, Israel J. Math., 166 (2008), 61–96 (ma.th.LO/ 0112237). MR2430425

Citations

From References: 6

From Reviews: 0

MR3100959 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-E)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics and Computer Science, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Pcf and abelian groups. (English summary)
Forum Math. 25 (2013), no. 5, 967–1038.
03E04 (03E75 20K20 20K30)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-12-10 Review Published2014-04-01

This paper deals with two major problems from Abelian group theory (and also with parallels in the more general context of $R$-modules). This is done through the typical way of employing set-theoretic methods in order to solve algebraic problems. The main focus here is on black box principles.
   Let us try to describe the algebraic problems:
$(\aleph)$
${\rm TDU}_\mu$ (for $\mu>\aleph_0$) is the assertion that there is a $\mu$-free Abelian group $G$ such that ${\rm Hom}(G,Z)=\{0\}$ (TDU stands for trivial dual).
$(\beth)$
${\rm TED}_\mu$ says that there is a $\mu$-free Abelian group $G$ such that ${\rm End}(G)\cong Z$ (TED stands for trivial endomorphism).

   The problems are whether these assertions hold for a given cardinal $\mu$, and the main effort in the current paper is the case of $\mu=\aleph_\omega$, hoping to get positive results in ZFC. The task is almost accomplished in the sense that a negative answer yields considerable restrictions on the pcf structure of the universe.
   The paper is arranged as follows. Section 0 provides the relevant background (especially the pertinent definitions). Section 1 develops several tools, culminating in the Black Box Trichotomy Theorem. This is a remarkable result, in ZFC, which seems fundamental far beyond its algebraic applications. Section 2 supplies prediction principles under the weak GCH (i.e., $\mu<\lambda\Rightarrow 2^\mu<2^\lambda$). This is done in the spirit (and the notation) of the middle diamond [S. Shelah, Arch. Math. Logic 44 (2005), no. 5, 527–560; MR2210145]. In Section 3, many black box instances are derived from existence theorems of free families. Finally, Section 4 deals with TDU for $R$-modules.
   In general, the paper is two-fold. One layer is mirrored in algebraic test problems in which the author (and to some extent, other mathematicians) made gradual progress over the years. The paper under review makes another step (although the overall problem is still open from the ZFC point of view). The second layer, and perhaps the more profound one, is reflected in the various black box principles proved along the way.
Reviewed by Shimon Garti

    References

MR3096314 Reviewed
Goldstern, Martin(A-TUWN-AL)
Institut für Algebra, Technische Universität Wien
1040 Vienna, Austria
; Pinsker, Michael(F-PARIS7-ELU)
Équipe de Logique, UFR de Mathématiques, Université de Paris VII (Denis Diderot)
75251 Paris, 05, France
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

A closed algebra with a non-Borel clone and an ideal with a Borel clone. (English summary)
Internat. J. Algebra Comput. 23 (2013), no. 5, 1115–1125.
08A40 (03E15 22A30 54H15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-12-05 Review Published2014-08-20

The collection $\scr{O}=\bigcup_{n\ge1}\scr{O}^{(n)}$ of all finitary functions on the set $\Bbb{N}$ of natural numbers has both an algebraic and a topological structure. As an algebraic structure, $\scr{O}$ is a clone, that is, a multisorted algebra with sorts $\scr{O}^{(n)}=\Bbb{N}^{\Bbb{N}^n}$ $(n\ge1)$ whose operations are compositions of functions and whose distinguished elements are the projection functions. As a topological structure, $\scr{O}$ is a Polish space homeomorphic to the Baire space, namely the sum of the Baire spaces $\scr{O}^{(n)}=\Bbb{N}^{\Bbb{N}^n}$ $(n\ge1)$ where $\Bbb{N}^{\Bbb{N}^n}$ is a product space obtained from $\Bbb{N}$ with the discrete topology. From the perspective of descriptive set theory, it is interesting to compare the descriptive complexity of a subclone of $\scr{O}$ to the descriptive complexity of a generating set or other set determining the clone.
   It is known that for a set $F\subseteq\scr{O}$ of functions that is Borel or analytic, the clone generated by $F$ is analytic. One of the main results of this paper is the first example of a Borel set $F\subseteq\scr{O}$ of functions such that the clone generated by $F$ is non-Borel. In fact, in the given example $F$ is a low complexity Borel set: a closed set of unary functions $\Bbb{N}\to\Bbb{N}$.
   The second main result of the paper concerns the clone $\scr{C}_{I_d}$ determined by the ideal $I_d$ that consists of all subsets of $\Bbb{N}$ of upper density $0$. A function $f\in\scr{O}^{(n)}$ is defined to be in $\scr{C}_{I_d}$ iff $f[A^n]\in I_d$ for all $A\in I_d$. The clone $\scr{C}_{I_d}$ has been expected to be complicated [see M. Beiglböck et al., Internat. J. Algebra Comput. 19 (2009), no. 3, 397–421; MR2522843] and high in the descriptive hierarchy. However, the second main result of this paper shows that $\scr{C}_{I_d}$ is Borel of low complexity; moreover, $\scr{C}_{I_d}$ is a precomplete clone.
   The results of this paper solve Problems N and E in [M. R. Goldstern and M. Pinsker, Algebra Universalis 59 (2008), no. 3-4, 365–403; MR2470587].
Reviewed by Ágnes Szendrei

    References
  1. M. Beiglböck, M. Goldstern, L. Heindorf and M. Pinsker, Clones from ideals, Int. J. Algebra Comput. 19(3) (2009) 397–421. MR2522843
  2. M. Bodirsky, H. Chen and M. Pinsker, The reducts of equality up to primitive positive interdefinability, J. Symbolic Logic 75(4) (2010) 1249–1292. MR2767967
  3. M. Bodirsky and M. Pinsker, Reducts of Ramsey structures, in Model Theoretic Methods in Finite Combinatorics, Contemporary Mathematics, Vol. 558 (American Mathematical Society, 2011), pp. 489–519. MR3418644
  4. M. Bodirsky and M. Pinsker, Schaefer's theorem for graphs, in Proc. Symp. Theory of Computing (STOC) (2011), pp. 655–664; preprint of the long version available at http://arXiv.org/abs/1011.2894. cf. MR2932016
  5. M. Bodirsky and M. Pinsker, Topological Birkhoff, to appear in Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. cf. MR3301873
  6. G. Czédli and L. Heindorf, A class of clones on countable sets arising from ideals, Studia Sci. Math. Hungar. 37 (2001) 419–427. MR1874694
  7. M. Goldstern, Analytic clones, preprint (2004), http://arXiv.org/abs/math/0404214.
  8. M. Goldstern and M. Pinsker, A survey of clones on infinite sets, Algebra Universalis, 59 (2008) 365–403. MR2470587
  9. A. Kechris, Classical Descriptive Set Theory, Graduate Texts in Mathematics, Vol. 156 (Springer, 1995). MR1321597
  10. Á. Szendrei, Clones in universal algebra, Séminaire de Mathématiques Supérieures. Les Presses de l'Université de Montréal (1986). MR0859550
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 5

MR3093393 Reviewed
Kaplan, Itay(D-MUNS-IM)
Mathematisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster
D-48149 Münster, Germany
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Chain conditions in dependent groups. (English summary)
Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 164 (2013), no. 12, 1322–1337.
03C45 (03C98)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-11-07 Review Published2014-06-02

In this paper, the authors analyze "chain conditions'' in type definable groups in dependent theories, focusing on what they call "Property A''. In order to state the results of the paper, we will fix the following context.
   Let $T$ be a theory and let $G$ be a type definable group in some model of $T$, type definable over some set $A$. Let $p(x,y)$ be a type such that $p(x,a)$ is a definable subgroup of $G$ and let $\langle a_i\rangle_{i\in I}$ be an $A$-indiscernible sequence of elements satisfying $(a/A)$. The authors prove in the paper that the following holds for theories of finite (bounded) dp-rank.
   Property A. There is some $n$ such that any finite intersection of groups of the form $p(x,a_i)$ is the intersection of $n$ of them.
   Studying when this property holds is justified in two ways. First, the definable analogue of this property (when types are replaced by definable sets) holds in all dependent theories. And second, if this property holds in a given theory $T$ then all the type definable fields of characteristic $p$ are Artin-Schreier closed (meaning that the map $x^p-x$ is surjective).
   The authors also study variations of Property A in different contexts. They show that Property A does not hold in all stable theories and give a weakening for a general dependent theory $T$: If $|I|\geq |T|^+$, then $$ \bigcap_{i\in I} p(x,a_i)= \bigcap_{i\in I,\, i\neq i_0} p(x,a_i) $$ for some $i_0\in I$.
   They also prove a much stronger statement than Property A for strongly$^2$-dependent theories, a context for which very few examples are known, namely, that any intersection of the $p(x,a_i)$ (not only finite intersections) is the intersection of $n$ of them for some $n\in \Bbb N$.
Reviewed by Alf Onshuus

    References
  1. Hans Adler, Strong theories, burden, and weight, preprint, 2007.
  2. Hans Adler, An introduction to theories without the independence property, Arch. Math. Logic (2013), in press.
  3. J.T. Baldwin, Jan Saxl, Logical stability in group theory, J. Austral. Math. Soc. Ser. A 21 (3) (1976) 267–276. MR0407151
  4. Itay Kaplan, Thomas Scanlon, Frank O. Wagner, Artin–Schreier extensions in nip and simple fields, Israel J. Math. 185 (2011) 141–153. MR2837131

  6. Serge Lang, Algebra, third ed., Grad. Texts in Math., vol. 211, Springer-Verlag, New York, 2002. MR1878556
  7. Bruno Poizat, Stable Groups, Math. Surveys Monogr., vol. 87, American Mathematical Society, Providence, RI, 2001, translated from the 1987 French original by Moses Gabriel Klein. MR1827833
  8. Saharon Shelah, On spectrum of $\kappa $-resplendent models, preprint, 363 in Shelah archive, arXiv:1105.3774. cf. MR2867976

From References: 0

MR3090811 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Large weight does not yield an irreducible base. (English summary)
Period. Math. Hungar. 66 (2013), no. 2, 131–137.
54E25
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-11-21 Review Published2014-03-18

A base $\scr{U}$ of a topological space $X$ is said to be irreducible if it can be decomposed as $\scr{U}=\bigcup\{\scr{U}_x:x\in X\}$ such that (i) each $\scr{U}_x$ is a neighborhood base at $x$ in $X$, (ii) for each $x\in X$, $\bigcup\{\scr{U}_y:y\in X, \,y\neq x\}$ is not a base of $X$. This notion was introduced by I. Juhász, L. Soukup and Z. Szentmiklóssy [Topology Appl. 57 (1994), no. 2-3, 271–285; MR1278028], who asked: Does every first countable space of uncountable weight contain an uncountable subspace which has an irreducible base? In this paper, the author shows that the answer to this question is consistently no. Every weakly separated space has an irreducible base.
Reviewed by Masami Sakai

    References
  1. I. Juhász, L. Soukup and Z. Szentmiklóssy, What makes a space have large weight?, Topology Appl., 57 (1994), 271–285. MR1278028
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Jerusalem 91904, Israel

More about $\lambda$-support iterations of $(<\lambda)$-complete forcing notions. (English summary)
Arch. Math. Logic 52 (2013), no. 5-6, 603–629.
03E40 (03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link

Summary: "This article continues A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah [Int. J. Math. Math. Sci. 28 (2001), no. 2, 63–82; MR1885053; in Set theory: recent trends and applications, 195–239, Quad. Mat., 17, Dept. Math., Seconda Univ. Napoli, Caserta, 2006; MR2374767; Israel J. Math. 159 (2007), 109–174; MR2342475; in Set theory and its applications, 287–330, Contemp. Math., 533, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 2011; MR2777755; Notre Dame J. Form. Log. 52 (2011), no. 2, 113–147; MR2794647] and we introduce here a new property of $(<\lambda)$-strategically complete forcing notions which implies that their $\lambda$-support iterations do not collapse $\lambda^+$ (for a strongly inaccessible cardinal $\lambda$).''

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3068953 Reviewed
Pinsker, Michael(F-PARIS7-ML)
Équipe de Logique Mathématique, Université de Paris VII (Denis Diderot)
75251 Paris, France
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Universality of the lattice of transformation monoids. (English summary)
Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 141 (2013), no. 9, 3005–3011.
06B15 (06B23 20M20)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-09-21 Review Published2014-11-07

The set of all transformation monoids on a fixed set of infinite cardinality $\lambda$, equipped with the order of inclusion, forms a complete algebraic lattice ${\rm Mon}(\lambda)$ with $2^{\lambda}$ compact elements. ${\rm Mon}(\lambda)$ is the subalgebra lattice of the algebra which has domain $\lambda^{\lambda}$, a binary operation which is the function composition on $\lambda^{\lambda}$, as well as a constant operation whose value is the identity function on $\lambda$. Any closed sublattice of ${\rm Mon}(\lambda)$ is algebraic and has at most $2^{\lambda}$ compact elements. The aim of this paper is to prove the converse of this fact, which had been stated as an open problem in [M. R. Goldstern and M. Pinsker, Algebra Universalis 59 (2008), no. 3-4, 365–403; MR2470587]. The main theorem of this paper is:
   Theorem 1.1. ${\rm Mon}(\lambda)$ is universal for complete algebraic lattices with at most $2^{\lambda}$ compact elements with respect to closed sublattices; i.e., the closed sublattices of ${\rm Mon}(\lambda)$ are, up to isomorphism, precisely the complete algebraic lattices with at most $2^{\lambda}$ compact elements.
Reviewed by Yan Hui Wang

    References
  1. [BF48] Garrett Birkhoff and Orrin Frink, Jr., Representations of lattices by sets, Transactions of the American Mathematical Society 64 (1948), 299–316. MR0027263
  2. [GP08] Martin Goldstern and Michael Pinsker, A survey of clones on infinite sets, Algebra Universalis 59 (2008), 365–403. MR2470587
  3. [Grä03] George Grätzer, General lattice theory, Birkhäuser Verlag, Basel, 2003, reprint of the 1998 second edition. MR2451139
  4. [Jec03] Thomas Jech, Set theory, Springer Monographs in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 2003. The third millennium edition, revised and expanded. MR1940513
  5. [Pin07] Michael Pinsker, Algebraic lattices are complete sublattices of the clone lattice on an infi-nite set, Fundamenta Mathematicae 195 (2007), no. 1, 1–10. MR2314073
  6. [Rep96] Vladimir B. Repnitskiĭ, On representation of lattices by lattices of subsemigroups, Rus-sian Mathematics 40 (1996), no. 1, 55–64 (translation of Russian original). MR1424151
  7. [Tům89] Jiří Tůma, Intervals in subgroup lattices of infinite groups, Journal of Algebra 125 (1989), no. 2, 367–399. MR1018952
  8. [Whi46] Philip M. Whitman, Lattices, equivalence relations and subgroups, Bulletin of the Amer-ican Mathematical Society 52 (1946), 507–522. MR0016750

MR3061483 Reviewed

On incompactness for chromatic number of graphs. (English summary)
Acta Math. Hungar. 139 (2013), no. 4, 363–371.
03E05 (05C15)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-09-03 Review Published2014-08-14

Summary: "We deal with incompactness. Assume the existence of non-reflecting stationary set of cofinality $\kappa$. We prove that one can define a graph $G$ whose chromatic number is $>\kappa$, while the chromatic number of every subgraph $G'\subseteqq G$, $|G'|<|G|$ is $\leqq \kappa$. The main case is $\kappa=\aleph_0$.''

    References
  1. P. Erdős and A. Hajnal, Solved and unsolved problems in set theory, in: L. Henkin (Ed.) Proc. of the Symp. in honor of Tarski's seventieth birthday in Berkeley 1971, Proc. Symp in Pure Math XXV (1974), pp. 269–287. MR0357122

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3061094 Reviewed
Goldstern, Martin(A-TUWN-DMG)
Institute of Discrete Mathematics and Geometry, Technische Universität Wien
1040 Vienna, Austria
; Sági, Gábor(H-AOS)
Alfréd Rényi Institute of Mathematics, Hungarian Academy of Sciences (MTA)
1364 Budapest, Hungary
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Very many clones above the unary clone. (English summary)
Algebra Universalis 69 (2013), no. 4, 387–399.
08A40 (05C25 05C65)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-08-29 Review Published2013-11-19

Let $ \germ{c} \coloneq 2^{\aleph_{0}} $. Let $ X $ be a set. An operation on $ X $ is a function $ f \colon X^{n} \longrightarrow X $, where $ n $ is some positive natural number which is called the arity of $ f $. Let $ \scr{O}^{(n)} = X^{X^{n}} $ be the set of all $ n $-ary operations on $ X $ and let $ \scr{O} = \bigcup_{n = 1}^{\infty} \scr{O}^{(n)} $.
   A subset $ C \subseteq \scr{O} $ is called a clone on $ X $ if it contains all projection functions and is closed under composition (i.e., if $ f \in \scr{O} $ is an $ n $-ary operation and $ g_{1}, g_{2}, \ldots, g_{n} \in \scr{O} $ are $ m $-ary operations for some $ m $, then $ f( g_{1}, g_{2}, \ldots, g_{n} ) \in \scr{O} $).
   For a clone $ C $, the set $ C^{(n)} = C \cap \scr{O}^{(n)} $ is called the $ n $-ary fragment of $ C $. Of course, the unary fragment $ C^{(1)} $ is a submonoid of the monoid $ X^{X} $ of all unary operations. For each submonoid $ M $ of $ X^{X} $, the set of all clones $ C $ such that $ C^{(1)} = M $ is called the monoidal interval of $ M $. This set has a least element, the clone generated by $ M $, and a greatest element, the set of all operations $ f $ such that if $ g_{1}, g_{2}, \ldots, g_{m} \in M $, then $ f( g_{1}, g_{2}, \ldots, g_{n} ) \in M $.
   The first main result of this paper shows that if $ X $ is a countable infinite set (e.g., $ X = \Bbb{N} $), then there are $ 2^{\germ{c}} $ clones on $ X $ containing the monoid $ X^{X} $. In other words, the monoidal interval on $ X^{X} $ has the largest possible size, because the cardinality $ \scr{O} $ equals $ \germ{c} = 2^{\aleph_{0}} $.
   In the second main result the authors prove that for each $ n \geq 1 $ and an arbitrary modest clone $ C $ on $ \Bbb{N} $ containing all $ n $-ary operations with range $ \{ 0, 1 \} $, there are $ 2^{\germ{c}} $ clones $ D $ having the same $ n $-ary fragment as $ C $. Here a clone is modest if each of its operations is modest, and an operation $ f \colon X^{n} \longrightarrow X $ is modest if there is a number $ a $ such that $ f(Y^{n}) $ has at most $ a|Y| $ elements for each finite $ Y \subseteq X $.
   Note that the first result is a particular case of the second, but its proof is easier (which does not mean easy). It should be also noted that proofs of these two results are complicated and use techniques from various branches of mathematics (e.g., graph, hypergraph and probability theories).
Reviewed by Konrad P. Pióro

    References
  1. Gavrilov, G.P.: On functional completeness in countably-valued logic. Problemy Kibernet. 15, 5–64 (1965) MR0229511
  2. Goldstern, M.: Analytic clones. http://arxiv.org/math.RA/0404214. (2004)
  3. Goldstern, M., Pinsker, M.: A survey of clones on infinite sets. Algebra Universalis 59, 365–403 (2008) MR2470587
  4. Goldstern, M., Shelah, S.: Clones on regular cardinals. Fund. Math. 173, 1–20 (2002) MR1899044
  5. Machida, H.: The clone space as a metric space. Acta Appl. Math. 52, 297–304 (1998) MR1656674
  6. Pinsker, M.: Monoidal intervals of clones on infinite sets. Discrete Math. 308, 59–70 (2008) MR2370522
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR3061090 Reviewed
Koszmider, Piotr(PL-PAN)
Institute of Mathematics, Polish Academy of Sciences
00-950 Warsaw, Poland
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Independent families in Boolean algebras with some separation properties. (English summary)
Algebra Universalis 69 (2013), no. 4, 305–312.
06E05 (03E05 46B10 54D30)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-08-29 Review Published2013-12-27

An independent family in a Boolean algebra $B$ is a set $A$ of elements such that for all pairs $\langle F,G\rangle$ of disjoint finite subsets of $A$ the element $\bigwedge F\wedge(\bigvee G)'$ is nonzero. Large independent families are of interest because of their consequences for objects dual to Boolean algebras. In particular if a Boolean algebra has an independent family of cardinality $\germ{c}$ then its Stone space $X$ has a continuous map onto the Tikhonov cube $[0,1]^\germ{c}$ and from this one deduces that $X$ contains a copy of $\beta\Bbb{N}$ and that $C(X)$ has $\ell_\infty$ as a quotient. The authors prove that a Boolean algebra has an independent family of cardinality $\germ{c}$ if it has the following property: for every countably infinite antichain $A$ there is $b\in B$ such that both $\{a\in A:a\le b\}$ and $\{a\in A:a\wedge b=0\}$ are infinite—termed the weak subsequential separation property.
   The paper ends with a discussion of the Grothendieck property in Banach spaces, which is related to the separation property and Efimov's problem that asks whether every compact space without convergent sequences contains a copy of $\beta\Bbb{N}$.
Reviewed by Klaas Pieter Hart

    References
  1. Brech, C.: On the density of Banach spaces $C(K)$ with the Grothendieck property. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 134, 3653–3663 (2006) MR2240680
  2. Diestel, J.: Sequences and Series in Banach Spaces. Graduate Texts in Mathematics, vol. 92. Springer, New York (1984) MR0737004
  3. Freniche, F.J.: The Vitali–Hahn–Saks theorem for Boolean algebras with the subsequential interpolation property. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 92, 362–366 (1984) MR0759653
  4. Hart, K.P.: Efimov's problem. In: Pearl, E. (ed.) Open Problems in Topology, vol. 2, pp. 171–177. Elsevier, Amsterdam (2007) MR2367385
  5. Haydon, R.: A nonreflexive Grothendieck space that does not contain ${\ell_\infty }$. Israel J. Math. 40, 65–73 (1981) MR0636907
  6. Haydon, R.: Boolean rings that are Baire spaces. Serdica Math. J. 27, 91–106 (2001) MR1879874
  7. Haydon, R., Odell, E., Levy, M.: On sequences without ${\roman{weak}}*$ convergent convex block subsequences. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 100, 94–98 (1987) MR0883407
  8. Koppelberg, S.: Handbook of Boolean Algebras, vol. 1. North-Holland, Amsterdam (1989) MR0991609
  9. Koszmider, P.: Banach spaces of continuous functions with few operators. Math. Ann. 330, 151–183 (2004) MR2091683
  10. Schachermeyer, W.: On some classical measure-theoretic theorems for non-sigma-complete Boolean algebras. Dissertationes Math. (Rozprawy Mat.) 214 (1982) MR0673286
  11. Semadeni, Z.: Banach spaces of continuous functions. Vol. I. Monografie Matematyczne, Tom 55. PWN—Polish Scientific Publishers, Warsaw (1971) MR0296671
  12. Talagrand, M.: Un nouveau $C(K)$ qui possède la propriété de Grothendieck. Israel J. Math. 37, 181–191 (1980) MR0599313
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3056773 Reviewed
Rosłanowski, Andrzej(1-NEO)
Department of Mathematics, University of Nebraska
Omaha, Nebraska, 68182
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Partition theorems from creatures and idempotent ultrafilters. (English summary)
Ann. Comb. 17 (2013), no. 2, 353–378.
03E05 (03E02 05D10 54A20)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-08-26 Review Published2013-12-03

The paper under review deals with finitary partition theorems which resemble Hindman's theorem. Hindman proved that if $\omega=\bigcup\{A_\ell:\ell<n\}$ then there exist $m<n$ and $B\in[A_m]^\omega$ such that $A_m$ is closed under finite sums of members of $B$ [see N. B. Hindman, J. Combinatorial Theory Ser. A 17 (1974), 1–11; MR0349574]. Several proofs are known, and the most elegant belongs to Glazer. (The proof appears in Section 10 of [W. W. Comfort, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. 83 (1977), no. 4, 417–455; MR0454893]; Glazer didn't publish the proof elsewhere.)
   Behind the proof stands a lemma which asserts that if $X$ is a (nonempty) compact topological space and $+$ is a binary operation on $X$, associative and right-continuous, then there exists $y\in X$ such that $y=y+y$. Glazer defined such an operation on $\beta\Bbb{N}$ which gives a (non-principal) ultrafilter $U$ on $\omega$ such that $U+U=U$. The ultrafilter $U$ satisfies the property designated in Hindman's theorem, so in every partition of $\omega$ into finitely many sets there is one piece which belongs to $U$.
   As Glazer himself indicated, the proof is flexible and might be adapted to other partition theorems of this kind. The authors of the present paper pursue more theorems based on the same proof. The combinatorial background comes from the notion of creature forcing, but in this paper only the combinatorial aspect of creatures is employed. They define associative and right-continuous operations which give (through Glazer's process) an appropriate idempotent ultrafilter (or a sequence of ultrafilters). This ultrafilter demonstrates a finitary partition theorem related to the special properties of sets in the ultrafilter.
   The paper is arranged as follows. After a general introduction (in Section 1), there is a survey of partial creatures (in Section 2). A comprehensive treatment of this subject (in the forcing atmosphere) can be found in the short monograph of A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah [Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 141 (1999), no. 671, xii+167 pp.; MR1613600]. The authors of the paper under review include all the relevant background material, adjusted to the needs of the current paper. Section 3 gives a partition theorem in the form described above (i.e., defining an operation $\oplus$ on the relevant compact space, and using an ultrafilter $D$ [essentially on $\omega$, practically on a countable set of functions] such that $D\oplus D=D$ in order to derive the combinatorial result).
   Section 4 develops similar ideas (using similar proofs), this time in the context of a sequence $\overline{D}$ of ultrafilters. Again, an appropriate operation $\circledast$ is defined, and the existence of a sequence $\overline{D}=\langle D_n:n\in\omega\rangle$ of ultrafilters such that $\overline{D}\circledast\overline{D}=\overline{D}$ is established. The result is the Carlson-Simpson theorem [T. J. Carlson and S. G. Simpson, Adv. in Math. 53 (1984), no. 3, 265–290; MR0753869], for which the authors can now produce a short and nice proof. In Section 5 the authors weaken the assumptions of Section 4 (hence also the corollary) and show that an interesting partition theorem can still be derived. Finally, Section 6 is a slight modification of Section 5 in which some other requirements are assumed (and Corollary 6.14 is the partition theorem which results).
   Entering into the combinatorial world of creatures requires some effort. But the complexity of the definitions which constitute the background for this article is eased by the clear and coherent exposition throughout the paper.
Reviewed by Shimon Garti

    References
  1. Bartoszyński, T., Judah, H.: Set Theory: On the Structure of the Real Line. A K Peters, Wellesley, MA (1995) MR1350295
  2. Carlson, T.J., Simpson, S.G.: A dual form of Ramsey's theorem. Adv. in Math. 53, 265–290 (1984) MR0753869
  3. Comfort, W.W.: Ultrafilters: some old and some new results. Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. 83, 417–455 (1977) MR0454893
  4. Goldstern, M., Shelah, S.: Ramsey ultrafilters and the reaping number—${\roman{Con}(\germ{r} < \germ{u})}$. Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 49(2), 121–142 (1990) MR1077075
  5. Hales, A.W., Jewett, R.I.: Regularity and positional games. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 106, 222–229 (1963) MR0143712
  6. Halpern, J.D., Läuchli, H.: A partition theorem. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 124, 360–367 (1966) MR0200172
  7. Kellner, J., Shelah, S.: Decisive creatures and large continuum. J. Symbolic Logic 74(1), 73–104 (2009) MR2499421
  8. Kellner, J., Shelah, S.: Creature forcing and large continuum: the joy of halving. Arch. Math. Logic 51, 49–70 (2012) MR2864397
  9. Pincus, D., Halpern, J.D.: Partitions of products. Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 267(2), 549–568 (1981) MR0626489
  10. Rosłanowski, A., Shelah, S.: Norms on possibilities I: forcing with trees and creatures. Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 141(671), (1999) MR1613600
  11. Rosłanowski, A., Shelah, S.: Measured creatures. Israel J. Math. 151, 61–110 (2006) MR2214118
  12. Rosłanowski, A., Shelah, S., Spinas, O.: Nonproper products. Bull. Lond. Math. Soc. 44(2), 299–310 (2012) MR2914608
  13. Shelah, S., Zapletal, J.: Ramsey theorems for product of finite sets with submeasures. Combinatorica 31(2), 225–244 (2011) MR2848252
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR3056300 Reviewed
Gitik, Moti(IL-TLAV)
School of Mathematical Sciences, Tel Aviv University
Ramat Aviv, Tel Aviv 69978, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Applications of pcf for mild large cardinals to elementary embeddings. (English summary)
Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 164 (2013), no. 9, 855–865.
03E55 (03E04 03E35 03E45)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-08-20 Review Published2014-05-27

The authors prove two new results in PCF Theory and, using them, analyze ultrapower maps by $\kappa$-complete ultrafilters over a measurable cardinal $\kappa$.
   New results in PCF Theory are the following: (1) Let $\kappa$ be a weakly compact cardinal and $\mu$ be a singular cardinal of cofinality $\kappa$ with $\mu > 2^\kappa$. Then for any regular $\lambda < \roman{pp}^+_{\Gamma ( \kappa )} ( \mu )$ there is an increasing sequence $\langle \lambda_i \mid i < \kappa \rangle$ of regular cardinals converging to $\mu$ such that $\lambda = \roman{tcf} ( \prod_{i < \kappa} \lambda_i , <^* )$. (2) Let $\mu$ be a strong limit cardinal and $\theta$ be a cardinal $> \mu$, and suppose that at least one of them has an uncountable cofinality. Then there is $\nu < \mu$ such that the following holds for any $\chi < \theta$: $$ \theta>\sup\{\sup \roman{pcf}_{\nu\text{-}\rm complete}(a) \mid a \subseteq \roman{Reg} \cap ( \mu^+ , \chi ) \wedge |a| < \mu \}. $$
   Using these results, the authors elucidate the behavior of ultrapower maps on cardinals: Suppose that $\kappa$ is a measurable cardinal and that $j \: V \to M$ is an ultrapower map by some $\kappa$-complete ultrafilter over $\kappa$. Let $\tau$ be a cardinal. Then $j( \tau ) > \tau$ if and only if either (i) $\kappa \leq \tau \leq 2^\kappa$, or (ii) there is a singular cardinal $\mu$ of cofinality $\kappa$ such that $2^\kappa < \mu \leq \tau$ and $\roman{pp}_{\Gamma ( \kappa )} ( \mu ) \geq \tau$. Moreover if $\tau$ satisfies (i), then $2^\kappa < j( \tau ) < ( 2^\kappa )^+$. If $\tau$ satisfies (ii), then, letting $\mu^*$ be the least $\mu$ as in (ii), it holds that $\roman{pp}_{\Gamma ( \kappa )} ( \mu^* ) < j( \tau ) < \roman{pp}_{\Gamma ( \kappa )} ( \mu^* )^+$.
   Several fundamental facts on ultrapower maps immediately follow from the above analysis. Let $\kappa$ and $j$ be as above. Then we have the following: (1) If $j( \tau )$ is a cardinal, then $j( \tau ) = \tau$. (2) $| j( \tau ) | = | j ( j ( \tau )) |$. (3) Suppose that $j'$ is an ultrapower map by another $\kappa$-complete ultrafilter over $\kappa$. Then $| j ( \tau ) | = | j' ( \tau ) |$.
Reviewed by Hiroshi Sakai

    References
  1. U. Abraham, M. Magidor, Cardinal arithmetic, in: M. Foreman, A. Kanamori (Eds.), Handbook of Set Theory, Springer, 2010, pp. 1149–1228. MR2768693
  2. M. Gitik, S. Shelah, More on simple forcing notions and forcing with ideals, Annals of Pure and Applied Logic 59 (1993) 219–238. MR1213273
  3. S. Shelah, Cardinal Arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides, vol. 29, Oxford Science Publications, 1994. MR1318912
  4. S. Shelah, Further cardinal arithmetic, 430, Israel Journal of Mathematics 95 (1996) 61–114. MR1418289
  5. S. Shelah, GCH revisited, 460, Israel Journal of Mathematics 116 (1998) 285–321. MR1759410
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Göbel, Rüdiger(D-DUES2)

Hochschule Mannheim (Mannheim University of Applied Sciences)
68163 Mannheim, Germany

$\aleph_n$-free modules over complete discrete valuation domains with almost trivial dual. (English summary)
Glasg. Math. J. 55 (2013), no. 2, 369–380.
13F30 (13C99 20K99)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-07-30 Review Published2013-11-20

The main result of the paper is as follows: If $n$ denotes a positive natural number and $R$ denotes a (commutative) complete discrete valuation domain, then there exist proper classes of $R$-modules, as follows: (i) class $\scr M_n$ of torsion-free $\aleph_n$-free modules such that $\bigoplus_{\Bbb N} R$ is not an epi image of any $M\in \scr M_n$; and (ii) class $\scr N_n$ of torsion, $\aleph_n$-$\Sigma$-cyclic modules with the property that no epi image of any $N\in\scr N_n$ is of the form $\bigoplus_{i\in\Bbb N}R/p^iR$. It is also shown that modules in $\scr M_n$ are almost indecomposable and those in $\scr N_n$ are essentially indecomposable. Boundaries of the cardinalities of modules in these classes are also given. The proofs require utilization of a variant of Shelah's prediction principle.
Reviewed by Radoslav Dimitrić

    References
  1. A. L. S. Corner, Every countable reduced torsion-free ring is an endomorphism ring, Proc. Lond. Math. Soc. 13(3) (1963), 687–710. MR0153743

MR3040670 Reviewed
Hall, Eric J.(1-MOKC-MS)
Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Missouri

; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Partial choice functions for families of finite sets. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 220 (2013), no. 3, 207–216.
03E25
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-07-30 Review Published2014-03-05

The main result of this paper is that in Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory without the axiom of choice, the assertion "every countable set of $m$-element sets has an infinite partial choice function'' does not imply "every countable set of $m$-element sets has a choice function''. This turns out to be a rather difficult result. As the authors point out, the models which might be expected to show this independence fail to do so. The actual model constructed in the paper is a permutation model of set theory with atoms where the atoms have the structure of a vector space over a finite field. The argument that partial choice for countable families of $m$-element sets holds in the model uses a combination of permutation model and forcing arguments and is especially beautiful. By the transfer results of D. Pincus [J. Symbolic Logic 37 (1972), 721–743; MR0337605], constructing a model of set theory with atoms is sufficient for the independence in Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory without atoms.
Reviewed by Paul E. Howard

    References
  1. O. De la Cruz, E. J. Hall, P. Howard, K. Keremedis, and J. E. Rubin, Unions and the axiom of choice, Math. Logic Quart. 54 (2008), 652–665. MR2472471
  2. P. Howard and J. E. Rubin, Consequences of the Axiom of Choice, Math. Surveys Monogr. 59, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 1998 (see also http://consequences.emich.edu/). MR1637107
  3. T. J. Jech, The Axiom of Choice, Stud. Logic Found. Math. 75, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1973. MR0396271
  4. D. Pincus, Zermelo–Fraenkel consistency results by Fraenkel–Mostowski methods, J. Symbolic Logic 37 (1972), 721–743. MR0337605
  5. S. Shelah, Can the fundamental (homotopy) group of a space be the rationals?, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 103 (1988), 627–632. MR0943095

MR3001542 Reviewed
Jarden, Adi(IL-AU-CM)

Non-forking frames in abstract elementary classes. (English summary)
Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 164 (2013), no. 3, 135–191.
03C48 (03C35 03C45 03C52)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2013 Indexed 2013-04-04 Review Published2014-03-21

Summary: "The stability theory of first order theories was initiated by Saharon Shelah in 1969. The classification of abstract elementary classes was initiated by Shelah, too. In several papers, he introduced non-forking relations. Later, Shelah [Classification theory for abstract elementary classes. Vol. 2, Stud. Log. (Lond.), 20, Coll. Publ., London, 2009; MR2649290] introduced the good non-forking frame, an axiomatization of the non-forking notion.
   "We improve results of Shelah on good non-forking frames, mainly by weakening the stability hypothesis in several important theorems, replacing it by the almost $\lambda$-stability hypothesis: The number of types over a model of cardinality $\lambda$ is at most $\lambda^+$.
   "We present conditions on $K_\lambda$, that imply the existence of a model in $K_{\lambda^{+n}}$ for all $n$. We do this by providing sufficiently strong conditions on $K_\lambda$, that they are inherited by a properly chosen subclass of $K_{\lambda^+}$. What are these conditions? We assume that there is a `non-forking' relation which satisfies the properties of the non-forking relation on superstable first order theories. Note that here we deal with models of a fixed cardinality, $\lambda$.
   "While in [op. cit.] we assume stability in $\lambda$, so we can use brimmed (= limit) models, here we assume almost stability only, but we add an assumption: The conjugation property.
   "In the context of elementary classes, the superstability assumption gives the existence of types with well-defined dimension and the $\omega$-stability assumption gives the existence and uniqueness of models prime over sets. In our context, the local character assumption is an analog to superstability and the density of the class of uniqueness triples with respect to the relation $\preccurlyeq_{bs}$ is the analog to $\omega$-stability.''
Reviewed by Enrique Casanovas

MR3028765 Reviewed
Eklof, Paul C.(1-CA3)
Department of Mathematics, University of California
Irvine, California, 92664
; Fuchs, László(1-TULN)

Test groups for Whitehead groups. (English summary)
Rocky Mountain J. Math. 42 (2012), no. 6, 1863–1873.
20K20 (03E35 20A15 20K35 20K40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2013-06-05 Review Published2013-11-21

Since the solution of the well-known Whitehead problem in abelian group theory by the third author, Whitehead groups and their generalizations have been considered and investigated in a long list of substantial papers. Recall that a Whitehead group is an abelian group $A$ such that ${\rm Ext}_{\Bbb{Z}}(A,\Bbb{Z})=0$. It is a natural question to ask about the existence of other groups different from $\Bbb{Z}$ that can decide the Whitehead property. These are called Whitehead test groups. Obviously, the separable groups are such groups since they have $\Bbb{Z}$ as a summand. However, it is not true that Whitehead groups always have vanishing ${\rm Ext}$-functors with all separable groups. The present authors are therefore interested in the class of dual groups—a subclass of the class of separable groups. Recall that a dual group is a group of the form ${\rm Ext}_{\Bbb{Z}}(G,\Bbb{Z})$. It is shown that in any model of ZFC the following two properties are equivalent:
$\bullet$
the tensor product of any two Whitehead groups is again a Whitehead group;
$\bullet$
every dual group of a Whitehead group is a Whitehead test group.
The authors then investigate models of ZFC in which the two equivalent conditions above fail, and models in which they hold. Finally, they investigate what happens under Martin's axiom.
Reviewed by Lutz Struengmann

    References
  1. T. Becker, L. Fuchs and S. Shelah, Whitehead modules over domains, Forum Math. 1 (1989), 53–68. MR0978975
  2. H. Cartan and S. Eilenberg, Homological algebra, Princeton University Press, Princeton, 1956. MR0077480
  3. P.C. Eklof, Whitehead's problem is undecidable, Amer. Math. Month. 83 (1976), 775–788. MR0476511
  4. P.C. Eklof, Set theoretic methods in homological algebra and abelian groups, Les Presses de L'Université de Montréal, Montreal, 1980. MR0565449
  5. P.C. Eklof and A.H. Mekler, Almost free modules, revised edition, NorthHolland, Amsterdam, 2002. MR1914985
  6. P.C. Eklof and S. Shelah, The structure of Ext $(A,Z)$ and GCH: Possible coMoore spaces, Math. Z. 239 (2002), 143–157. MR1879333
  7. L. Fuchs, Infinite Abelian groups, vols. I and II, Academic Press, New York, 1970, 1973. MR0349869
  8. M. Huber, On reflexive modules and abelian groups, J. Algebra 82 (1983), 469–487. MR0704765
  9. S. Shelah, Infinite abelian groups, Whitehead problem and some constructions, Israel J. Math. 18 (1974), 243–256. MR0357114
  10. S. Shelah, Whitehead groups may not be free even assuming CH, II, Israel J. Math. 35 (1980), 257–285. MR0594332
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR3011486 Reviewed

Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University

Many partition relations below density. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 191 (2012), no. 2, 507–543.
03E02 (03E35 54A25)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2013-04-18 Review Published2014-03-10

Summary: "We force $2^\lambda$ to be large, and for many pairs in the interval $(\lambda,2^\lambda)$ a strong version of the polarized partition relations holds. We apply this to problems in general topology. For example, consistently, every $2^\lambda$ is the successor of a singular and for every Hausdorff regular space $X$, ${\rm hd}(X) \leq s(X)^{+3}$, ${\rm hL}(X) \leq s(X)^{+3}$ and better when $s(X)$ is regular, via a half-graph partition relations. For the case $s(X)=\aleph_0$ we get ${\rm hd}(X), {\rm hL}(X) \leq \aleph_2$.''

    References

MR3000439 Reviewed
Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)

91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Combinatorial aspects of the splitting number. (English summary)
Ann. Comb. 16 (2012), no. 4, 709–717.
03E02 (03E40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2013-04-05 Review Published2014-04-08

Summary: "This paper deals with the splitting number $\germ s$ and polarized partition relations. In the first section we define the notion of strong splitting families, and prove that its existence is equivalent to the failure of the polarized relation $\binom{\germ s}\omega \rightarrow\binom{\germ s}\omega^{1,1}_2$. We show that the existence of a strong splitting family is consistent with ZFC, and that the strong splitting number equals the splitting number, when it exists. Consequently, we can put some restriction on the possibility that $\germ s$ is singular. In the second section we deal with the polarized relation under the weak diamond, and we prove that the strong polarized relation $\binom{2^\omega} \omega\rightarrow\binom{2^\omega}\omega^{1,1}_2$ is consistent with ZFC, even when ${\rm cf}(2^\omega)=\boldsymbol\aleph_1$ (hence the weak diamond holds).''

    References

  2. Erdős, P., Hajnal, A., Rado, R.: Partition relations for cardinal numbers. Acta Math. Acad. Sci. Hungar. 16, 93–196 (1965) MR0202613

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 0

MR2992547 Reviewed
Garti, S.(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, S.(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

The ultrafilter number for singular cardinals. (English summary)
Acta Math. Hungar. 137 (2012), no. 4, 296–301.
03E05 (03E04 03E55)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2013-03-06 Review Published2013-05-13

In what follows, we assume the reader is familiar with the standard notions of: filter (and ultrafilter) over a cardinal; finite intersection property; and filter base. A family $\scr{F}$ of infinite sets, all of them with the same cardinality, is said to satisfy the strong finite intersection property (s.f.i.p., for short) if it satisfies the finite intersection property but with the additional condition that the size of the finite intersections is the size of the sets in $\scr{F}$.
   An ultrafilter $\scr{U}$ over an infinite cardinal $\lambda$ is said to be uniform if every member of $\scr{U}$ has size $\lambda$. The necessity of the s.f.i.p. for filter bases of uniform ultrafilters is clear. In the paper under review, the authors investigate, given an infinite cardinal $\lambda$, the following cardinal invariant, which they refer to as the ultrafilter number: $$ \germ{u}_\lambda = \{|\scr{F}|:\,\,\scr{F}\,\,\text{is a filter base for some uniform ultrafilter on}\,\,\lambda\}. $$
   As is probably expected within the theory of cardinal invariants, $\germ{u}_\lambda > \lambda$ for every infinite cardinal $\lambda$. The main result of the paper is the consistency (modulo supercompact cardinals) of "large $2^\lambda$ and small $\germ{u}_\lambda$" for singular cardinals $\lambda$, meaning that if one assumes the existence of a supercompact cardinal in the ground model then it is possible to force the existence of a singular cardinal $\lambda$ with $\germ{u}_\lambda = \lambda^+$ and $2^\lambda$ arbitrarily large. The forcing machinery for establishing the result includes a combination of Prikry and Magidor forcings, together with tools from pcf theory. As the authors themselves remark, it is quite natural to handle successors of singulars by employing methods of this theory.
Reviewed by Samuel Gomes da Silva

    References
  1. U. Abraham and M. Magidor, Cardinal arithmetic, in: Handbook of Set Theory. Vols. 1, 2, 3, Springer (Dordrecht, 2010), pp. 1149–1227. MR 2768693 MR2768693
  2. A. Blass, Combinatorial cardinal characteristics of the continuum, in: Handbook of Set Theory. Vols. 1, 2, 3, Springer (Dordrecht, 2010), pp. 395–489. MR 2768685 MR2768685
  3. M. R. Burke and M. Magidor, Shelah's pcf theory and its applications, Ann. Pure Appl. Logic, 50 (1990), 207–254. MR 1086455 (92f:03053) MR1086455
  4. S. Garti and S. Shelah, A strong polarized relation, The Journal of Symbolic Logic (accepted). cf. MR2987137
  5. M. Gitik, Prikry-type forcings, in: Handbook of Set Theory. Vols. 1, 2, 3, Springer (Dordrecht, 2010), pp. 1351–1447. MR 2768695 MR2768695
  6. S. Shelah, Cardinal Arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides 29, The Clarendon Press Oxford University Press (New York, 1994), Oxford Science Publications. MR 1318912 (96e:03001) MR1318912
  7. S. Shelah, The character spectrum of $\beta({\Bbb {N}})$, Topology Appl., 158 (2011), 2535–2555. MR2847327

Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)

A strong polarized relation. (English summary)
J. Symbolic Logic 77 (2012), no. 3, 766–776.
03E05 (03E55)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2013-02-06 Review Published2013-04-26

Summary: "We prove that the strong polarized relation $\left(\smallmatrix \mu^+\\ \mu\endsmallmatrix\right)\rightarrow\left(\smallmatrix \mu^+\\\mu\endsmallmatrix\right)^{1,1}_2$ is consistent with ZFC, for a singular $\mu$ which is a limit of measurable cardinals.''
Reviewed by J. M. Henle

PCF arithmetic without and with choice. (English summary)
Israel J. Math. 191 (2012), no. 1, 1–40.
03E04 (03E25 03E50)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link

Summary: "We deal with relatives of GCH which are provable. In particular, we deal with rank version of the revised GCH. Our motivation was to find such results when only weak versions of the axiom of choice are assumed, but some of the results give us additional information even in ZFC. We also start to deal with pcf for pseudo-cofinality (in ZFC with little choice).''

    References

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 0

MR2965281 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Universality among graphs omitting a complete bipartite graph. (English summary)
Combinatorica 32 (2012), no. 3, 325–362.
05C63 (03E04 03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2013-01-08 Review Published2013-05-20

If ${\scr F}$ is a class of graphs, we call a graph $X\in {\scr F}$ weakly (strongly) universal if each $Y\in{\scr F}$ weakly (strongly) embeds into $X$ where weak embedding means edge preserving and strong embedding means edge and non-edge preserving. In [J. Combin. Theory Ser. B 63 (1995), no. 1, 125–135; MR1309360] the author and the reviewer completely described under GCH when a weakly/strongly universal $K_\kappa$-free graph of cardinality $\lambda$ exists. A further direction was initiated by J. Pach and the reviewer in [Mathematika 31 (1984), no. 2, 282–290 (1985); MR0804203], where they proved that $\diamondsuit$ implies the nonexistence of a weakly universal $K_{\aleph_0,\aleph_1}$-free graph of cardinality $\aleph_1$. In this paper a large number of results on the existence of weakly/strongly universal $K_{\theta,\kappa}$-free graphs of cardinality $\lambda$ are presented where $\kappa\leq\theta\leq\lambda$ are infinite cardinals. These results suffice to give a full answer under GCH.
Reviewed by Péter Komjáth

    References
  1. P. Erdös and A. Hajnal: Solved and Unsolved Problems in set theory, in: Proc. of the Symp. in honor of Tarksi's seventieth birthday in Berkeley 1971 (Leon Henkin, ed.), Proc. Symp in Pure Math., vol. XXV, 1974, pp. 269–287. MR0357122
  2. P. Komjáth and J. Pach: Universal graphs without large bipartite subgraphs, Mathematika 31 (1984), 282–290. MR0804203
  3. O. Shafir: Two cases when $d_{\kappa}$ and $d_{\kappa}^{\ast}$ are equal, Fundamenta Mathematicae 167 (2001), 17–21. MR1816815
  4. S. Shelah: Non-structure theory, vol. accepted, Oxford University Press.
  5. S. Shelah: Notes on combinatorial set theory, Israel Journal of Mathematics 14 (1973), 262–277 MR0327522
  6. S. Shelah: Abstract elementary asses near $\aleph_{1}$, Chapter I. 0705.4137.
  7. S. Shelah: On successors of singular cardinals, Logic Colloquium '78 (Mons, 1978), Stud. Logic Foundations Math, vol. 97, North-Holland, Amsterdam-New York, 1979, pp. 357–380. MR0567680
  8. S. Shelah: Universal classes, Classification theory (Chicago, IL, 1985), Lecture Notes in Mathematics, vol. 1292, Springer, Berlin, 1987, Proceedings of the USA-Israel Conference on Classification Theory, Chicago, December 1985; ed. Baldwin, J.T., pp. 264–418. MR1033033
  9. S. Shelah: Black Boxes,, 0812.0656. 0812.0656. 0812.0656.
  10. S. Shelah: The Generalized Continuum Hypothesis revisited, Israel Journal of Mathematics 116 (2000), 285–321, math.LO/9809200. MR1759410
  11. P. Komjáth and S. Shelah: Universal graphs without large cliques, Journal of Combinatorial Theory. Ser. B 63 (1995), 125–135. MR1309360
  12. S. Shelah: More on the Revised GCH and the Black Box, Annals of Pure and Applied Logic 140 (2006), 133–160, math.LO/0406482. MR2224056
  13. S. Shelah: Many partition relations below density, Israel Journal of Mathematics submitted, 0902.0440. cf. MR3011486
