Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 0

MR2963031 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Simon, Pierre(F-ENS-DAM)
Département de Mathématiques et Applications (DMA), École Normale Supérieure
75230 Paris, France

Adding linear orders. (English summary)
J. Symbolic Logic 77 (2012), no. 2, 717–725.
03C45 (06A05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-10-04 Review Published2013-04-26

The authors address the interesting question of when a theory without the independence property can be expanded by a linear order of the universe so that the expansion continues not to have the independence property. They note first that if a NIP theory satisfies ${\rm acl}(A) =A$ for all $A$, then there is a linearly ordered expansion with NIP. In contrast, they show there is a totally categorical theory with NIP such that every expansion to a linearly ordered structure has the independence property. By a more complicated construction, they show that there is an $\omega$-stable, depth 2, NDOP theory such that every expansion to a linearly ordered structure has NIP (indeed, interprets pseudo-finite arithmetic).
Reviewed by John T. Baldwin

    References
  1. John Baldwin and Michael Benedikt, Stability theory, permutations of indiscernibles, and embedded finite models, Transactions of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 352 (2000), no. 11, pp. 4937–4969. MR1776884
  2. Artem Chernikov and Pierre Simon, Externally definable sets and dependent pairs, submitted, Modnet preprint 265. cf. MR3047077
  3. R. Graham, B. Rothschild, and J.H. Spencer, \it Ramsey theory, 2nd ed., New York: John Wiley and Sons, 1990. MR1044995
  4. Wassily Hoeffding, Probability inequalities for sums of bounded random variables, Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 58 (1963), no. 301, pp. 13–30. MR0144363
  5. James H. Schmerl, Decidability and ${\aleph _0}$-categoricity of theories of partially ordered sets, this Journal, vol. 45 (1980), no. 3, pp. 585–611. MR0583376
  6. Akito Tsuboi, Random amalgamation of simple theories, Mathematical Logic Quarterly, vol. 47 (2001), no. 1, pp. 45–50. MR1808945
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 1

MR2962893 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Modules and infinitary logics. (English summary) Groups and model theory, 305–316,
Contemp. Math., 576, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 2012.
03C60 (03C10 03C45 03C75 16B70)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-11-08 Review Published2013-04-29

The paper considers the model theory of modules over a given ring $R$ in the framework of an infinitary logic $L_{\lambda, \theta}$. It is proved that they admit elimination of quantifiers up to positive existential formulas. On this basis several stability properties are also shown.

{For the collection containing this paper see MR2961370.} Reviewed by Carlo Toffalori

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 1

MR2962885 Reviewed
Kaplan, Itay(D-MUNS-NDM)
Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster
D-48149 Münster, Germany
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-NDM)
Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

Automorphism towers and automorphism groups of fields without choice. (English summary) Groups and model theory, 187–203,
Contemp. Math., 576, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 2012.
20A15 (03E25)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-11-08 Review Published2013-04-22

For a centerless group $G$, one can consider its automorphism tower. Although the paper under review hardly mentions automorphism towers, it is the main motivation for it, and the paper can be viewed as a continuation without the axiom of choice of an article by the same authors [Arch. Math. Logic 48 (2009), no. 8, 799–815; MR2563819] that dealt with the automorphism tower. Here they deal with the inequality ${{\tau}^{\rm nlg}_{\kappa}} \leq {{\tau}_{\kappa}}$ without the axiom of choice and introduce a new proof of a theorem of Fried and Kollár stating that any group can be represented as the automorphism group of a field. The proof uses a simple construction, working more in graph theory and less in algebra.

{For the collection containing this paper see MR2961370.} Reviewed by Eric Jaligot

Citations

From References: 4

From Reviews: 0

MR2950191 Reviewed
Baldwin, John T.(1-ILCC-MS)
Department of Mathematics, Statistics and Computer Science, University of Illinois
Chicago, Illinois, 60680
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel

The stability spectrum for classes of atomic models. (English summary)
J. Math. Log. 12 (2012), no. 1, 1250001, 19 pp.
03C45 (03C75)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-11-21 Review Published2013-02-21

A subset $A$ of a model of a complete first-order theory $T$ is called atomic if the type of every tuple in $A$ over $\emptyset$ is principal. Let $\boldsymbol{K}=\boldsymbol{K}_T$ be the class of atomic models of $T$. For $M\in\boldsymbol{K}$, let $S^n_{\rm mod}(M)$ be the set of complete $n$-types over $M$ realized in atomic elementary extensions of $M$, and $S^n_{\rm at}(M)$ the set of complete $n$-types $p$ over $M$ such that $M\boldsymbol{a}$ is atomic for any realization $\boldsymbol{a}$ of $p$ in an elementary extension of $M$. For $i$ equal to $\rm at$ or $\rm mod$, $\boldsymbol{K}$ is called $i$-stable in a cardinal $\lambda$ if $|S^n_i(M)|=\lambda$ for every $n <\omega$ and $M\in\boldsymbol{K}$ with $|M| =\lambda$.
   The authors prove that if $\boldsymbol{K}$ is "sufficiently $i$-unstable'' in certain cardinals then $\boldsymbol{K}$ is $i$-unstable in any cardinal. Let $\tau=|T|$, and the ordinal $\delta=\delta(T)$ be the well-ordering number of the class of models of $T$ omitting a family of types, defined in [S. Shelah, Classification theory and the number of nonisomorphic models, Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, 92, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1978; MR0513226 (Chapter VII.5)]. It is shown that if there exists $M\in\boldsymbol{K}$ with $$ |S_i^n(M)|>|M|=\beth_\delta(\tau) $$ then $\boldsymbol{K}$ is $i$-unstable in any $\lambda\ge\tau$. Actually, a slightly stronger result is proven: If for any $\alpha<\delta$ there is $M\in\boldsymbol{K}$ with $$ |S_i^n(M)|>|M|^{\beth_\alpha(\tau)} $$ then for any $\lambda\ge\tau$ there exists $M\in\boldsymbol{K}$ with $$ |S_i^n(M)|>|M|=\lambda. $$ Another result sheds some light on the stability spectrum in the $i$-stable but not $i$-superstable case: If for any $\alpha<\delta$ there is $M\in\boldsymbol{K}$ with $$ |S_i^n(M)|>|M|\ge\beth_\alpha(\tau) $$ then $\boldsymbol{K}$ is $i$-unstable in any $\lambda$ with $\lambda^{\aleph_0}>\lambda\ge\tau$.
   The atomic models are exactly the models that omit all non-principal types; the authors claim that in fact the results above hold not only for $\boldsymbol{K}$ but also for an arbitrary finite diagram of $T$, the class of models of $T$ that omit a given set of types over $\emptyset$. It is known that the study of atomic models is equivalent to studying complete sentences in $L_{\omega_1\omega}$, and the study of finite diagrams is equivalent to studying sentences in $L_{\omega_1\omega}$. Therefore the authors interpret the results of the paper as results on the stability spectrum for $L_{\omega_1\omega}$.
Reviewed by O. V. Belegradek

    References
  1. J. Baldwin, Diverse classes, J. Symb. Log. 54 (1989) 875–893. MR1011176
  2. J. T. Baldwin, Categoricity, University Lecture Notes, Vol. 51 (American Mathematical Society, 2009); www.math.uic.edu/$\sim$jbaldwin. MR2532039
  3. C. C. Chang and H. J Keisler, Model Theory (North-Holland, 1973; 3rd edn., 1990). MR0409165
  4. M. Džamonja and S. Shelah, On $\triangleleft^{\ast}$-maximality, Ann. Pure Appl. Log. 125 (2004) 119–158. MR2033421
  5. R. Grossberg and O. Lessmann, Shelah's stability spectrum and homogeneity spectrum in finite diagrams, Arch. Math. Log. 41 (2002) 1–31. MR1883106
  6. R. Grossberg and S. Shelah, A non-structure theorem for an infinitary theory which has the unsuperstablity property, Illinois J. Math. 30 (1986) 364–390. MR0840135
  7. W. Hodges, What is a structure theory? Bull. London Math. Soc. 19 (1987) 209–237. MR0879509
  8. W. Hodges, Model Theory (Cambridge University Press, 1993). MR1221741
  9. H. J. Keisler, Model Theory for Infinitary Logic (North-Holland, 1971). MR0491155
  10. H. J. Keisler, Six classes of theories, J. Australian Math. Soc. Ser. A 25 (1976) 257–266. MR0409168

  13. D. Marker, Model Theory: An Introduction (Springer-Verlag, 2002). MR1924282
  14. G. Mills and J. Paris, Regularity in models of arithmetic, J. Symb. Log. 49 (1984) 272–280. MR0736621
  15. M. Morley, Categoricity in power, Trans. Ameri. Math. Soc. 114 (1965) 514–538. MR0175782
  16. M. Morley, Omitting classes of elements, in editors, The Theory of Models, eds. J. W. Addison et al. (North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1965), pp. 265–273. MR0201305
  17. L. Scow, Characterization of NIP theories by random graph ordered indiscernibles, to appear.
  18. S. Shelah, Finite diagrams stable in power, Ann. Math. Log. 2 (1970) 69–118. MR0285374
  19. S. Shelah, Categoricity of uncountable theories, in Proc Tarski Symp., Proceedings of Symposia in Pure Mathematics, Vol. 25 (American Mathematical Society, 1974), pp. 187–203. MR0373874
  20. S. Shelah, A two-cardinal theorem, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 48 (1975) 207–213. MR0357105
  21. S. Shelah, A two-cardinal theorem and a combinatorial theorem, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 62 (1976) 134–136. MR0434800
  22. S. Shelah, Classification Theory and the Number of Non-Isomorphic Models (North-Holland, 1978). MR0513226
  23. S. Shelah, Classification theory for nonelementary classes. I. the number of uncountable models of $\psi\in L_{\omega_{1}\omega}$ part A, Israel J. Math. 46(3) (1983) 212–240. MR0733351
  24. S. Shelah, Classification theory for nonelementary classes. I. the number of uncountable models of $\psi\in L_{\omega_{1}\omega}$ part B, Israel J. Math. 46(3) (1983) 241–271. MR0730343
  25. S. Shelah, Classification Theory and the Number of Non-Isomorphic Models (North-Holland, 1990). MR1083551

This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 6

From Reviews: 0

MR2927607 Reviewed
Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Strong polarized relations for the continuum. (English summary)
Ann. Comb. 16 (2012), no. 2, 271–276.
03E02 (03E05 03E35 03E55)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-10-25 Review Published2013-09-26

This paper deals with the strong polarized relation $\left(\smallmatrix \alpha\\\beta \endsmallmatrix\right)\to \left(\smallmatrix \alpha\\\beta \endsmallmatrix\right)^{1,1}_\theta$ for ordinals $\alpha$, $\beta$ and $\theta$, which states that for any coloring $c\:\alpha \times \beta \to \theta$ there are $A \subseteq \alpha$ of order type $\alpha$ and $B \subseteq \beta$ of order type $\beta$ such that the restriction of $c$ to $A \times B$ is constant. In particular, the authors prove the consistency of the strong polarized relations of the form $\left(\smallmatrix 2^\kappa\\\kappa \endsmallmatrix\right)\to \left(\smallmatrix 2^\kappa\\\kappa \endsmallmatrix\right)^{1,1}_\theta$.
   First they prove the consistency of the statement that $\left(\smallmatrix 2^\omega\\\omega \endsmallmatrix\right)\to \left(\smallmatrix 2^\omega\\\omega \endsmallmatrix\right)^{1,1}_n$ holds for all natural numbers $n$. Generalizing their technique to higher cardinals, they also prove that if $\kappa$ is Laver-indestructibly supercompact, then there exists a cofinality-preserving forcing extension in which $\left(\smallmatrix 2^\kappa\\\kappa \endsmallmatrix\right)\to\left(\smallmatrix 2^\kappa\\\kappa \endsmallmatrix\right)^{1,1}_\theta$ holds for every $\theta < \kappa$.
   It is also shown that if $\mu$ is a cardinal less than the splitting number $\germ{s}$ and has an uncountable cofinality, then $\left(\smallmatrix \mu\\\omega \endsmallmatrix\right)\to\left(\smallmatrix \mu\\\omega \endsmallmatrix\right)^{1,1}_2$ holds.
Reviewed by Hiroshi Sakai

    References
  1. Erdős, P., Hajnal, A., Rado, R.: Partition relations for cardinal numbers. Acta Math. Acad. Sci. Hungar. 16, 93–196 (1965) MR0202613
  2. Erdős, P., Rado, R.: A partition calculus in set theory. Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. 62, 427–489 (1956) MR0081864
  3. Garti, S., Shelah, S.: A strong polarized relation. J. Symbolic Logic (to appear) cf. MR2987137
  4. Laver, R.: Partition relations for uncountable cardinals $\leq 2^{\aleph 0}$. In: Hajnal, A. et al (eds.) Infinite and Finite Sets, Vol. II, pp. 1029–1042. North- Holland, Amsterdam (1975) MR0371652
  5. Laver, R.: Making the supercompactness of $\kappa$ indestructible under $\kappa$-directed closed forcing, Israel J. Math. 29(4), 385–388 (1978) MR0472529
  6. Shelah, S.: A weak generalization of MA to higher cardinals. Israel J. Math. 30(4), 297–306 (1978) MR0505492
  7. Williams, N.H.: Combinatorial Set Theory. North-Holland publishing company, New York (1977) MR3075383
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 1

From Reviews: 1

MR2924249 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

When a first order $T$ has limit models. (English summary)
Colloq. Math. 126 (2012), no. 2, 187–204.
03C45 (03C50 03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-09-28 Review Published2012-11-15

A universal model $M$ of a complete first-order theory $T$ with $|M|=\lambda$ is called a superlimit if, for any continuous elementary chain $\langle M_\alpha:\alpha<\delta\rangle$ with $\delta<\lambda^+$, if $M_\alpha\simeq M$ for all $\alpha<\delta$ then $\bigcup_{\alpha<\delta}M_\delta\simeq M$. The author studies the question of when $T$ has superlimit models (and some of their relatives) of cardinality $\lambda$, where $\lambda\ge |T|$.
   It is easy to see that if $T$ and $M$ are countable then $M$ is a superlimit iff $M$ is saturated. Being universal, every superlimit model of $T$ is of cardinality at least $|D(T)|$, where $D(T)$ is the set of complete types of $T$ over $\emptyset$. The author observes that his classical basic results on stability imply that if $T$ is superstable and $\lambda\ge |D(T)|, 2^{\aleph_0}$ then $T$ has a saturated model of cardinality $\lambda$ which is a superlimit. Here the condition $\lambda\ge 2^{\aleph_0}$ is not fully necessary for the existence of a superlimit model in $\lambda$: he shows that it is consistent with $\aleph_1<2^{\aleph_0}$ that the (superstable non-$\aleph_0$-stable) theory of the structure $(^\omega 2, E_n)_{n<\omega}$, where $\eta E_n\nu$ iff $\eta\upharpoonright n =\nu\upharpoonright n$, has a superlimit non-saturated model of cardinality $\aleph_1$.
   It is proven in the paper that an unstable theory $T$ cannot have superlimit models in uncountable $\lambda\ge |T|$. For a non-superstable $T$ the author shows non-existence of superlimit models in all uncountable $\lambda\ge |T|$ except for $\lambda<\beth_\omega$ with $\lambda<\lambda^{\aleph_0}$; in the exceptional cases the problem remains open. Also he proves that it is consistent with $\aleph_1<2^{\aleph_0}$ that the (stable non-superstable) theory of the structure $(^\omega\omega_{1}, E_n)_{n<\omega}$, where $\eta E_n\nu$ iff $\eta\upharpoonright n =\nu\upharpoonright n$, has a non-saturated model of cardinality $\aleph_1$ which is a limit in a certain sense, weaker that superlimitness.
Reviewed by O. V. Belegradek

    References
  1. M. Džamonja, Club guessing and the universal models, Notre Dame J. Formal Logic 46 (2005), 283–300. MR2160658
  2. M. Kojman and S. Shelah, Non-existence of universal orders in many cardinals, J. Symbolic Logic 57 (1992), 875–891; math.LO/9209201. MR1187454
  3. S. Shelah, Abstract elementary classes near $\aleph_1 $, Chapter of [19]I; math.LO/0705.4137.
  4. S. Shelah, Dependent dreams: recounting types, Ann. of Math., submittedof [19]; math.LO/1202. 5795.
  5. S. Shelah, Dependent $T$ and existence of limit models, Tbilisi Math. J., submitted; math.LO/0609636. cf. MR3313049
  6. S. Shelah, Dependent theories and the generic pair conjecture, Comm. Contemp. Math., submitted; math.LO/0702292. cf. MR3291978
  7. S. Shelah, General non-structure theory and constructing from linear orders, [Sh:E59]; math.LO/1011.3576.

Citations

From References: 2

From Reviews: 0

MR2916079 Reviewed
Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(1-RTG)
Department of Mathematics, Rutgers University
Piscataway (New Brunswick), New Jersey, 08854

$(\kappa,\theta)$-weak normality. (English summary)
J. Math. Soc. Japan 64 (2012), no. 2, 549–559.
03E04 (03E05 03G05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-09-21 Review Published2013-01-22

Given two cardinals $\kappa$ and $\theta$ and a function $g \: \kappa \to \theta$, a function $f \: \kappa \to \theta$ is $(\kappa,g)$-regressive if $f(i) < g(i)$ for all $i < \kappa$. An ultrafilter $D$ on $\kappa$ is $(\kappa,g)$-weakly normal if for all $j < \theta$, the set $\{ i < \kappa : g(i) > j \}$ belongs to $D$ while for all $(\kappa,g)$-regressive $f$, there is $j_f < \theta$ such that $\{ i < \kappa : f(i) < j_f \}$ belongs to $D$. $D$ is $(\kappa,\theta)$-weakly normal if $D$ is $(\kappa,g)$-weakly normal for some $g \: \kappa \to \theta$. There are no $(\kappa, \aleph_0)$-weakly normal ultrafilters. Given a sequence of cardinals $\overline\lambda = (\lambda_i \: i < \kappa)$, its $D$-limit $\lim_D (\overline \lambda)$ is the unique cardinal $\lambda$ such that $\{ i < \kappa : \beta < \lambda_i \leq \lambda \}$ belongs to $D$ for all $\beta < \lambda$. For the ultraproduct $\prod_{i < \kappa} \lambda_i / D$ one always has $|\prod_{i<\kappa} \lambda_i /D| \geq \lim_D (\overline \lambda)$.
   The authors establish a close connection between weakly normal ultrafilters and smallness of the ultraproduct. Assume $\aleph_0 < \roman{cf} (\lambda) = \theta \leq \kappa < \lambda$, $|\alpha|^\kappa < \lambda$ for $\alpha < \lambda$, and $D$ is an ultrafilter on $\kappa$. Then $D$ is $(\kappa,\theta)$-weakly normal iff there is a sequence of cardinals $\overline\lambda = (\lambda_i \: i < \kappa)$ smaller than $\lambda$ such that $|\prod_{i<\kappa} \lambda_i /D| = \lim_D (\overline \lambda) = \lambda$.
   The authors also discuss an application to depth in Boolean algebras.
Reviewed by Jörg D. Brendle

    References
  1. C. C. Chang and H. J. Keisler, Model theory, Stud. Logic Found. Math., 73, North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1973. MR0409165
  2. M. Foreman, M. Magidor and S. Shelah, Martin's maximum, saturated ideals and non-regular ultrafilters, II, Ann. of Math. (2), 127 (1988), 521–545. MR0942519
  3. S. Garti and S. Shelah, Depth of Boolean algebras, Notre Dame J. Form. Log., 52 (2011), 307–314. MR2822491
  4. T. Jech, Set theory, Pure and Applied Mathematics, Academic Press [Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Publishers], New York, 1978. MR0506523
  5. A. Kanamori, The higher infinite, Large cardinals in set theory from their beginnings, Perspect. Math. Logic, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 1994. MR1321144
  6. J. König, Über die Grundlagen der Mengenlehre und das Kontinuumproblem, Math. Ann., 61 (1905), 156–160. MR1511338
  7. M. Magidor, How large is the first strongly compact cardinal? or A study on identity crises, Ann. Math. Logic, 10 (1976), 33–57. MR0429566
  8. J. D. Monk, Cardinal invariants on Boolean algebras, Progr. Math., 142, Birkhäuser Verlag, Basel, 1996. MR1393943

  10. S. Shelah, Classification theory and the number of nonisomorphic models, Stud. Logic Found. Math., 92, North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1978. MR0513226
  11. S. Shelah, Advances in cardinal arithmetic, Finite and infinite combinatorics in sets and logic, Banff, AB, 1991, NATO Adv. Sci. Inst. Ser. C Math. Phys. Sci., 411, Kluwer Acad. Publ., Dordrecht, 1993, pp. 355–383. MR1261217
  12. S. Shelah, The depth of ultraproducts of Boolean algebras, Algebra Universalis, 54 (2005), 91–96. MR2217966
  13. W. H. Woodin, The axiom of determinacy, forcing axioms, and the nonstationary ideal, de Gruyter Ser. Log. Appl., 1, Walter de Gruyter & Co., Berlin, 1999. MR1713438
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 2

MR2914923 Reviewed
Raghavan, Dilip(J-KOBEE-GSI)
Graduate School of System Informatics, Kobe University
Nada, Kobe, Hyogo, 657-8501, Japan
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Comparing the closed almost disjointness and dominating numbers. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 217 (2012), no. 1, 73–81.
03E17 (03E05 03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-09-17 Review Published2013-10-23

Two functions $f,g\in \omega^\omega$ are almost disjoint if the set $\{n\in\omega: f(n)=g(n)\}$ is finite. An infinite partial function $p$ is a function from some infinite set ${\rm dom}(p)\subseteq \omega$ into $\omega$. A van Douwen family is a family ${\scr A}\subseteq\omega^\omega$ of pairwise almost disjoint functions such that for any infinite partial function $p$ there is $h\in {\scr A}$ such that the set $\{n\in {\rm dom}(p): p(n)=h(n)\}$ is infinite. (Thus ${\scr A}\subseteq \omega^\omega$ is a van Douwen family if and only if ${\scr A}\cup\{c_n: n\in \omega\}$ is a MAD family in $[\omega\times\omega]^\omega$, where $c_n$ is the $n$th vertical column of $\omega\times\omega$.)
   The authors show that if there exists a dominating family in $\omega^\omega$ of size $\aleph_1$, then there exists a van Douwen family which can be represented as the union of $\aleph_1$ many compact subsets of $\omega^\omega$.
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

    References
  1. J. Brendle and Y. Khomskii, $\aleph_{1}$-perfect MAD families, in preparation.
  2. E. Pearl (ed.), Open Problems in Topology. II, Elsevier, Amsterdam, 2007. MR2023411
  3. D. Raghavan, There is a Van Douwen MAD family, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 362 (2010), 5879–5891. MR2661500
  4. S. Shelah, Two cardinal invariants of the continuum $(\germ{d}< \germ{a})$ and FS linearly ordered iterated forcing, Acta Math. 192 (2004), 187–223. MR2096454
  5. E. K. van Douwen, The integers and topology, in: Handbook of Set-Theoretic Topology, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1984, 111–167. MR0776622
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Rosłanowski, Andrzej(1-NEO)

; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)

Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Spinas, Otmar(D-KIEL-MS)
Mathematisches Seminar, Christian-Albrechts Universität Kiel
D-24118 Kiel, Germany

Nonproper products. (English summary)
Bull. Lond. Math. Soc. 44 (2012), no. 2, 299–310.
03E40
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-09-17 Review Published2013-05-07

S. Shelah [Fund. Math. 166 (2000), no. 1-2, 1–82; MR1804704] asked about the properness of the forcing notion $\Bbb{Q}=\{\langle w_n:n<\omega\rangle:w_n\subseteq2^n$, $w_n\ne\emptyset$ and $\lim_{n\to\omega}|w_n|=\infty\}$ ordered by $w\le w'\Leftrightarrow(\forall n\in\omega)$ $w'_n\subseteq w_n$. The authors give a general criterion for collapsing the continuum to $\aleph_0$ and then apply it to $\Bbb{Q}$ showing that $\Bbb{Q}$ is not proper. It is known that properness is not a productive property. The authors show that there exist two proper creature forcings having simple Borel definitions whose product is not proper. They also give a new condition ensuring properness of some forcings with norms.
Reviewed by Miroslav Repický

    References
  1. T. Bartoszyński and H. Judah, Set theory: on the structure of the real line (A K Peters, Wellesley, MA, 1995). MR1350295
  2. J. Kellner and S. Shelah, `Decisive creatures and large continuum', J. Symbolic Logic 74 (2009) 73–104. math.LO/0601083. MR2499421
  3. J. Kellner and S. Shelah, `Creature forcing and large continuum. The joy of halving', Arch. Math. Logic, accepted. 1003.3425. cf. MR2864397
  4. A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, `Norms on possibilities I: forcing with trees and creatures', Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 141 (1999) xii + 167. math.LO/9807172. MR1613600
  5. A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, `Monotone hulls for ${\scr {N}}{\cap}{\scr {M}}$', Period. Math. Hungar., submitted. 1007.5368. cf. MR3269711
  6. S. Shelah, Proper and improper forcing (Springer, Berlin, 1998). MR1623206
  7. S. Shelah, `On what I do not understand (and have something to say:) Part I', Fund. Math. 166 (2000) 1–82. math.LO/9906113. MR1804704
  8. O. Spinas, `Proper products', Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 137 (2009) 2767–2772. MR2497491
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2899700 Reviewed
Lücke, Philipp(D-MUNS-MI)
Fachbereich für Mathematik und Informatik, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster
D-48149 Münster, Germany
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

External automorphisms of ultraproducts of finite models. (English summary)
Arch. Math. Logic 51 (2012), no. 3-4, 433–441.
03C20 (03E50 20B27)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-08-07 Review Published2013-07-25

The two authors are interested in the existence of ultraproducts that have few external automorphisms. Let $\germ{L}$ be a finite first-order language and let $\langle M_n : n < \omega \rangle$ be a sequence of finite $\germ{L}$-models. For a non-principal ultrafilter $U$ on $\omega$ let $\prod_UM_n$ denote the usual ultraproduct and let $[x]_U$ be the corresponding equivalence class of an element $x \in \prod_nM_n$. Recall that an automorphism $\pi$ of $\prod_UM_n$ is internal if there is a sequence of automorphisms $\pi_n$ of $M_n$ that induces $\pi$ in the obvious sense. Otherwise $\pi$ is called external. While under the continuum hypothesis (CH) such an ultraproduct always has many external automorphisms, the situation is different under the negation of CH. Two classical results, one by the second author of the paper under review and one by Simon Thomas and the first author, state that the following two statements are consistent with ZFC:
$\bullet$
there is a non-principal ultrafilter $U$ over the set $P$ of primes such that the field $\prod_UF_p$ has no nontrivial external automorphisms;
$\bullet$
there is a non-principal ultrafilter $U$ on $\omega$ such that all automorphisms of the group $\prod_U{\rm Sym}(n)$ are internal.
This work is inspired by asking whether one can generalize the above results by replacing the existence quantifier by a for-all quantifier. The main theorem shows that under a mild set-theoretic assumption, known as Martin's Axiom of Cohen-Forcing, this cannot be done. Note that CH and also Martin's Axiom both imply this mild set-theoretic assumption.
Reviewed by Lutz Struengmann

    References
  1. Chang, C.C., Keisler, H.J.: Model Theory, 2nd edn, Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, 73. North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam (1977) MR0532927
  2. Kechris, A.S.: Classical Descriptive Set Theory, vol 156 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics. Springer, New York, NY (1995) MR1321597
  3. Lücke, P., Thomas, S.: Automorphism groups of ultraproducts of finite symmetric groups. Commun. Algebra 39(10), 3625–3630 (2011) MR2845589
  4. Shelah, S.: On the cardinality of ultraproduct of finite sets. J. Symb. Log. 35, 83–84 (1970) MR0325388
  5. Shelah, S.: Vive la différence. III. Israel J. Math. 166, 61–96 (2008) MR2430425
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR2897749 Reviewed
Dow, Alan(1-NC3-NDM)
University of North Carolina
Charlotte, North Carolina, 28213
; Shelah, Saharon(1-RTG)
Department of Mathematics, Rutgers University
Piscataway (New Brunswick), New Jersey, 08854

Martin's axiom and separated mad families. (English summary)
Rend. Circ. Mat. Palermo (2) 61 (2012), no. 1, 107–115.
03E35 (03E50)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-10-19 Review Published2013-05-07

Summary: "Two families $\scr A,\scr B$ of subsets of $\omega$ are said to be separated if there is a subset of $\omega$ which mod finite contains every member of $\scr A$ and is almost disjoint from every member of $\scr B$. If $\scr A$ and $\scr B$ are countable disjoint subsets of an almost disjoint family, then they are separated. Luzin gaps are well-known examples of $\omega_1$-sized subfamilies of an almost disjoint family which can not be separated. An almost disjoint family will be said to be $\omega_1$-separated if any disjoint pair of $\leq\omega_1$-sized subsets are separated. It is known that the proper forcing axiom (PFA) implies that no maximal almost disjoint family is $\leq\omega_1$-separated. We prove that this does not follow from Martin's Axiom.''

    References
  1. Abraham, U., Shelah, S.: Lusin sequences under CH and under Martin's axiom. Fundam. Math. 169(2), 97–103 (2001). MR1852375 (2002k:03069) MR1852375
  2. Dow, A.: Sequential order under PFA. Canad. Math. Bull. 54, 270–276 (2011) MR2884242
  3. Luzin, N.N.: On subsets of the series of natural numbers. Izv. Akad. Nauk SSSR, Ser. Mat. 11, 403–410 (1947). MR0021576 (9,82c) MR0021576
  4. Martin, D.A., Solovay, R.M.: Internal Cohen extensions. Ann. Math. Log. 2(2), 143–178 (1970). MR0270904 (42 #5787) MR0270904
  5. Steprāns, J.: Strong $Q$-sequences and variations on Martin's axiom. Can. J. Math. 37(4), 730–746 (1985). MR801424 (87c:03106) MR0801424
  6. Todorčević, S.: Analytic gaps. Fundam. Math. 150(1), 55–66 (1996). MR1387957 (98j:03070) MR1387957

MR2885917 (2012k:05163) Reviewed
Larson, Paul(1-MMOH-DM)
Department of Mathematics, Miami University
Oxford, Ohio, 45056
; Matteo, Nicholas(1-MMOH-DM)
Department of Mathematics, Miami University

Majority decisions when abstention is possible. (English summary)
Discrete Math. 312 (2012), no. 7, 1336–1352.
05C20 (91B14)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-06-19 Review Published2012-08-08

Summary: "Suppose that we are given a family of choice functions on pairs from a given finite set. The set is considered as a set of alternatives (say candidates for an office) and the functions as potential `voters'. The question is, what choice functions agree, on every pair, with the majority of some finite subfamily of the voters? For the problem as stated, a complete characterization was given in [S. Shelah, Discrete Math. 309 (2009), no. 8, 2349–2364; MR2510361], but here we allow voters to abstain. Aside from the trivial case, the possible families of (partial) choice functions break into three cases in terms of the functions that can be generated by majority decision. In one of these, cycles along the lines of Condorcet's paradox are avoided. In another, all partial choice functions can be represented.''
Reviewed by M. Remzi Sanver

    References
  1. N. Alon, Voting paradoxes and digraphs realizations, Advances in Applied Mathematics 29 (2002) 126–135. MR1921548
  2. J.A.N.d. Condorcet, Essai sur l'application de l'analyse à la probabilité des décisions rendues à la pluralité des voix, L'imprimerie Royale, Paris, 1785.
  3. P. Erdős, L. Moser, On the representation of directed graphs as unions of orderings, Magyar Tudományos Akadémia Matematikai Kutató Intézet Közleményei 9 (1964) 125–132. MR0168494
  4. K.-I. Inada, A note on the simple majority decision rule, Econometrica 32 (1964) 525–553. MR0176847
  5. J. Mala, On $\lambda $-majority voting paradoxes, Mathematical Social Sciences 37 (1999) 39–44. MR1662482
  6. D.C. McGarvey, A theorem on the construction of voting paradoxes, Econometrica 21 (1953) 608–610. MR0062415
  7. S. Shelah, What majority decisions are possible, Discrete Mathematics 309 (2009) 2349–2364. MR2510361
  8. R. Stearns, The voting problem, American Mathematical Monthly 66 (1959) 761–763. MR0109087
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2869022 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-E)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics and Computer Science, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Nice infinitary logics.
J. Amer. Math. Soc. 25 (2012), no. 2, 395–427.
03C95 (03C55 03C80)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-05-08 Review Published2014-04-14

In the paper under review, the author constructs a new infinitary logic satisfying several highly desirable properties as well as a characterization theorem. The term "logic'', $\Bbb{L}$, as used in the paper may loosely be understood as consisting of a function taking a vocabulary $\tau$ to a set of logical formulae $\Bbb{L}(\tau)$ together with a nation of satisfaction $\models_{\Bbb{L}}$ satisfying several very basic coherence properties. Before stating the main theorem, we provide two necessary definitions.
   To begin with, a logic $\Bbb{L}$ is called nice if among other technical conditions it is closed under conjunction, negation, and existential quantification. One of the main properties considered for a logic in the current paper is interpolation, defined as follows:
   Definition. A nice logic $\Bbb{L}$ satisfies interpolation if whenever $\tau, \tau_0, \tau_1$ are vocabularies with $\tau=\tau_0 \cap \tau_1$, $\psi_1 \in \Bbb{L}(\tau_1)$, $\psi_2 \in \Bbb{L}(\tau_2)$ such that $\psi_1 \wedge \neg\psi_2$ has no model, then there is $\phi \in \Bbb{L}(\tau)$ such that $\psi_1 \wedge \neg \phi$ has no model and $\phi \wedge \neg \psi_2$ has no model.
   The following summarizes many of the main results of the paper:
   Theorem. If $\kappa=\beth_{\kappa}$ there is a logic $\Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$ such that:
(1)
$\Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$ is nice;
(2)
$\Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$ is the maximal nice logic such that for any ordinal $\alpha < \kappa$, the structure $(\alpha, <)$ can be characterized up to isomorphism by some $\psi \in \Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$;
(3)
$\Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$ satisfies interpolation;
(4)
$\Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$ is between $\bigcup\{\Bbb{L}_{\lambda^+,\aleph_0}: \lambda < \kappa\}$ and $\bigcup \{\Bbb{L}_{\lambda^+, \lambda^+} : \lambda< \kappa\}$;
(5)
$\Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}$ satisfies a downward Löwenheim-Skolem theorem: every $\psi \in \Bbb{L}^1_{\kappa}(\tau)$ with a model has a model of cardinality less than $\kappa$;
(6)
well ordering is not expressible: if $\psi$ is a sentence and for every ordinal $\alpha$ there is $M \models \psi$ such that $(P^M,<^M)$ is a well ordering of type $\geq \alpha$ then there is a model $N \models \psi$ such that $(P^M,<^N)$ is not a well ordering.
Reviewed by Alfred Dolich

    References

  2. [Dic85] M. A. Dickman, Larger infinitary languages, Model Theoretic Logics (J. Barwise and S. Feferman, eds.), Perspectives in Mathematical Logic, Springer-Verlag, New York, Berlin, Heidelberg, Tokyo, 1985, pp. 317–364. MR819540 MR0819540

Citations

From References: 4

From Reviews: 0

MR2864397 Reviewed
Kellner, Jakob(A-WIEN-IL)
Kurt Gödel Research Center for Mathematical Logic (formerly Institut für Formalen Logik), Universität Wien
1090 Vienna, Austria
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Creature forcing and large continuum: the joy of halving. (English summary)
Arch. Math. Logic 51 (2012), no. 1-2, 49–70.
03E17 (03E40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2012 Indexed 2012-05-05 Review Published2012-09-25

Cardinal characteristics of the form $c^\forall(f,g), c^\exists(f,g)$ were used in [M. R. Goldstern and S. Shelah, Arch. Math. Logic 32 (1993), no. 3, 203–221; MR1201650; J. Kellner, Arch. Math. Logic 47 (2008), no. 5, 503–515; MR2425542; J. Kellner and S. Shelah, J. Symbolic Logic 74 (2009), no. 1, 73–104; MR2499421] to show that consistently we may have many distinct simple cardinal invariants of the continuum. The present article continues this line of research. The authors show that it is consistent that $c^\forall(f_\varepsilon,g_\varepsilon)=c^\exists(f_\varepsilon,g_\varepsilon)=\kappa_\varepsilon$ for continuum many pairwise different cardinals $\kappa_\varepsilon$ and suitable pairs $(f_\varepsilon, g_\varepsilon)$. For the proof they introduce a new forcing construction, somewhat in between a restricted product and a CS iteration.
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

    References

  2. Goldstern, M., Shelah, S.: Many simple cardinal invariants. Arch. Math. Logic 32(3), 203–221 (1993) MR1201650

  5. Rosłanowski, A., Shelah, S.: Norms on possibilities. I. Forcing with trees and creatures. Mem. Am. Math. Soc. 141 (671), xii+167 (1999) MR1613600
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2908010 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

On $\lambda$ strong homogeneity existence for cofinality logic. (English, Spanish summary)
Cubo 13 (2011), no. 2, 59–72.
03C95 (03C80)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-07-11 Review Published2013-03-14

Let $C$ be a non-empty class of regular cardinals. This paper considers first-order logic $\Bbb{L}$ expanded by the quantifier $Q^{\roman{cf}}_C$, which asserts that a linear order or quasilinear order has cofinality in $C$. More precisely, if $\phi(x,y)$ is a formula then the formula $(Q^{\roman{cf}}_C x,y)\phi(x,y)$ asserts that $\phi(x,y)$ defines a linear or quasilinear order whose cofinality is in $C$.
   The author previously showed [Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 204 (1975), 342–364; MR0376334] that the logic $\Bbb{L}(Q^{\roman{cf}}_C)$ is compact. In this paper he shows that every theory in the logic which has a model also has a strongly $\aleph_0$-homogeneous model.
Reviewed by Jonathan Kirby

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2895398 Reviewed
Mildenberger, Heike(D-FRBG-IML)
Institut für Mathematische Logik, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg
D-79104 Freiburg, Germany
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

The minimal cofinality of an ultrapower of $\omega$ and the cofinality of the symmetric group can be larger than $\germ b^+$. (English summary)
J. Symbolic Logic 76 (2011), no. 4, 1322–1340.
03E17 (03E05 03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-04-28 Review Published2012-09-28

Given an ultrafilter ${\scr U}$ on the natural numbers $\omega$, equip the ultrapower $\omega^\omega/{\scr U}$ with the linear order $\leq_{\scr U}$ given by $[f] \leq_{\scr U} [g]$ if the set $\{ n \: f(n) \leq g(n) \}$ belongs to ${\scr U}$. The cardinal invariant ${\germ{mcf}}$ is the minimal cofinality of $(\omega^\omega/{\scr U} , \leq_{\scr U})$ where ${\scr U}$ ranges over the non-principal ultrafilters on $\omega$. Clearly ${\germ b} \leq {\germ{mcf}}$ where ${\germ b}$ is the unbounding number. ${\roman{Sym}} (\omega)$ is the group of all permutations of $\omega$. Its cofinality, ${\roman{cf}} ({\roman{Sym}} (\omega))$, is the least $\kappa$ such that ${\roman{Sym}} (\omega)$ can be written as a strictly increasing union of proper subgroups of length $\kappa$. Both cardinals ${\germ{mcf}}$ and ${\roman{cf}} ({\roman{Sym}} (\omega))$ are larger than or equal to the groupwise density number ${\germ g}$, and are consistently strictly larger.
   The authors prove that for arbitrary regular cardinals $\theta < \kappa$, ${\germ b} = \theta $ and ${\germ{mcf}} \geq \kappa$ is consistent. Their model is obtained by a cofinality-preserving forcing and satisfies ${\germ c} > \kappa$. By collapsing over this model, one also obtains the consistency of ${\germ b} = \theta $ and ${\germ{mcf}} = {\germ c} = \kappa$. Similarly, the authors prove the consistency of ${\germ b} = \theta $ and ${\roman{cf}} ({\roman{Sym}} (\omega)) \geq \kappa$, and the comment about the collapse applies to this situation as well.
   The consistency of ${\germ b} < {\germ g}$ (and thus also of ${\germ b} < {\germ{mcf}}$ and ${\germ b} < {\roman{cf}} ({\roman{Sym}} (\omega))$) has been known previously. However, S. Shelah [MLQ Math. Log. Q. 54 (2008), no. 4, 340–344; MR2435897] proved that ${\germ g} \leq {\germ b}^+$, and this triggered the question of whether cardinals closely related to ${\germ g}$, like ${\germ{mcf}}$ and ${\roman{cf}} ({\roman{Sym}} (\omega))$, are also bounded by ${\germ b}^+$. The present results say that this is not the case.
Reviewed by Jörg D. Brendle

    References
  1. Taras Banakh. Dušan Repovš, and Lyubomyr Zdomskyy, On the length of chain of proper subgroups covering a topological group, Archive for Mathematical Logic, vol. 50 (2011), no. 3–4, pp. 411–421. MR2786762
  2. Tomek Bartoszyński and Haim Judah, \it Set theory, on the structure of the real line, A K Peters, 1995. MR1350295

  15. Simon Thomas, Groupwise density and the cofinality of the infinite symmetric group, Archive for Mathematical Logic, vol. 37 (1998), pp. 483–493. MR1651244
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2895391 Reviewed
Kellner, Jakob(A-WIEN-IL)
Kurt Gödel Research Center for Mathematical Logic (formerly Institut für Formalen Logik), Universität Wien
1090 Vienna, Austria
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Saccharinity. (English summary)
J. Symbolic Logic 76 (2011), no. 4, 1153–1183.
03E40 (03E35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-04-28 Review Published2012-11-20

The authors present a method to iterate lim-sup finitely splitting tree forcings along any linear (not necessarily well-founded) orders.
   The forcing notions which can be used in this scheme are essentially the finitary t-omittory instances of ${\Bbb Q}^{\rm tree}_0(K,\Sigma)$ of [A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, Mem. Amer. Math. Soc. 141 (1999), no. 671, xii+167 pp.; MR1613600]. They are defined as follows. We are given some finitely branching tree $T_{\max}$ with a function $\mu$ which measures the sizes of subsets of successors of nodes $t\in T_{\max}$. Then the corresponding forcing notion $Q$ consists of all subtrees $T$ of $T_{\max}$ with no maximal nodes and such that $$ (\forall b\in \lim(T))(\limsup_{n\to\infty}\mu({\rm succ}_T(b \restriction n))=\infty). $$ The order is the inclusion relation, so stronger conditions are smaller trees. For instance, the Sacks forcing notion can be represented this way.
   For $Q$ as above we define an ideal ${\Bbb I}$ of subsets of $\lim(T_{\max})$ by declaring that a set $X\subseteq \lim(T_{\max})$ belongs to ${\Bbb I}$ if and only if $$ (\forall S\in Q)(\exists T\leq S)(\lim(T)\cap X=\emptyset). $$ (If $Q$ is the Sacks forcing notion then ${\Bbb I}$ is the Marczewski ideal.) Then we let ${\Bbb I}^{\germ c}$ be the ${<}2^{\aleph_0}$-closure of ${\Bbb I}$. We also say that a set $X\subseteq \lim(T_{\max})$ is weakly measurable if $$ (\forall S\in Q)(\exists T\leq S)(\lim(T)\cap X\in {\Bbb I}^{\germ c}\ \vee \lim(T)\sbs X\in {\Bbb I}^{\germ c}). $$
   As an application of non-well-founded iterations of forcing notions as above, the authors construct a model in which every definable subset of $\lim(T_{\max})$ is weakly measurable, $2^{\aleph_0}>\aleph_1$ and the ideal ${\Bbb I}^{\germ c}$ is proper.
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

    References
  1. Jörg Brendle, Mad families and iteration theory Logic and algebra, Contemporary Mathematics, vol. 302, American Mathematical Society, Providence, RI, 2002, pp. 1–31. MR1928381
  2. Jörg Brendle, Lorenz Halbeisen, and Benedikt Löwe, Silver measurability and its relation to other regularity properties, Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, vol. 138 (2005), no. 1, pp. 135–149. MR2127234
  3. Martin Goldstern, A taste of proper forcing Set theory (\it Curaçao, 1995; Barcelona, 1996), Kluwer Academic Publishers, Dordrecht, 1998, pp. 71–82. MR1601976
  4. M. Groszek and T. Jech, Generalized iteration of forcing, Transactions of the American Mathematical Society, vol. 324 (1991), no. 1, pp. 1–26. MR0946221
  5. Marcia Groszek, $\omega _1^*$ as an initial segment of the $c$-degrees, this Journal, vol. 59 (1994), no. 3, pp. 956–976. MR1295981
  6. Thomas Jech and Saharon Shelah, A complete Boolean algebra that has no proper atomless complete subalgebra, Journal of Algebra, vol. 182 (1996), no. 3, pp. 748–755. MR1398120
  7. Vladimir Kanovei, On non-wellfounded iterations of the perfect set forcing, this Journal, vol. 64 (1999), no. 2, pp. 551–574. MR1777770

  15. Jindřich Zapletal, \it Forcing idealized, Cambridge Tracts in Mathematics, vol. 174, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 2008. MR2391923
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 4

From Reviews: 4

MR2894445 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

MAD saturated families and SANE player. (English summary)
Canad. J. Math. 63 (2011), no. 6, 1416–1435.
03E05 (03E17 03E40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-04-12 Review Published2012-09-25

An infinite family ${\scr A}$ of almost disjoint infinite subsets of $\omega$ is a completely separable (or saturated) MAD family if for every set $B\in[\omega]^{\aleph_0}$, either $B$ is almost included in the union of finitely many members of ${\scr A}$ or $B$ almost includes an element of ${\scr A}$.
   The question whether there exist completely separable MAD families was posed in [P. Erdős and S. Shelah, Israel J. Math. 12 (1972), 207–214; MR0319770] and since then several partial results and constructions under various set-theoretic assumptions have been given.
   In the present article the author provides further evidence that it is hard to show the consistency of the negative answer. He defines a cardinal invariant ${\germ a}_*$ as the minimal cardinal number $\kappa$ for which there exists a sequence $\langle A_\alpha:\alpha<\kappa+\omega\rangle$ of infinite subsets of $\omega$ with the following two properties:
(i)
If $\alpha<\beta<\kappa+\omega$ then $A_\alpha\cap A_\beta$ is finite.
(ii)
If an infinite subset $B$ of $\omega$ is almost disjoint from all $A_\alpha$ for $\alpha<\kappa$, then $(\forall^\infty n\in\omega)(|B\cap A_{\kappa+n}|<\omega)$.
(Plainly, ${\germ b}\leq{\germ a}_*\leq{\germ a}$.) The main result of the paper is that there exists a completely separable MAD family if any of the following three assumptions is satisfied:
$\bullet$
${\germ s}<{\germ a}_*$ (Theorem 2.1), or
$\bullet$
${\germ s}={\germ a}_*={\rm cf}([{\germ s}]^{\aleph_0},\subseteq)$ (Theorem 3.1), or
$\bullet$
${\germ a}_*<{\germ s}$ and ${\rm Pr}({\germ s},{\germ a}_*)$ (Theorem 3.6).
Reviewed by Andrzej Rosłanowski

    References
  1. B. Balcar, J. Pelant, and P. Simon, The space of ultrafilters on $N$ covered by nowhere dense sets. Fund. Math. 110(1980), no. 1, 11–24. MR0600576
  2. B. Balcar and P. Simon, Disjoint refinement. In: Handbook of Boolean algebras, Vol. 2, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1989, pp. 333–388. MR0991597
  3. P. Simon, A note on almost disjoint refinement. 24th Winter School on Abstract Analysis (Benešova Hora, 1996). Acta. Univ. Carolin. Math. Phys. 37(1996), no. 2, 89–99. MR1600453
  4. P. C. Eklof and A. Mekler, Almost free modules: Set theoretic methods. North-Holland Mathematical Library, 65, North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 2002. MR1914985
  5. P. Erdös and S. Shelah, Separability properties of almost-disjoint families of sets. Israel J. Math. 12(1972), 207–214. doi:101007/BF02764666 MR0319770
  6. M. Goldstern, H. Judah, and S. Shelah, Saturated families. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 111(1991), no. 4, 1095–1104. doi:10.1090/S0002-9939-1991-1052573-0 MR1052573
  7. S. H. Hechler, Classifying almost-disjoint families with applications to $\beta N-N$. Israel J. Math. 10(1971), 413–432. doi:10.1007/BF02771729 MR0302450

  10. S. Shelah and J. Steprans, MASAS in the Calkin algebra without the continuum hypothesis. J. Appl. Anal. 17(2011), no. 1, 69–89. doi:10.1515/JAA.2011.004 MR2805847
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

From References: 0

MR2886755 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

The first almost free Whitehead group. (English summary)
Tbil. Math. J. 4 (2011), 17–30.
03E75 (03C60 20K20)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-06-25 Review Published2012-10-01

The author continues the investigation of Whitehead groups. Recall that an abelian group $G$ is called a Whitehead group if ${\rm Ext}_{\Bbb{Z}}(G,\Bbb{Z})=0$, i.e. whenever $H$ is an abelian group with $\Bbb{Z} \subseteq H$ such that $H/\Bbb{Z} \cong G$, $\Bbb{Z}$ is a direct summand of $H$. It is by now well known that it is undecidable in ZFC if Whitehead groups are free or not. The author proves the following theorem: Assume the generalized continuum hypothesis and let $\kappa$ be the first uncountable cardinal such that there is a non-free $\kappa$-free Whitehead group of cardinality $\kappa$. If all $\kappa$-free groups of cardinality $\kappa$ are Whitehead groups, then $\kappa$ necessarily has to be inaccessible.
Reviewed by Lutz Struengmann

Citations

From References: 13

From Reviews: 1

MR2867976 (2012k:03093) Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

No limit model in inaccessibles. (English summary) Models, logics, and higher-dimensional categories, 277–290,
CRM Proc. Lecture Notes, 53, Amer. Math. Soc., Providence, RI, 2011.
03C45 (03C55)
Review PDF Clipboard Series Chapter Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-05-05 Review Published2012-08-08

In recent papers ["Dependent $T$ and existence of limit models'', preprint, arXiv:math/0609636; Colloq. Math. 126 (2012), no. 2, 187–204, doi:10.4064/cm126-2-4; "Dependent dreams: recounting types'', preprint, arXiv:1202.5795; "Dependent theories and the generic pair conjecture'', preprint, arXiv:math/0702292] the author suggested some conjectures which claim that the independence property of a complete theory is a meaningful dividing line between non-existence and existence of models of a certain kind. Let $T$ be a complete first-order theory, $\lambda$ be a cardinal such that $\lambda^{<\lambda}=\lambda>|T|$ and $2^\lambda=\lambda^+$, and $\kappa$ be a regular cardinal $<\lambda$. The "unique limit model conjecture'' asserts that $T$ is dependent if and only if for any continuous increasing elementary chain $\langle M_\alpha: \alpha<\lambda^+\rangle$ of models of cardinality $\lambda$ with saturated union there is a club $E$ of $\lambda^+$ such that all $M_\alpha$ with $\alpha\in E$ and ${\rm cf}(\alpha)=\kappa$ are pairwise isomorphic. The "generic pair conjecture'' claims that $T$ is dependent if and only if for any $\langle M_\alpha: \alpha<\lambda^+\rangle$ as above there is a club $E$ of $\lambda^+$ such that for all $\alpha, \beta\in E$ of cofinality $\lambda$ with $\alpha<\beta$ the structures $(M_\beta, M_\alpha)$ have the same isomorphism type. In the preprints the author proved some partial results supporting the conjectures. In particular, the limit model conjecture holds for typical special cases of dependent theories: for stable theories (in many cases) and for the theory of dense linear order without endpoints. In [op. cit., arXiv:math/0609636] the conjectures were proven for independent theories and $\lambda$ of the form $2^\nu$. In the paper under review the same is done for strongly inaccessible $\lambda$.

{For the collection containing this paper see MR2848606.} Reviewed by O. V. Belegradek

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2861541 (2012j:20160) Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR)
Department of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem, Israel
; Strüngmann, Lutz(D-DUES2M)
Universität Duisburg-Essen
D-45117 Essen, Germany

Kulikov's problem on universal torsion-free abelian groups revisited. (English summary)
Bull. Lond. Math. Soc. 43 (2011), no. 6, 1198–1204.
20K15 (20K20 20K35)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-04-24 Review Published2012-06-28

Let $T$ be a torsion abelian group and let $^{\perp}T$ denote the class of all torsion-free abelian groups such that ${\rm Ext}(G,T)=0$. Let $\lambda$ be an infinite cardinal. An abelian group $G\in{}^{\perp}T$ is called $\lambda $-universal for $T$ if ${\rm rank}(G)\leq\lambda$ and all $H\in{}^{\perp}T$ with ${\rm rank}(H)\leq\lambda$ are isomorphic to a subgroup of $G$. The authors study the existence of $\lambda$-universal abelian groups. It is shown that if $T$ is a torsion abelian group with infinitely many bounded, nontrivial primary components, then there is no $\lambda$-universal group for $T$ for any cardinal $\aleph_{0}\leq\lambda<2^{\aleph_{0}}$. On the other hand, under the set-theoretic axiom $V=L$, if $\lambda>\aleph_{0}$, then there exists a $\lambda$-universal group for any torsion group $T$.
Reviewed by Manfred Dugas

    References
  1. R. Baer, `The subgroup of the elements of finite order of an abelian group', Ann. of Math. 37 (1936) 766–781. MR1503308
  2. P. C. Eklof and A. Mekler, Almost free modules, set-theoretic methods (revised edition) (North-Holland Mathematical Library, Amsterdam, 2002). MR1914985
  3. L. Fuchs, Infinite abelian groups I, II (Academic Press, New York, 1970/73). MR0348006
  4. S. Shelah and L. Strüngmann, `On Kulikov's problem and universal torsion-free abelian groups', J. London Math. Soc. 67 (2003) 626–642. MR1967696
  5. L. Strüngmann, `On problems by Baer and Kulikov using $V = L$', Illinois J. Math. 46 (2002) 477–490. MR1936930
  6. E.I. Khukhro and V.D. Mazurov, The Kourovka Notebook: unsolved questions in group theory, 14th edn (Russian Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russia, 1999). MR1733915
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Citations

From References: 0

From Reviews: 0

MR2851699 Reviewed
Mildenberger, Heike(D-FRBG-ML)
Abteilung für Mathematische Logik, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg
D-79104 Freiburg, Germany
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Proper translation. (English summary)
Fund. Math. 215 (2011), no. 1, 1–38.
03E35 (03E15 03E17)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-03-21 Review Published2012-11-02

For Borel sets $A, B,$ and $E \subseteq A \times B$, the parametrized diamond principle $\diamondsuit (A,B,E)$, introduced by J. T. Moore, M. Hrušák and M. Džamonja [Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 356 (2004), no. 6, 2281–2306; MR2048518], says that for every Borel map $F \: 2^{< \omega_1} \to A$ there is a function $g \: \omega_1 \to B$ such that for every function $f \: \omega_1 \to 2$, the set of $\alpha$ in $\omega_1$ with $F (f \upharpoonright \alpha) E g(\alpha)$ is stationary. These diamonds are natural weakenings of Jensen's classical diamond principle $\diamondsuit$.
   The authors show that it is consistent that the continuum has size $\aleph_2$, all Aronszajn trees are special, and the parametrized diamond ${\diamondsuit ({\Bbb{R}}, {\text{closed null sets}}, \in)}$ for covering of the real line by closed null sets holds. The proof uses a countable support iteration of length $\omega_2$ of proper partial orders which alternately add Sacks reals and specialize Aronszajn trees with a forcing notion not adding reals. In particular, the parametrized diamonds $\diamondsuit ( {\roman{Cov}} ({\scr{N}}))$ and $\diamondsuit ( {\roman{Cov}} ({\scr{M}}))$ are consistent with all Aronszajn trees being special and the negation of the continuum hypothesis. For $\diamondsuit ( {\roman{Cov}} ({\scr{M}}))$, this has been known by a result of R. J. Laver [Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 100 (1987), no. 3, 531–534; MR0891159].
   In the context of the continuum hypothesis CH, the same consistency result (all Aronszajn trees are special and ${\diamondsuit ({\Bbb{R}}, {\text{closed null sets}}, \in)}$ holds) has been proved earlier by the present authors [J. Appl. Anal. 15 (2009), no. 1, 47–78; MR2537976].
Reviewed by Jörg D. Brendle

    References
  1. U. Abraham, Proper forcing, in: M. Foreman et al. (eds.), Handbook of Set Theory, Springer, 2010, 333–394. MR2768684

From References: 4

From Reviews: 0

MR2848252 (2012f:05312) Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel
; Zapletal, Jindřich(1-FL)
Department of Mathematics, University of Florida
Gainesville, Florida, 32611

Ramsey theorems for product of finite sets with submeasures. (English summary)
Combinatorica 31 (2011), no. 2, 225–244.
05D10 (03E15 03E40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2011-12-09 Review Published2012-03-08

The authors prove the following parametrized partition theorem: Suppose $k\in\omega$ and $\langle r_n\colon n\in\omega\rangle$ is a sequence of real numbers. Then for every sequence of submeasures $\langle\phi_n\colon n\in\omega\rangle$ on finite sets "increasing fast enough'' and for every partition of the product $\prod_n\text{dom}(\phi_n)\times\omega$ into $k$ Borel pieces, one of the pieces contains a product of the form $\prod_nb_n\times c$ where $c\subseteq\omega$ is infinite and $b_n\subseteq\text{dom}(\phi_n)$ and $\phi_n(b_n)>r_n$. This theorem has a variation concerning $F_\sigma$-ideals on $\omega$ and a measure parametrized version. These theorems improve results of Di Prisco, Llopis and Todorcevic on parametrized partitions of products of finite sets.
Reviewed by Miroslav Repický

    References
  1. Carlos Di Prisco and James Henle: Partitions of products, J. Symbolic Logic 58 (1993), 860–871. MR1242042
  2. Carlos Di Prisco, Jimena Llopis and Stevo Todorcevic: Borel partitions of products of finite sets and the Ackermann function, J. Comb. Theory, Ser. A 93(2) (2001), 333–349. MR1805301
  3. Carlos A. Di Prisco, Jimena Llopis and Stevo Todorcevic: Parametrized partitions of products of finite sets, Combinatorica 24(2) (2004), 209–232. MR2071333
  4. David H. Fremlin: Large correlated families of positive random variables, Math. Proc. Cambridge. Philos. Soc. 103 (1988), 147–162. MR0913459
  5. Fred Galvin and Karel Prikry: Borel sets and Ramsey's theorem, Journal of Symbolic Logic 38 (1973), 193–198. MR0337630
  6. Ronald Graham, Bruce Rothschild and Joel Spencer: Ramsey theory, Wiley, New York, 1990. MR1044995
  7. Thomas Jech: Set Theory, Academic Press, San Diego, 1978. MR0506523
  8. Vladimir Kanovei: Borel Equivalence Relations. Structure and Classifications; University Lecture Series 44, American Mathematical Society, Providence, RI, 2008. MR2441635
  9. Richard Laver: Products of infinitely many perfect trees, Journal of London Mathematical Society 29 (1984), 385–396. MR0754925
  10. Krzysztof Mazur: ${F_\sigma}$-ideals and ${\omega_1}{\omega_1}*$ gaps in the Boolean algebra $P(\omega)/I$, Fundamenta Mathematicae 138 (1991), 103–111. MR1124539
  11. Andrzej Rosłanowski: $n$-localization property, Journal of Symbolic Logic 71 (2006), 881–902. MR2251546
  12. Andrzej Rosłanowski and Saharon Shelah: Norms on possibilities I: forcing with trees and creatures; Memoirs of the American Mathematical Society 141, xii + 167 p., 1999. math.LO/9807172. MR1613600
  13. Jindřich Zapletal: Forcing Idealized, Cambridge Tracts in Mathematics 174, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 2008. MR2391923
  14. Jindřich Zapletal: Preservation of $\roman {P}$-points and definable forcing, submitted to Fundamenta Mathematicae, 2008. cf. MR2520149

MR2847327 Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

The character spectrum of $\beta(\Bbb N)$. (English summary)
Topology Appl. 158 (2011), no. 18, 2535–2555.
03E35 (03E17 03E55 54A25)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-03-15 Review Published2012-11-07

For a non-principal ultrafilter $U$ on the set of natural numbers $\omega$, its character $\chi (U)$ is the least size of a subfamily $B \subseteq U$ such that every member of $U$ contains a member of $B$. The character spectrum ${\roman{Sp}}_\chi$ is the set of all characters. The author proves several consistency results concerning the possible behavior of the set ${\roman{Sp}}_\chi$.
   (1) Given two disjoint sets $\Theta_1$ and $\Theta_2$ of regular cardinals such that $\theta^{<\theta} = \theta$ for $\theta \in \Theta_1$ and all members of $\Theta_2$ are measurable cardinals, there is a partial order ${\Bbb{P}}$ which forces that $\Theta_1 \subseteq {\roman{Sp}}_\chi$ and $\Theta_2 \cap {\roman{Sp}}_\chi =\emptyset$ while preserving cardinals. In fact ${\Bbb{P}}$ is a product of a ccc partial order and a partial order not adding reals. The latter adjoins ultrafilters with character in $\Theta_1$ while the measurables are used to guarantee cardinals in $\Theta_2$ are not characters, by a method first explored by the same author in [Colloq. Math. 111 (2008), no. 2, 213–220; MR2365799].
   (2) Assuming the consistency of infinitely many compact cardinals, it is consistent that for any subset $A$ of $\{ n \in \omega : 1 \leq n \}$, $\{ \aleph_n : n \in A \}$ is the set of characters below $\aleph_\omega$. This is obtained by combining the first result with a product of Levy collapses. As a consequence of the collapsing method, the author obtains from the consistency of a measurable that it is consistent that ${\roman{Sp}}_\chi = \{ \aleph_1 , \aleph_3 \}$ and that it is consistent that ${\roman{Sp}}_\chi$ is cofinal in a cardinal $\mu$ of cofinality $\aleph_1$ while $\mu \notin {\roman{Sp}}_\chi$, thus answering two questions addressed in joint work of the author and the reviewer [Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 351 (1999), no. 7, 2643–2674; MR1686797].
Reviewed by Jörg D. Brendle

    References
  1. Istvan Juhász, Cardinal Functions in Topology–Ten Years Later, second edition, Math. Centre Tracts, vol. 123, Mathematisch Centrum, Amsterdam, 1980. MR0576927
  2. Kenneth Kunen, Ultrafilters and independent sets, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 172 (1972) 299–306. MR0314619
  3. Joerg Brendle, Saharon Shelah, Ultrafilters on $\omega$–their ideals and their cardinal characteristics, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 351 (1999) 2643–2674, math.LO/9710217. MR1686797
  4. Saharon Shelah, Two cardinal invariants of the continuum $(\partial < \roman a)$ and FS linearly ordered iterated forcing, Acta Math. 192 (2004) 187–223, also known under the title "Are $\roman a$ and $\partial$ your cup of tea?", math.LO/0012170. MR2096454
  5. Saharon Shelah, Long iterations for the continuum, Arch. Math. Logic, submitted for publication, math.LO/0112238.
  6. Saharon Shelah, The spectrum of characters of ultrafilters on $\omega$, Colloq. Math. 111 (2) (2008) 213–220, math.LO/0612240. MR2365799
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

Enayat, Ali(1-AMER-MS)

91904 Jerusalem, Israel

An improper arithmetically closed Borel subalgebra of $\scr P(\omega)\bmod\ssf{FIN}$. (English summary)
Topology Appl. 158 (2011), no. 18, 2495–2502.
03E15 (03C55 28A05 54H05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-03-15 Review Published2012-12-17

Summary: "We show the existence of a subalgebra $\scr A\subseteq\scr P(\omega)$ that satisfies the following three conditions:
$\bullet$
$\scr A$ is Borel (when $\scr P(\omega)$ is identified with $2^\omega$).
$\bullet$
$\scr A$ is arithmetically closed (i.e., $\scr A$ is closed under the Turing jump, and Turing reducibility).
$\bullet$
The forcing notion $(A,\subseteq)$ modulo the ideal \ssf{FIN} of finite sets collapses the continuum to $\aleph_0$.''

MR2832642 (2012g:03098) Reviewed
Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-EIM)
Einstein Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
Jerusalem 91904, Israel

Models of expansions of $\Bbb N$ with no end extensions. (English summary)
MLQ Math. Log. Q. 57 (2011), no. 4, 341–365.
03C62 (03E35 03E40)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2012-01-18 Review Published2012-04-06

In [Ann. Pure Appl. Logic 156 (2008), no. 2-3, 308–318; MR2484488] A. Enayat proved that there is an expansion ${\Bbb N}_{\scr A}=({\Bbb N}, A)_{A\in {\scr A}}$ of the standard model of arithmetic, where $\scr A$ is arithmetically closed, which has no conservative elementary extension. Enayat's construction used $\lozenge$ and the $\lozenge$ eliminating technique, which strongly suggested the question of how complex the family $\scr A$ has to be. Another question left open was whether there is an expansion ${\Bbb N}_{\scr A}$ such that some model of ${\rm Th}({\Bbb N}_{\scr A})$ has no elementary end extension. Shelah solves both problems. The main results of the paper are: (1) there is a Borel $\scr A\subseteq {\rm P}(\omega)$ such that ${\Bbb N}_{\scr A}$ has no conservative elementary extension; (2) there is an uncountable Borel $\scr B\subseteq {\rm P}(\omega)$ such that for any uncountable $\scr A\subset \scr B$, some model of ${\rm Th}({\Bbb N}_{\scr A})$ has no elementary end extension; (3) there is a Borel arithmetically closed ${\scr B}\subseteq {\rm P}(\omega)$ with no 2-Ramsey ultrafilter on it. All results depend on combinatorially complex arguments concerning the iterated creature forcing.
Reviewed by Roman Kossak

    References
  1. A. Enayat, A standard model of Peano Arithmetic with no conservative elementary extension, Ann. Pure Appl. Log. 156, 308–318 (2008). MR2484488
  2. A. Enayat and S. Shelah, An improper arithmetically closed Borel subalgebra of $P(\omega)$ mod FIN, Topol. Appl. submitted. cf. MR2847322
  3. M. Kaufmann and J. H. Schmerl, Remarks on weak notions of saturation in models of Peano Arithmetic, J. Symb. Log. 52, 129–148 (1987). MR0877860
  4. R. Kossak and J. Schmerl, The Structure of Models of Peano Arithmetic, Oxford Logic Guides, Vol. 50 (Oxford University Press, 2006). MR2250469
  5. G. Mills, A model of Peano arithmetic with no elementary end extension, J. Symb. Log. 43, 563–567 (1978). MR0491159
  6. A. Rosłanowski and S. Shelah, Norms on possibilities I: forcing with trees and creatures. Mem. Am. Math. Soc. 141(671) (1999). MR1613600
  7. A. Rosłanowski, S. Shelah, and O. Spinas, Nonproper Products, Preprint (RShS:941) (2009). cf. MR2914608
  8. S. Shelah, Iterated creature ${}^\omega \omega$-bounding forcing, Unpublished notes (Sh:F834).
  9. S. Shelah, Models of PA: Standard Systems without Minimal Ultrafilters, Preprint (Sh:944) (2009).
  10. S. Shelah, End extensions and numbers of countable models, J. Symb. Log. 43, 550–562 (1978). MR0503792
  11. S. Shelah. Models with second-order properties, II, Trees with no undefined branches, Ann. Math. Log. 14, 73–87 (1978). MR0501098
This list reflects references listed in the original paper as accurately as possible with no attempt to correct error.

MR2822491 (2012h:06037) Reviewed
Garti, Shimon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel
; Shelah, Saharon(IL-HEBR-IM)
Institute of Mathematics, Hebrew University
91904 Jerusalem, Israel

Depth of Boolean algebras. (English summary)
Notre Dame J. Form. Log. 52 (2011), no. 3, 307–314.
06E05 (03E45 03G05)
Review PDF Clipboard Journal Article Make Link
Publication Year 2011 Indexed 2011-12-08 Review Published2012-04-26

Let $\bf B$ be a Boolean algebra. Then ${\rm Depth}({\bf B})$ denotes the supremum of the cardinalities of well-ordered subsets in $\bf B$.
   Here the authors compare the depth of the ultraproduct of a family of Boolean algebras with the depth of the factors. They show: Suppose that $D$ is an ultrafilter on $\kappa$ and $\lambda^{\kappa} = \lambda$, $\{ {\bf B}_i\:\ i < \kappa \}$ is a family of Boolean algebras with ${\rm Depth}({\bf B}_i) \leq \lambda$ for every $i <\kappa$. Let $B = \prod_{i < \kappa} {\bf B}_i/D$. Then ${\rm Depth}({\bf B}) \leq \lambda^+$. In the proof they use a sequence of elementary submodels of $({\scr H}(\chi),\in)$ for a sufficiently large $\chi$.
   They also show that, for singular cardinals with small cofinality, there is no gap at all. This partially answers a problem raised by Monk.
Reviewed by Martin Weese

    References
  1. Chang, C. C., and H. J. Keisler, Model Theory, vol. 73 of Studies in Logic and the Foundations of Mathematics, North-Holland Publishing Co., Amsterdam, 1973. Zbl 0276.02032. MR 0409165. 312 MR0409165
  2. Donder, H.-D., "Regularity of ultrafilters and the core model," Israel Journal of Mathematics, vol. 63 (1988), pp. 289–322. Zbl 0663.03037. MR 969944. 312, 313 MR0969944
  3. Garti, S., and S. Shelah, "On Depth and ${\roman{Dept}}{{\roman{h}}^ + }$ of Boolean algebras," Algebra Universalis, vol. 58 (2008), pp. 243–48. Zbl 1141.06010. MR 2386531. 308 MR2386531
  4. Garti, S., and S. Shelah, "$(\kappa- \theta)$-weak normality," forthcoming in Journal of the Mathematical Society of Japan, (2011). 308, 313 cf. MR2916079
